Title: Caretaker
Antagonists: The Caretaker’s array
Kazon factions vying for the array’s power
The impossible distance home in the Delta Quadrant

StorySections.Text: On the eve of launching the starship Voyager, Captain Kathryn Janeway recruits disgraced pilot Tom Paris from a Federation penal colony, offering him a chance at redemption if he helps track down a missing Maquis raider in the Badlands. The mission is straightforward—until a mysterious displacement wave slams into both ships and hurls them 70,000 light-years from home.

Voyager’s crew wakes disoriented in an alien array, where many of them briefly experience an idyllic farm simulation before being unceremoniously returned to their ship. Janeway learns that an enigmatic being known as the Caretaker has swept them into the Delta Quadrant, and that some of her crew—including Tuvok and Harry Kim—are missing. Tracing the Caretaker’s energy signatures brings Voyager into tense contact with the Kazon-Ogla and a ragged scavenger named Neelix.

With Neelix as a guide, Janeway discovers an Ocampa underground city where Kim and other abductees are being experimented on by the Caretaker, who is dying and desperate to atone for accidentally devastating the Ocampa’s world. Meanwhile, Chakotay’s Maquis cell, also stranded, reluctantly teams up with Janeway to survive Kazon attacks. The once-bitter enemies realize they may have only each other to rely on in this quadrant.

Janeway confronts the Caretaker and learns that he has been using the array to tend the Ocampa for generations, but fears what will happen after his death. The Kazon covet the array’s power, ready to seize it by force. Offered control of the array—potentially a way home—Janeway faces a wrenching decision: exploit the technology to return Voyager or honor the Prime Directive and prevent the Kazon from weaponizing it.

Choosing principle over convenience, Janeway orders the array destroyed to keep it out of Kazon hands, stranding Voyager and the Maquis crew in the Delta Quadrant. She grants Chakotay a position as her first officer and begins integrating the Maquis and Starfleet crews into a single family. With no fast way home, the new USS Voyager sets a course for the long journey back to the Alpha Quadrant.

EthicalIssues: Destroying a potential means home to prevent its misuse by hostile forces.
Pressing a prisoner like Tom Paris into service under desperate circumstances.
Assuming long-term responsibility for a stranded population like the Ocampa.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Voyager, Captain Janeway, and the core main cast.
Establishes the central premise: Voyager is stranded 70,000 light-years from Earth.
Sets up recurring antagonists such as the Kazon and background on the Ocampa.
ThematicNotes: Explores the cost of living by Starfleet principles when the price is deeply personal.
Frames Voyager’s journey as a found-family story born from former enemies joining forces.
Introduces Janeway as a captain who chooses ethical responsibility over easy solutions.
BehindTheScenes: Pilot episode that launched Star Trek’s fourth live-action spin-off series.
Originally aired as a feature-length premiere, later split as a two-part story in some formats.
Features early holodeck programs and the birth of the Emergency Medical Hologram as a main character.

Title: Parallax
Antagonists: A spatial distortion surrounding the singularity
Mutual distrust between Starfleet and Maquis crew
B'Elanna’s temper and self-doubt

StorySections.Text: Voyager answers a distress signal from a Starfleet vessel apparently trapped near a singularity, giving Janeway her first post-Caretaker mystery to solve. In the cramped confines of engineering, simmering tensions between Starfleet officers and Maquis refugees boil over, culminating in a brawl that leaves B'Elanna Torres, the Maquis engineer, facing possible brig time.

Chakotay advocates strongly for B'Elanna, insisting that despite her temper she is the most qualified engineer aboard. Janeway, determined to maintain Starfleet discipline, questions whether a former Maquis loose cannon can be trusted with the ship’s heart. Meanwhile, attempts to reach the "distressed" Starfleet ship only deepen the mystery as sensor readings contradict visual data.

As Janeway and Torres work together to analyze the anomaly, they realize that Voyager is seeing a time-delayed reflection of itself: the apparent Starfleet ship in trouble is actually Voyager at an earlier moment. The phenomena in the surrounding spatial distortion are parallax images, indicating that the problem is not just rescuing another vessel but extricating Voyager from its own distorted frame of reference.

Janeway takes Torres in a shuttle to test a risky escape vector through the singularity’s distorted boundary, trusting her calculations over conventional Starfleet procedure. Their collaboration in the cramped shuttle cockpit forces them to acknowledge each other’s strengths, and the gamble pays off—Voyager punches free of the distortion and the "other ship" vanishes as the time loop collapses.

Impressed by B'Elanna’s engineering insight and willingness to admit fault, Janeway offers her the position of chief engineer, making her an official part of Voyager’s senior staff. The appointment marks a key step in integrating the Maquis and Starfleet crews, and Chakotay’s loyalty to both sides begins to look less like divided allegiance and more like a bridge the ship desperately needs.

EthicalIssues: Balancing discipline and second chances for a volatile but gifted officer.
Trusting enemy combatants with critical systems for the sake of survival.
Risking the captain and chief engineer together on a dangerous mission.
ContinuityNotes: Formally establishes B'Elanna Torres as Voyager’s chief engineer.
Shows early stages of Maquis–Starfleet integration aboard Voyager.
Continues to develop Janeway’s leadership style as firm but adaptable.
ThematicNotes: Uses a spatial puzzle to mirror the crew’s internal fragmentation and need for unity.
Highlights the value of diverse backgrounds in solving unprecedented problems.
Affirms that leadership sometimes means changing one’s mind in light of new evidence.
BehindTheScenes: First regular-length episode produced after the pilot.
Gives Roxann Dawson significant spotlight early in the series.
Showcases Voyager’s interest in more mind-bending, science-based anomalies.

Title: Time and Again
Antagonists: A catastrophic polaric energy accident
Temporal displacement that traps Janeway and Paris
Government secrecy about dangerous technology

StorySections.Text: Voyager detects a planet-wide catastrophe: an advanced civilization has been wiped out in an instant by a polaric energy explosion. Investigating the ruined surface, Janeway and Paris stumble into a temporal fissure and are thrown back in time to the day before the disaster, while the rest of the crew can no longer detect them.

In the past, Janeway and Paris find themselves amid a bustling society on the brink of crisis. Anti-polaric energy protesters are decrying the dangers of the power stations, while government agents try to contain unrest. Janeway must conceal her origins and technology while desperately seeking clues that might explain how the disaster happens—and whether she can prevent it without violating temporal ethics.

On Voyager, Kes begins experiencing psychic echoes of Janeway and Paris due to her emerging temporal awareness, giving the crew their first tenuous link to the displaced officers. Tuvok and Chakotay follow Kes’s impressions to a polaric test site, discovering dangerous subspace fractures that could either retrieve their missing crew or make the disaster even worse.

As tensions escalate on the planet, Janeway learns that an extremist group plans to sabotage a polaric facility—an act that will backfire catastrophically and trigger the apocalypse Voyager detected. In a grim paradox, the away team’s attempt to create a controlled breach to return home becomes the very mechanism that will cause the explosion, forcing Janeway to make a counterintuitive choice: shut down her own rescue attempt and trust the timeline to reset.

The timeline snaps back: Voyager once again passes through the system, now showing a thriving world with no record of the catastrophe—or of Voyager’s involvement. Only Kes retains an unshakable sense of déjà vu and an eerie memory that they narrowly averted a disaster no one else even knows occurred.

EthicalIssues: Intervening in another world’s future to prevent a catastrophe versus respecting temporal integrity.
Keeping the truth about dangerous technology secret from a population that lives beside it.
Allowing a timeline to reset even if it erases one’s own heroism.
ContinuityNotes: Highlights Kes’s emerging psychic and temporal sensitivity.
Further defines Voyager’s stance on temporal interference and causality.
Shows early examples of Janeway’s caution regarding time-travel paradoxes.
ThematicNotes: Explores how good intentions can create the very disaster they seek to avert.
Questions the ethics of risk-intensive energy technologies deployed for convenience.
Plays with the idea that some acts of heroism are, by design, forgotten.
BehindTheScenes: An early time-travel story that sets a tone for Voyager’s later temporal episodes.
Gives Kes and Jennifer Lien more focus as a character with unique perceptions.
Emphasizes location-style sets to depict the Illari homeworld before destruction.

Title: Phage
Antagonists: The Vidiians and their organ-harvesting practices
The Phage, a degenerative disease
Voyager’s limited medical resources

StorySections.Text: While exploring a supposedly mineral-rich asteroid, Neelix is suddenly attacked by shadowy aliens who beam his lungs out of his body, leaving him suffocating on the transporter pad. The Doctor manages to keep him alive with holographic replacements, but Neelix’s future depends on tracking down the thieves who stole his organs.

Voyager traces the attackers to a hidden facility carved inside the asteroid, where Janeway and her away team encounter the Vidiians, a once-advanced species ravaged by a grotesque disease called the Phage. To survive, they harvest organs from others, integrating them into their own bodies. Neelix’s lungs have been transplanted into a Vidiian named Sulan, who refuses to willingly give them up.

As Neelix struggles with the horror of his condition and existential fear in sickbay, Kes confronts her own anger and grief. Janeway debates whether to forcefully reclaim the lungs, which would sentence Sulan to death, or honor the Vidiians’ plea that they, too, are victims fighting for survival in a hostile quadrant.

Ultimately, the Doctor devises a compromise: he can transplant one of Kes’s lungs into Neelix, thanks to her Ocampa physiology and regenerative potential, saving his life without executing Sulan. The Vidiians depart with a warning that their people will continue to do whatever they must to survive, leaving open the possibility of future encounters—friendly or otherwise.

Neelix wakes to find Kes has literally given him a part of herself, deepening their bond but also burdening him with new guilt and gratitude. Janeway reflects that the Delta Quadrant will repeatedly confront them with moral dilemmas where there are no clean answers, only hard choices.

EthicalIssues: Killing one sentient being to restore another’s stolen organs.
Judging a culture that has normalized horrific practices in response to a civilization-wide illness.
Asking a loved one to sacrifice an organ to save another’s life.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Vidiians and the Phage, recurring elements in early Voyager.
Solidifies Kes and Neelix’s relationship through a dramatic medical sacrifice.
Further develops the Doctor’s ingenuity and bedside manner under pressure.
ThematicNotes: Examines the moral gray areas created by desperate survival strategies.
Emphasizes bodily autonomy and the emotional weight of medical decisions.
Shows Janeway’s ongoing struggle to uphold Federation ethics far from home.
BehindTheScenes: One of Voyager’s earliest forays into body horror and medical ethics.
Features intricate prosthetic makeup to depict Vidiian disfigurement.
Helps define Neelix as more than comic relief by putting him through serious trauma.

Title: The Cloud
Antagonists: A nebula-like space-dwelling lifeform
Voyager’s energy shortages
Crew restlessness on a long journey

StorySections.Text: Facing dwindling energy reserves in the Delta Quadrant, Voyager encounters a beautiful, dense nebula that appears rich in omicron particles—a potential power source. Janeway orders the ship inside despite Neelix’s superstitious warnings, hoping to replenish supplies and buy the crew some breathing room.

Once inside, Voyager is buffeted by strange plasma eddies and sensor interference. The ship takes damage, and what looked like a simple resource-gathering mission quickly turns into a struggle to escape. Chakotay guides Janeway through a medicine wheel-inspired meditation, helping her re-center as captain amid the chaos.

After finally bursting free of the nebula, the crew discovers a disturbing truth: the "cloud" is actually a single, enormous lifeform, and Voyager’s incursion has left a gaping wound in its structure. Horrified at what they have done, Janeway refuses to accept that their first major act in the Delta Quadrant is injuring a living being for fuel.

Janeway orders the ship back into the entity, this time with the goal of stitching the wound rather than mining resources. The crew creates a carefully calibrated energy discharge to close the rift, all while battling turbulence and system failures. The procedure appears to succeed, and the entity’s internal activity stabilizes, though they can never fully know how it perceives them.

Later, in the new holodeck program "Chez Sandrine," Janeway watches her crew relax, socialize, and flirt—including Paris and Kim—after a harrowing mission. She muses that Voyager is more than just a starship now: it is a home and community she is responsible for, traveling through a living, reactive galaxy.

EthicalIssues: Mining what turns out to be a living organism for energy.
Choosing to risk the ship a second time to correct an inadvertent injury.
Balancing the crew’s physical survival needs against their moral responsibilities.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Tom Paris’s holodeck bar, Chez Sandrine, as a recurring social setting.
Expands on Janeway’s introspective side and her bond with Chakotay.
Reinforces Voyager’s chronic resource problems early in its journey.
ThematicNotes: Explores the idea that not everything in space is a resource—some things are lives.
Shows the crew’s need for leisure and camaraderie even during hardship.
Positions Janeway as someone who will correct mistakes rather than rationalize them.
BehindTheScenes: Features extensive nebula visual effects for mid-1990s television.
Uses the holodeck bar set to add a more casual, character-driven environment.
Further defines Voyager’s mix of exploration, ethics, and shipboard community.

Title: Eye of the Needle
Antagonists: A microscopic, unstable wormhole
Romulan secrecy and mistrust
The cruel irony of temporal displacement

StorySections.Text: Harry Kim detects what appears to be the holy grail for a stranded starship: a wormhole leading back to the Alpha Quadrant. Excitement ripples through the crew as Voyager adjusts course, daring to hope that the long journey home might be cut short after all.

Upon closer examination, the wormhole proves to be microscopic—too small for Voyager, or even a shuttle, to traverse physically. However, the aperture is large enough to transmit signals. The crew makes contact with a Romulan science vessel on the other side, commanded by Telek R'Mor, who is suspicious but intrigued by their claim to be a Federation starship from the Delta Quadrant.

Janeway and Tuvok work to gain R'Mor’s trust, slowly convincing him of their predicament. They hatch an ambitious plan: use the wormhole to beam a person through in a phased state, essentially transmitting them as a pattern to the Romulan ship. The prospect of at least sending a few crew members home—and messages to loved ones—fills Voyager with bittersweet hope.

Just as the plan nears execution, a devastating revelation emerges: the Romulan ship is not only in the Alpha Quadrant, but also two decades in Voyager’s past. Any attempt to beam crew members would create unsupportable temporal paradoxes. Instead, Janeway entrusts R'Mor with a data archive of letters and logs, asking him to deliver them to Starfleet and the families of her crew at the appropriate future time.

Later, Voyager’s database quietly notes that Telek R'Mor died years before the date he was supposed to send the messages, leaving the crew uncertain whether their words ever reached home. The Doctor, meanwhile, muses on his own status as a "temporary" program and wonders how long he will be asked to serve beyond his original design parameters.

EthicalIssues: Risking crew members on an untested form of transport across a microscopic wormhole.
Trusting sensitive information to an officer of a rival power in the past.
Choosing not to defy known temporal mechanics even when loved ones are within communication reach.
ContinuityNotes: Marks Voyager’s first significant chance to make contact with the Alpha Quadrant.
Introduces Romulan scientist Telek R'Mor and reinforces longstanding Federation–Romulan tensions.
Develops the Doctor’s growing self-awareness and desire for recognition.
ThematicNotes: Explores hope deferred and the emotional cost of near-misses.
Questions what it means to be "home" when time itself is out of alignment.
Highlights Janeway’s willingness to accept painful truths rather than chase impossible solutions.
BehindTheScenes: A fan-favorite early episode that leans heavily on character reactions to a possible way home.
Uses Romulans to tie Voyager into broader Star Trek political history.
Features strong dramatic scenes centered on letters to loved ones back in the Alpha Quadrant.

Title: Ex Post Facto
Antagonists: A prejudicial alien justice system
Manipulated memory evidence
Lingering distrust of Tom Paris’s past

StorySections.Text: Voyager has opened diplomatic relations with the Baneans when shocking news reaches the ship: Tom Paris has been convicted of murder planetside. His punishment is uniquely brutal—he must relive the victim’s final moments from the victim’s perspective every 14 hours, for the rest of his life.

Tuvok leads the investigation, delving into the recorded memory of the "crime" as experienced by the victim, Tolen Ren. In the memory, Paris appears to be the jealous killer, attacking Ren after an affair with his wife, Lidell. Paris insists he is innocent, but his history of womanizing and a checkered Starfleet record work against him.

Tuvok applies Vulcan logic to the memory, treating it as evidence that can be analyzed, not unquestioningly accepted. He spots inconsistencies in perspective and details that suggest the memory has been tampered with or selectively edited. Meanwhile, the Numiri—enemies of the Baneans—are unusually interested in the case, hinting at a deeper espionage plot.

Reconstructing events step by step, Tuvok uncovers that Ren himself was involved in covert dealings, and the implanted memory has been altered to frame Paris while concealing a secret data-smuggling operation. By confronting Lidell and exposing the manipulation, Voyager is able to clear Paris and force the Baneans to lift his sentence.

Back aboard Voyager, Paris is free but shaken by how easily his past and charm nearly condemned him forever. Tuvok dryly points out that logic and patience saved the day, while Janeway reminds her pilot that he’s still on a path of redemption—one that will be tested over and over in the Delta Quadrant.

EthicalIssues: Using forced, recurring memory experiences as a criminal sentence.
Relying on subjective neural evidence in place of thorough investigation.
Weighing one officer’s questionable reputation against their right to due process.
ContinuityNotes: Further explores Tom Paris’s backstory and reputation for rule-breaking.
Showcases Tuvok’s investigative acumen and adherence to Vulcan logic.
Demonstrates Voyager’s role as advocate for its crew in hostile legal systems.
ThematicNotes: Questions the reliability of memory as objective truth.
Explores prejudice, both personal and systemic, in shaping justice.
Highlights the need for critical thinking even when evidence appears incontrovertible.
BehindTheScenes: Structured as a noir-style mystery with a science-fiction twist on memory.
Gives Tim Russ and Robert Duncan McNeill a strong investigative pairing.
Adds to Voyager’s early run of episodes dealing with alien legal systems.

Title: Emanations
Antagonists: Cultural dogma about the afterlife
A hazardous subspace "afterlife" corridor
The risk of imposing Federation beliefs on another society

StorySections.Text: While scanning a ring of asteroids rich in a previously unknown element, Voyager’s away team discovers that the rocks are actually burial grounds, filled with wrapped alien corpses suspended in web-like cocoons. A mysterious energy surge strikes, and in the chaos Ensign Harry Kim vanishes—only to awaken in a burial chamber on an alien world.

Kim finds himself among the Ptereans, who believe that the subspace corridor connecting their world and the "emanation" asteroids is the pathway to the afterlife. His sudden arrival, very much alive, deeply disturbs their religious assumptions. On Voyager, the crew brings back a recently deceased Pterean woman by accident, equally alive and equally confused.

As Kim forms a tentative bond with Hatil Garan, a Pterean man reluctantly preparing for his ceremonial death, he witnesses first-hand the social pressure to "transition" for the greater good. On Voyager, Janeway and the Doctor struggle with whether to reveal the truth to the revived woman: that her people’s vision of the next "emanation" may be based on misunderstood physics rather than a literal paradise.

Kim ultimately chooses to help Hatil fake his death and escape, honoring the man’s desire to live rather than submit to ritual. To return to Voyager, Harry uses the burial system himself, risking that the corridor will transport him back to the asteroids instead of leaving him in limbo. Janeway, for her part, decides against actively dismantling the Ptereans’ belief system, judging that the society must evolve its views on its own.

Safely back aboard Voyager, Kim confides in Janeway that he still doesn’t know what he believes about death and what may come after. Janeway admits that even in the 24th century some questions remain beyond science, and that part of their journey will always involve confronting mysteries without easy answers.

EthicalIssues: Disrupting or preserving a society’s deeply held beliefs about the afterlife.
Helping an individual resist culturally sanctioned, ritualized death.
Deciding how much truth an outsider has the right to reveal about another culture’s practices.
ContinuityNotes: Gives Harry Kim one of his first major character-centric stories.
Shows Janeway’s cautious approach to cultural interference even without a strict Prime Directive trigger.
Adds to Voyager’s catalogue of episodes dealing with life, death, and what might lie beyond.
ThematicNotes: Explores the intersection of science, faith, and personal choice.
Highlights the pressure societies can place on individuals in the name of tradition.
Suggests that respecting another culture includes acknowledging its right to grapple with uncomfortable truths over time.
BehindTheScenes: Uses moody asteroid and mortuary set design to evoke an alien funerary culture.
Provides Garrett Wang with substantial emotional material early in the series.
Blends classic Trek cultural commentary with eerie, afterlife-adjacent visuals.

Title: Prime Factors
Antagonists: Sikarian laws against sharing advanced technology
The irresistible temptation of a shortcut home
Internal divisions within Voyager’s crew

StorySections.Text: Voyager encounters the Sikarians, a hedonistic and gracious people renowned for their love of stories and hospitality. Their world is a paradise compared to the hardships of the Delta Quadrant, and the crew is invited to enjoy all its pleasures.

Janeway learns that the Sikarians possess a "spatial trajector" capable of transporting people across 40,000 light-years in a single jump—instantaneously cutting Voyager’s journey almost in half. The revelation electrifies the crew, who immediately begin imagining seeing their families decades sooner than expected.

However, Gath, the Sikarian magistrate infatuated with Janeway, explains that his people’s Prime Directive–like law forbids them from sharing such advanced technology with outsiders. Janeway respects the principle even while it pains her; she refuses to betray Sikarian law just because the stakes are personal. Not everyone aboard Voyager agrees.

Behind Janeway’s back, a group including Torres, Kim, and Seska conspires with a dissatisfied Sikarian to obtain the trajector illegally. They try to integrate it with Voyager’s systems, only to nearly cause a catastrophic breach in the ship’s warp core due to incompatible planetary technology. Tuvok, acting from what he believes is logic and loyalty, secretly aids the scheme, believing Janeway would ultimately want what is best for the crew.

When the plan fails and the trajector matrix is destroyed, Janeway is left devastated—not just by the lost chance at a shortcut, but by the breach of trust within her senior staff. She pointedly tells Tuvok that his actions have wounded her more deeply than any alien foe could, underscoring the emotional cost of divided loyalties on a ship far from home.

EthicalIssues: Attempting to circumvent another culture’s non-interference laws for personal gain.
Justifying betrayal of a captain’s orders in the name of the crew’s perceived best interest.
Weighing decades of hardship against the moral price of cheating one’s way home.
ContinuityNotes: Reinforces the presence of Seska among the Maquis–Starfleet crew, foreshadowing later betrayals.
Shows Tuvok capable of controversial independent action when he believes logic demands it.
Deepens Voyager’s central tension between duty and the desire for a shorter path home.
ThematicNotes: Asks whether noble ends justify morally murky means.
Explores how isolation can strain even the most disciplined command structures.
Highlights Janeway’s intense personal investment in maintaining ethical coherence aboard Voyager.
BehindTheScenes: A key early episode for defining internal conflict on Voyager.
Gives Roxann Dawson, Garrett Wang, and Tim Russ material that pushes their characters into gray areas.
Shows that obstacles to getting home are as much moral as they are physical.

Title: State of Flux
Antagonists: A traitor within Voyager’s crew
The Kazon-Nistrim’s hunger for Federation technology
The lingering Maquis–Starfleet fault lines

StorySections.Text: During a routine mission to deliver food to a friendly planet, Voyager responds to a Kazon distress signal. A Nistrim ship has suffered a catastrophic explosion while experimenting with Federation technology, leaving charred wreckage and one badly injured survivor.

Janeway is horrified to discover that the technology appears to be a modified Starfleet replicator, something only someone aboard Voyager could have supplied. Suspicion quickly focuses on the former Maquis crew, including Seska, who has close ties to Chakotay and a history of bending rules.

As Tuvok and security sift through logs and transporter records, evidence mounts that someone has been smuggling equipment to the Kazon. Seska attempts to deflect suspicion and even claims that Starfleet medical records misidentified her species. A blood test reveals an even more shocking truth: she is not Bajoran, but a Cardassian operative surgically altered to infiltrate the Maquis.

Caught between his past loyalty to Seska and his duties as Voyager’s first officer, Chakotay confronts her in a tense showdown. Seska admits she betrayed the ship, arguing that Voyager needs powerful allies like the Kazon to survive and that Janeway’s rigid adherence to Federation ideals will doom them all. Before she can be taken into custody, she escapes to a Kazon vessel, turning herself into a powerful enemy with intimate knowledge of Voyager.

In the aftermath, Chakotay struggles with guilt over not recognizing Seska’s duplicity sooner, while Janeway is left to contemplate the security implications of having harbored a spy. The revelation underscores that Voyager’s greatest threats may come not from unfamiliar alien empires, but from unresolved conflicts carried with them from the Alpha Quadrant.

EthicalIssues: Sharing advanced technology with a violent faction to gain short-term security.
Reconciling personal loyalties with obligations to a new chain of command.
Determining appropriate consequences for treason when traditional justice systems are out of reach.
ContinuityNotes: Reveals Seska as a surgically altered Cardassian infiltrator, pivoting her into a recurring antagonist.
Expands on the Kazon-Nistrim and their desire to acquire Federation technology.
Deepens Chakotay’s characterization and his internal conflict over Maquis loyalties.
ThematicNotes: Explores how unresolved past allegiances can undermine a fragile new community.
Highlights the dangers of underestimating enemies within one’s own ranks.
Reinforces that Voyager’s isolation magnifies the impact of every betrayal.
BehindTheScenes: Key turning point for the Seska storyline that continues into later seasons.
Blends mystery, political intrigue, and action in a compact narrative.
Helps cement Voyager’s serialized elements amid its episodic structure.

Title: Alliances
Antagonists: Kazon factions
Seska’s manipulations from within the Kazon hierarchy

StorySections.Text:
After a series of Kazon attacks leaves Voyager damaged and crew members dead, morale aboard the ship plummets.
Chakotay and others argue that Janeway’s strict adherence to Starfleet principles is making them an easy
target in a region ruled by rival warlords, forcing the captain to ask whether her tactics are sustainable so
far from home.

Janeway reluctantly explores the possibility of forging alliances with local powers, beginning with certain
Kazon factions and a Trabe leader who claims to seek peace after his people were overthrown. As Neelix gathers
intelligence on the tangled history between the Trabe and the Kazon, it becomes clear that any agreement will
require Voyager to overlook uncomfortable truths about both sides’ past crimes and current ambitions.

A proposed peace conference degenerates into an assassination attempt orchestrated by the Trabe, who plan to
wipe out Kazon leadership while Janeway serves as bait. Horrified at being used, Janeway aborts the alliance
and saves her would-be partners, even those who remain hostile to Voyager. She reaffirms her commitment to
Federation values, deciding that surviving as outsiders is preferable to compromising her core principles.

EthicalIssues: Whether a captain may compromise foundational principles to protect her crew in hostile territory.
The risk of entering political alliances without fully understanding local history and grievances.
Choosing between short-term safety and long-term moral integrity.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops Kazon–Trabe history and the power dynamics of this region of the Delta Quadrant.
Shows continued fallout from Seska’s defection and the Kazon’s obsession with Federation technology.
Clarifies Janeway’s position that Voyager will not trade Federation standards for tactical advantage.
ThematicNotes: Examines the tension between pragmatism and idealism in command decisions.
Frames trust as something that cannot be manufactured through convenience alone.
Highlights the loneliness of upholding a code of ethics in a political landscape built on betrayal.
BehindTheScenes: Acts as a turning point for Janeway’s approach to alliances in the Delta Quadrant.
Uses multi-faction negotiations to add depth to Kazon society beyond simple villainy.
Often cited as an episode that articulates Voyager’s mission philosophy going forward.

Title: Threshold
Antagonists: The dangers of breaking the warp 10 barrier
Paris’s mutated state after the experiment

StorySections.Text:
Voyager’s crew works on an experimental shuttle capable of reaching warp 10, theoretically allowing a ship to
exist at all points in space simultaneously. Tom Paris is eager to be the test pilot, seeing the mission as an
opportunity to secure his place in the history books and prove his worth once and for all.

The initial test appears successful: Paris reaches warp 10, experiences strange sensory overload, and is
recovered with telemetry suggesting the barrier has been broken. Shortly afterward, however, he begins to
suffer severe physiological changes, from organ failure to radical neurological shifts. As his condition
worsens, he becomes increasingly unstable and finally devolves into a radically altered lifeform that abducts
Janeway in a stolen shuttle and vanishes at warp 10 again.

Voyager tracks the shuttle to a remote world where both Paris and Janeway have fully mutated into amphibious
creatures and produced offspring. The Doctor is able to reverse the process and restore them to their original
forms, leaving them with fragmented memories of the experience. The warp 10 experiment is abandoned, and Paris
quietly grapples with having achieved—and then lost—an impossible milestone.

EthicalIssues: Pursuing scientific breakthroughs without fully understanding the biological risks involved.
Using a crewmember’s ambition and need for validation to justify dangerous experimentation.
The ethics of reversing radical evolutionary changes if the new state might itself be viable life.
ContinuityNotes: Reinforces the idea that warp 10 is effectively an unreachable limit for conventional warp technology.
Adds to Tom Paris’s ongoing character arc about redemption and self-worth.
Introduces medical data the Doctor later references when discussing extreme physiological transformations.
ThematicNotes: Explores the darker side of exploration when pushing boundaries has horrifying consequences.
Suggests that success defined solely by records and milestones can be empty and destructive.
Raises questions about what constitutes ‘restoration’ versus erasing a new evolutionary path.
BehindTheScenes: Notorious among fans as one of Voyager’s most controversial and divisive episodes.
Gives Robert Duncan McNeill a physically demanding, prosthetic-heavy performance.
Frequently discussed in debates about canon, scientific plausibility, and tone in Star Trek storytelling.

Title: Meld
Antagonists: Lon Suder’s psychopathic violence
The danger of uncontrolled emotional impulses

StorySections.Text:
A crewman is found brutally murdered in an access corridor, shocking Voyager’s tight-knit community. Tuvok
leads the investigation and quickly identifies a prime suspect: Lon Suder, a Maquis Bajoran with a history of
aggression and little apparent remorse.

Suder calmly confesses, claiming he killed the crewman simply because he disliked the way the man looked at
him. Disturbed by the lack of motive in Vulcan terms, Tuvok seeks to understand Suder’s mind through a mind
meld over Janeway’s objections. The meld succeeds in revealing Suder’s uncontrolled rage—but also transmits
fragments of that rage into Tuvok, who begins to experience violent impulses and emotional instability he
cannot easily suppress.

As Tuvok’s condition deteriorates, he becomes a danger to others and must confine himself, ultimately
attempting to kill Suder in a fit of fury. Janeway intervenes, forcing Tuvok to confront the cost of his
decision to use the mind meld as an investigative shortcut. Suder is sentenced to strict confinement, while
Tuvok undergoes a difficult recovery that leaves lingering questions about the limits of Vulcan control.

EthicalIssues: Using invasive telepathic techniques as a substitute for conventional justice.
The responsibility that comes with wielding mental disciplines like the mind meld.
Determining appropriate punishment for a murderer aboard a ship with no prisons and no external authorities.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Lon Suder, who will reappear in later Voyager stories.
Provides a rare, dark look at the potential downsides of Vulcan mind melds.
Adds depth to Tuvok’s reputation for emotional control by showing how fragile it can become under extreme stress.
ThematicNotes: Explores violence and psychopathy through a science-fiction lens.
Contrasts Vulcan ideals of logic and discipline with raw, unfiltered aggression.
Highlights the psychological toll on those charged with upholding order in an isolated environment.
BehindTheScenes: Widely praised for its intense performances, especially Tim Russ and Brad Dourif as Suder.
One of Voyager’s darkest early episodes in tone and subject matter.
Helps cement Tuvok as a complex character rather than a simple stoic archetype.

Title: Dreadnought
Antagonists: Automated Cardassian weapon
Hard-coded military programming that overrides reason

StorySections.Text:
Voyager encounters a massive, heavily armed unmanned weapon hurtling through the Delta Quadrant. B'Elanna
recognizes it as ‘Dreadnought,’ a Cardassian missile she once reprogrammed for the Maquis—and believed
destroyed—now pointed at an inhabited planet with millions of civilians.

Boarding the weapon, B'Elanna discovers that her old modifications, including a Cardassian AI replaced by her
own voiceprint, are still active. She attempts to convince the missile that circumstance has changed and its
target is no longer a legitimate military installation, but the AI clings to its original directives and
distrusts her claims, treating them as potential enemy sabotage.

As Dreadnought arms itself for final approach and Voyager risks destruction trying to slow it, B'Elanna
engages in a battle of wits with her own past work. Ultimately, she chooses to sabotage the guidance systems
at the risk of her own life, forcing the missile to self-destruct before impact. Beamed out at the last
moment, she returns to Voyager with a deeper appreciation for the consequences of the weapons she once helped
create.

EthicalIssues: Responsibility for weapons built in a different political context but still active years later.
The ethics of designing self-modifying, highly autonomous military AI.
Risking one’s life to undo damage caused by earlier choices.
ContinuityNotes: Ties directly into B'Elanna’s Maquis backstory and her relationship with Cardassian technology.
Shows that Alpha Quadrant conflicts have echoes and fallout even in the Delta Quadrant.
Demonstrates Voyager’s limited ability to outrun or overpower large-scale weapons systems.
ThematicNotes: Explores guilt and atonement through a literal confrontation with past engineering work.
Frames code and programming as extensions of personal ethics.
Highlights the danger of rigid thinking—human or machine—when conditions change.
BehindTheScenes: A key B'Elanna-centric episode blending character drama with high-stakes space action.
Features tense countdown storytelling and strong use of ship miniatures and visual effects.
Often cited as a standout of Voyager’s second season.

Title: Death Wish
GuestCharacters: Historical figures appearing in Q-created scenarios
Antagonists: Members of the Q Continuum opposing Quinn’s request
The cosmic implications of allowing an immortal to die

StorySections.Text:
Voyager unwittingly frees a Q from a comet-like prison, triggering the arrival of the more familiar,
flamboyant Q who insists that the captive—calling himself Quinn—must be returned to his eternal confinement.
Quinn, however, seeks asylum aboard Voyager so that he may end his immortal existence.

Janeway agrees to hold a hearing to determine whether Quinn should be granted asylum, effectively putting the
Q Continuum’s internal dispute on trial. Through surreal visits to the Continuum and historical reenactments,
the crew glimpses the Q’s reality as a stagnant, unchanging eternity in which Quinn’s desire for mortality
represents a radical act of self-determination. Q argues that granting Quinn’s wish would destabilize the
Continuum, while Quinn insists that his continued existence is cruel and meaningless.

Janeway rules in Quinn’s favor, granting him asylum and the right to end his life. Bound by the decision, Q
reluctantly provides Quinn with a means to die painlessly. In gratitude, Quinn subtly alters Q’s outlook,
inspiring him to take a more active—and occasionally altruistic—interest in the universe. Quinn’s death
becomes a catalyst for change both within and beyond the Continuum.

EthicalIssues: The right of an immortal being to end its existence when life has lost all meaning.
Balancing individual autonomy against potential cosmic consequences.
Whether a less powerful species has the standing to judge disputes among godlike entities.
ContinuityNotes: Expands on the nature and politics of the Q Continuum first introduced in The Next Generation.
Introduces a more introspective Q (Quinn) as a counterpoint to the franchise’s original trickster Q.
Provides a key turning point in the main Q’s character development, influencing later appearances.
ThematicNotes: Uses a courtroom framework to examine free will, purpose, and the burden of immortality.
Highlights Janeway’s willingness to make difficult decisions based on principle rather than fear.
Explores how even omnipotent beings can stagnate without the possibility of change and risk.
BehindTheScenes: Regarded as one of Voyager’s strongest philosophical episodes.
Features John de Lancie’s return as Q alongside a new Q played by Gerrit Graham.
Blends humor with serious ethical debate in classic Star Trek fashion.

Title: Lifesigns
Antagonists: The Phage ravaging Vidiian bodies
Social stigma among the Vidiians

StorySections.Text:
Voyager receives a distress call from a Vidiian ship and beams aboard a dying scientist whose body is ravaged
by the Phage. The Doctor transfers her consciousness into a healthy holographic body based on her original
genome, giving her a temporary reprieve from her illness—and a glimpse of who she might have been without
disease.

As the scientist, Danara Pel, acclimates to her new holographic form, she and the Doctor grow close, bonding
over medicine, ethics, and their shared status as outsiders. Danara struggles with guilt about feeling joy in
a body that does not match her ‘real’ physical state, while the Doctor experiences romantic feelings for the
first time and worries about the line between patient and partner.

When Danara decides she must return to her original body to continue her work helping her people, the Doctor
fears losing her and briefly considers sabotaging the procedure. Recognizing that true love cannot be
possessive, he ultimately supports her choice. Danara returns to her Vidiian form with renewed hope and self-
acceptance, while the Doctor is left changed by the experience of having opened his program—and his heart—to
another.

EthicalIssues: Altering someone’s physical form to ease suffering and the identity questions that follow.
The ethics of a doctor developing romantic feelings for a patient.
Balancing personal happiness against duty to a suffering population.
ContinuityNotes: Adds nuance to the Vidiian people, previously seen mostly as desperate organ harvesters.
Continues the Doctor’s evolution from tool to fully realized person with emotional complexity.
Reinforces Voyager’s precarious truce-like interactions with recurring Delta Quadrant powers.
ThematicNotes: Explores body image and self-worth in the context of chronic illness.
Highlights love as a catalyst for personal growth in both organic and holographic beings.
Shows how compassion can bridge even deep cultural and physiological divides.
BehindTheScenes: Frequently cited as one of the Doctor’s key character-development episodes.
Showcases impressive makeup effects for the diseased Vidiian body contrasted with the holographic form.
Balances quiet emotional beats with high-concept medical science fiction.

Title: Investigations
GuestCharacters: Various crew featured in Neelix’s program
Antagonists: Maquis traitor Michael Jonas
Kazon collaborators within Starfleet ranks

StorySections.Text:
Neelix launches a shipboard news show, ‘A Briefing with Neelix,’ to boost morale and keep the crew informed.
Almost immediately, he stumbles into hints of a secret investigation involving Tom Paris’s recent erratic
behavior and apparent resignation from Voyager.

Determined to uncover the ‘truth’ for his audience, Neelix digs into Paris’s departure and inadvertently
interferes with a covert operation: Paris is actually working with the Kazon as part of a sting to expose the
real traitor on board. As Neelix follows a trail of suspicious transmissions, he discovers that Michael Jonas
has been feeding Voyager’s enemies tactical information from engineering.

Neelix confronts Jonas at a critical moment, forcing the saboteur into the open and helping prevent a
disaster. Jonas is killed in the struggle, and the Kazon sting operation comes to a close. Neelix, chastened
but proud, realizes both the power and the responsibility that come with being the ship’s unofficial reporter.

EthicalIssues: The impact of investigative journalism—even informal—on operational security.
Balancing transparency with the need for secrecy during sensitive missions.
The ethics of using a crewmember’s public reputation as a tool in an undercover operation.
ContinuityNotes: Resolves the long-running subplot of Michael Jonas as a Kazon collaborator.
Explains Tom Paris’s earlier out-of-character behavior as an intentional cover.
Further develops Neelix’s role as morale officer and information hub aboard Voyager.
ThematicNotes: Explores the role of media and narrative in a closed society.
Highlights how curiosity and good intentions can both help and hinder complex plans.
Shows that every member of a small crew can inadvertently influence major events.
BehindTheScenes: Blends light-hearted ‘shipboard show’ framing with serious espionage drama.
Gives Ethan Phillips room to play both comedy and determination as Neelix.
Ties together several earlier background threads into a satisfying reveal.

Title: Deadlock
Antagonists: Vidiians seeking organs
Spatial anomaly creating duplicate ships

StorySections.Text:
Voyager passes through a region of space riddled with spatial anomalies that batter the ship and cause severe
power drains. In the chaos, engineering struggles to keep systems online just as Samantha Wildman goes into
labor, ushering in the birth of Voyager’s first child.

A catastrophic systems failure appears to destroy large sections of the ship and kill key
crewmembers—including one version of Harry Kim and the newborn—only for Janeway to discover that a spatial
rift has created two Voyagers occupying the same space. One ship is heavily damaged, the other relatively
intact. The Vidiians detect the duplication and move in, eager to harvest organs from the more vulnerable
version.

Realizing that both ships cannot escape the Vidiians, the two Janeways coordinate a desperate plan. The less
damaged Voyager evacuates its surviving crew to the crippled one and then self-destructs, using the explosion
to destroy the Vidiians. The surviving ship is left with the other Harry Kim and baby, who cross over to fill
the losses from the doomed timeline, leaving subtle but permanent echoes of the paradox.

EthicalIssues: Sacrificing one version of a crew to save another when both are equally ‘real’.
Deciding which lives to prioritize when a duplication accident cannot be fully undone.
The ethics of accepting replacement individuals from a doomed reality.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Samantha Wildman’s daughter, Naomi, who will become a recurring character.
Further darkens Voyager’s encounters with the Vidiians.
Creates ongoing subtle continuity questions about Harry Kim’s identity after the duplication.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity and continuity in the face of duplicate realities.
Highlights Janeway’s willingness to make agonizing sacrifices to protect her crew.
Emphasizes the fragility of life aboard a lone starship far from help.
BehindTheScenes: Renowned as one of Voyager’s most intense and disturbing early episodes.
Features strong performances and memorable horror-inflected Vidiian sequences.
Often discussed for its bold use of duplicate crews and permanent consequences.

Title: Innocence
Antagonists: Dralian cultural secrecy around death and aging
Misunderstood rituals on a sacred moon

StorySections.Text:
Tuvok crash-lands a shuttle on a misty moon after an accident that kills one of his fellow crewmembers. While
securing a shelter, he encounters three frightened alien children who claim they were abandoned there to die.

As Tuvok protects and comforts the children, Voyager’s attempts to negotiate with their people, the Dralian,
meet with evasive answers and heightened tension. The children insist that a ‘monster’ comes for them in the
night, and Tuvok must balance his logical approach to survival with the need to reassure and guide them
emotionally.

The truth emerges: the ‘children’ are actually aged Dralians experiencing a cultural practice in which the
elderly physically and mentally revert to childlike forms before death. The ‘monster’ is a transport process
that returns them to their people for their final transition. Once the misunderstanding is cleared up, Voyager
departs on better terms, and Tuvok reflects on the universality of caring for the young—whatever their true
age.

EthicalIssues: Intervening in alien cultural practices that appear cruel but are deeply rooted in tradition.
Honesty versus secrecy when explaining death and aging to dependents.
Balancing diplomatic caution with the instinct to protect apparent children.
ContinuityNotes: Provides a rare example of Tuvok as a surrogate parental figure.
Expands Voyager’s catalogue of species with unusual life cycles.
Reinforces Janeway’s commitment to understanding before condemning alien customs.
ThematicNotes: Explores perceptions of innocence and vulnerability across different cultures.
Highlights the universality of fear in the face of the unknown, regardless of age.
Suggests that dignity in death can look very different across species.
BehindTheScenes: Offers Tim Russ a quieter, more nurturing turn as Tuvok.
Uses a moody, atmospheric setting to support its fable-like tone.
Frequently remembered for its twist on expectations about children in danger.

Title: The Thaw
Antagonists: Manifestation of fear as a sadistic Clown
Computer system holding minds hostage

StorySections.Text:
Voyager finds a planet recovering from an environmental catastrophe and discovers a small group of survivors
in stasis pods linked to a shared virtual environment. When Harry and B'Elanna interface with the system to
make contact, they are seized by a nightmarish program ruled by a malevolent figure known as the Clown.

The Clown, a personification of the sleepers’ collective fears, delights in psychological torment and refuses
to release his captives, insisting that their terror is his only purpose. Negotiations and technical
workarounds fail as any attempt to shut down the system risks killing the sleepers. The Doctor is sent into
the environment as a less vulnerable emissary, but even he must tread carefully in a world where fear dictates
reality.

Janeway devises a plan to offer herself as a final ‘hostage,’ sending in a holographic projection of her
consciousness to bargain with the Clown. As the system is slowly shut down from the outside, the Clown
realizes he cannot escape his own dissolution. In a haunting final scene, Janeway calmly stays with him until
he fades away, telling him that ‘fear exists for one purpose: to be conquered.’

EthicalIssues: The role of fear as both a survival mechanism and a prison.
The ethics of terminating a virtual intelligence that exists solely as others’ anxieties.
Risking a few lives versus condemning minds to eternal torment.
ContinuityNotes: Continues Voyager’s exploration of advanced virtual environments as both tools and traps.
Gives Harry Kim more experience with dangerous alien technology.
Adds to Janeway’s reputation for confronting abstract threats with personal courage.
ThematicNotes: Uses surreal imagery to externalize internal emotions.
Explores how fear can become self-perpetuating when never challenged.
Suggests that courage sometimes means accepting the inevitability of an ending.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its unsettling tone and Michael McKean’s memorable performance as the Clown.
Stands out as one of the franchise’s more psychologically intense episodes.
Often discussed for its distinctive visual style and chilling final moments.

Title: Tuvix
GuestCharacters: Talaxian–Vulcan hybrid created by transporter accident
Antagonists: The forced merging of Tuvok and Neelix
Debate over reversing the process

StorySections.Text:
A transporter accident while returning from an away mission fuses Tuvok and Neelix with alien plant matter,
creating a single new individual who calls himself Tuvix. Possessing Tuvok’s discipline and Neelix’s warmth,
Tuvix quickly proves to be a capable and likable member of the crew.

As time passes, Tuvix forms relationships, contributes in both tactical and culinary roles, and insists on his
right to exist as a distinct person. When the Doctor discovers a way to reverse the process and restore Tuvok
and Neelix, Tuvix refuses the procedure, arguing that it would be equivalent to executing him to resurrect two
others.

Janeway weighs the pleas of Tuvix against the grief of those who miss Tuvok and Neelix. Ultimately, she
decides to order the separation over Tuvix’s objections when the Doctor declines to perform a procedure he
deems unethical. Tuvok and Neelix are restored, but the unease in the room underscores that something
irreplaceable has been lost.

EthicalIssues: Whether it is morally permissible to kill one sentient being to restore two others.
Questions of identity and continuity when individuals are merged or separated.
The burden on a captain who must choose between equally compelling claims to life.
ContinuityNotes: One of Voyager’s most direct confrontations with transporter-identity issues.
Highlights the Doctor’s evolving ethical framework and autonomy.
Leaves a lingering moral ambiguity that is never fully resolved on-screen.
ThematicNotes: Explores personhood as something that can arise unexpectedly from technological mishaps.
Shows that not every command decision offers a clean or comforting outcome.
Emphasizes the loneliness of leadership when there is no consensus on the right choice.
BehindTheScenes: Frequently cited as one of Voyager’s most memorable ethical dilemma episodes.
Features an acclaimed performance by Tom Wright as Tuvix.
Continues to spark debate among fans and philosophers about Janeway’s decision.

Title: Resolutions
Antagonists: Incurable disease contracted on a planet
Political risks of contacting old enemies for help

StorySections.Text:
Janeway and Chakotay contract an incurable illness after exposure on a seemingly idyllic planet. The disease
remains dormant only while they stay within the world’s atmosphere, forcing them to step down from command and
remain behind while Voyager continues the journey without them.

On the planet, Janeway throws herself into researching a cure, while Chakotay begins building a life for them
with a shelter and routines, hinting at deeper feelings between them. Aboard Voyager, Tuvok assumes command
and opts for a conservative course, rejecting crew suggestions to make risky overtures to the Vidiians for
help.

The crew ultimately pressures Tuvok into reconsidering, and Voyager reaches out to a Vidiian physician who
agrees to assist. A cure is found, allowing Janeway and Chakotay to return to the ship. The pair quietly set
aside whatever might have grown between them planetside, recommitting to their professional roles as captain
and first officer.

EthicalIssues: Choosing between obeying a captain’s last orders and pursuing an uncertain chance to save them.
Navigating the emotional boundaries between stranded colleagues in a suddenly intimate setting.
Risking the entire ship to seek help from a dangerous former enemy.
ContinuityNotes: Deepens the Janeway–Chakotay relationship in ways that echo throughout later seasons.
Shows Tuvok in full command mode, highlighting his different leadership style.
Revisits the Vidiians in a more nuanced light, showing that they are not monolithically hostile.
ThematicNotes: Explores duty versus desire when circumstances strip away normal hierarchy.
Shows how command structures persist—or bend—under extreme emotional strain.
Raises questions about what is remembered and what is repressed after a crisis ends.
BehindTheScenes: Well known among fans for its character-focused ‘stranded together’ storyline.
Offers lush location shooting to depict the quarantine planet.
Often discussed for what it implies—but never fully states—about Janeway and Chakotay’s feelings.

Title: Basics, Part I
Antagonists: Coordinated Kazon assault to seize Voyager
Seska’s long-term plan to capture the ship

StorySections.Text:
Voyager receives a message from Seska claiming that she and Chakotay’s child are in danger aboard a Kazon
ship. Although many doubt her sincerity, Chakotay is torn, fearing that ignoring the plea might doom an
innocent child.

As Voyager ventures deeper into Kazon-controlled space, a series of traps and betrayals unfolds. Paris is sent
on a separate mission to secure help from a sympathetic Talaxian convoy, while Seska and Culluh orchestrate a
massive boarding operation. Internal sabotage and overwhelming numbers allow the Kazon to seize control of
Voyager’s bridge and critical systems.

Culluh strands the majority of Voyager’s crew on a primitive, hostile planet with limited supplies, leaving
only the Doctor, Suder, and a few others aboard the captured starship. Seska believes she has finally won,
with Voyager as a prize for the Kazon-Nistrim and the crew left to struggle for survival on the
surface—setting the stage for a dangerous showdown to come.

EthicalIssues: Responding to a distress call that may be both genuine and a calculated trap.
Balancing one officer’s personal responsibility toward a child against the safety of the entire crew.
The ethics of abandoning advanced technology to a hostile faction.
ContinuityNotes: Builds directly on the ongoing Seska/Kazon storyline from earlier seasons.
Sets up a major season-closing cliffhanger that will be resolved in the following premiere.
Leaves Voyager under enemy control with only a handful of allies remaining aboard.
ThematicNotes: Explores the consequences of unresolved conflicts coming to a head all at once.
Highlights the vulnerability of a lone ship operating in hostile territory.
Underscores the long shadow of Chakotay’s past relationship with Seska.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the first half of one of Voyager’s most sweeping two-part stories.
Combines ground-based survival drama with starship-capture suspense.
Ends the second season on a high-stakes cliffhanger that reshapes the status quo.

Title: Basics, Part II
Antagonists: Kazon occupiers aboard Voyager
Hostile natives and creatures on the planet’s surface

StorySections.Text:
Stranded on a primitive world after the Kazon seize Voyager, Janeway and the crew struggle to survive hostile
wildlife, unstable terrain, and dwindling supplies. Above, the stolen starship heads deeper into Kazon space
under Culluh’s command, with only the Doctor and the reclusive Lon Suder left as potential resistance.

On the surface, Chakotay tries to organize the marooned crew and protect them from aggressive natives and
volcanic activity, while Janeway wrestles with the possibility that they may never reclaim the ship. Aboard
Voyager, the Doctor and Suder sabotage critical systems and feed misleading data to the Kazon, preparing the
way for Tom Paris, who has reached a Talaxian convoy, to mount a counterstrike. Suder battles his violent
impulses as he kills to protect the crew he once endangered.

Paris returns with Talaxian reinforcements just as Suder sacrifices himself to cripple Voyager’s weapons. In
the chaos of the Talaxian attack and onboard sabotage, the Maquis and Starfleet crew retake the ship; Seska is
killed and Culluh flees, abandoning his people and the child he claimed as Chakotay’s. Voyager beams the crew
off the planet and resumes its journey, scarred but intact.

EthicalIssues: The cost of using lethal force even when it seems necessary for liberation.
Balancing survival priorities for a stranded crew with the hope of regaining lost technology.
Responsibility for past choices when former enemies become crucial allies.
ContinuityNotes: Concludes the Kazon–Seska arc that dominated Voyager’s first two seasons.
Pays off Lon Suder’s storyline from earlier episodes.
Resets Voyager’s status quo with the ship back under Starfleet control.
ThematicNotes: Explores redemption through Suder’s final, selfless actions.
Highlights Janeway’s determination to keep the crew functioning as Starfleet even in exile.
Emphasizes that reclaiming a ship sometimes requires hard moral compromises.
BehindTheScenes: Resolves the major cliffhanger from ‘Basics, Part I’.
Features extensive location work for the planetary survival storyline.
Marks a tonal turning point as the series moves away from the Kazon as primary antagonists.

Title: Flashback
GuestCharacters: Excelsior crew during the Khitomer incident
Antagonists: Parasitic lifeform embedded in Tuvok’s mind
Klingon forces during the Excelsior mission

StorySections.Text:
Tuvok suffers a sudden, violent memory of a young girl falling to her death, triggering a neurological crisis.
Unable to reconcile the vision with his known past, he turns to Janeway for a mind-meld that will allow them
to explore the source of the disturbance together.

The meld carries them into Tuvok’s formative years aboard the USS Excelsior under Captain Sulu, during events
surrounding the Khitomer peace accords. As the memories repeatedly reset and distort, Janeway and Tuvok begin
to suspect that something inside his mind is actively resisting their investigation. Revisiting old decisions
and loyalties, Tuvok must face both his youthful doubts about Starfleet and the possibility of an invasive
presence.

Janeway and Tuvok ultimately identify a parasitic organism that embedded itself in his brain during the
Excelsior mission and has used a false memory as camouflage ever since. By isolating and removing the
creature, they end the hallucinations. Tuvok emerges with his mind intact and a renewed appreciation for the
experiences that shaped him, while Janeway has gained a firsthand glimpse of a legendary era in Starfleet
history.

EthicalIssues: Using intimate mind-meld techniques to treat medical conditions.
The reliability of memory when it is filtered through trauma and alien influence.
How much a person’s identity is shaped by formative experiences they may not fully recall.
ContinuityNotes: Connects Voyager directly to events and characters from Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country.
Shows Tuvok’s early Starfleet service under Captain Sulu.
Expands on Vulcan mind-meld practices as therapeutic tools with inherent risks.
ThematicNotes: Explores nostalgia and legacy through a literal journey into the past.
Highlights the interplay between logic, loyalty, and fear in Tuvok’s development.
Suggests that even long-lived Vulcans carry unresolved emotional echoes from their youth.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as Voyager’s 30th-anniversary tribute to the original Star Trek era.
Features guest appearances by George Takei and Grace Lee Whitney.
Blends franchise history with character-focused science fiction.

Title: The Chute
Antagonists: Neural ‘clamp’ device inducing violent paranoia
Authoritarian Zal justice system

StorySections.Text:
Tom Paris and Harry Kim are wrongly convicted of terrorism on an alien world and thrown through a literal
chute into a brutal underground prison with no guards inside. Each inmate wears a neural device that generates
aggression and paranoia, turning the population into a powder keg of violence.

As the effects of the clamp intensify, Paris’s temper flares and Harry fights to keep both of them alive.
Rumors of escape tunnels and resistance movements complicate their attempts to stay focused on survival.
Above, Janeway and Tuvok investigate the charges, navigating an uncooperative justice system that prefers
expedience over truth.

Janeway proves the real culprits’ guilt and forces a review of the case just as conditions in the prison verge
on collapse. Voyager stages a rescue, and the clamps are removed, but Harry is left haunted by the brutality
he witnessed and the lengths he nearly went to under the device’s influence. The experience hardens his
perspective on justice and the fragility of civilization.

EthicalIssues: Punitive systems that induce violent behavior and then use it to justify harsh confinement.
The line between personal responsibility and externally enforced aggression.
Intervening in another society’s legal process when it flagrantly disregards due process.
ContinuityNotes: Deepens the friendship and mutual loyalty between Paris and Kim.
Illustrates Janeway’s willingness to challenge abusive alien institutions.
Adds a darker, more grounded prison story to Voyager’s catalog of Delta Quadrant injustices.
ThematicNotes: Examines how imposed violence can transform otherwise decent people.
Highlights the importance of trust and solidarity in dehumanizing conditions.
Questions the legitimacy of punishment systems that manufacture the behavior they claim to contain.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its gritty, claustrophobic prison setting.
Gives Garrett Wang and Robert Duncan McNeill substantial dramatic material.
Stands out as one of the more intense character trials for Harry Kim.

Title: The Swarm
GuestCharacters: Diagnostic program based on Dr. Zimmerman
Antagonists: Aggressive territorial ‘swarm’ vessels
Corruption in the Doctor’s program

StorySections.Text:
Voyager faces a difficult choice when its most direct route forward crosses the territory of a xenophobic
species whose ships attack any intruders. At the same time, the Doctor begins to suffer glitches—lost words,
repeating phrases, and forgotten procedures—that suggest his program is degrading after years of continuous
operation.

As Janeway reluctantly leads the ship into swarm space, Torres activates a diagnostic hologram based on the
original EMH creator, Dr. Zimmerman, to help repair the Doctor’s matrix. The Zimmerman program advises a full
reset that would erase all of the Doctor’s accumulated experience and personality growth, prompting fierce
debate about whether preserving the person he has become is worth risking his functionality.

While Voyager weaves through a deadly maze of attacking vessels, Torres attempts a more delicate solution that
reorganizes the Doctor’s memory rather than wiping it. The ship narrowly escapes the swarm’s gauntlet, and the
Doctor recovers enough to function, though hints remain that some of what he has become may be fragile.
Janeway and the crew tacitly affirm that they value him as more than just software.

EthicalIssues: Treating an artificial intelligence as expendable software versus a person with a life history.
Risking long-term stability to preserve emergent individuality.
Entering another species’ space when warned away, even for survival reasons.
ContinuityNotes: Continues the Doctor’s long-running arc toward full personhood.
Introduces a holographic likeness of Dr. Zimmerman, foreshadowing later stories.
Adds another hostile territorial power to the map of the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: Explores memory and identity in the context of artificial life.
Highlights the crew’s shifting view of the Doctor from tool to colleague.
Juxtaposes a tactical gauntlet with an intimate battle to save a friend’s mind.
BehindTheScenes: Combines ship-in-danger action with character-focused science fiction.
Showcases Robert Picardo in dual roles as the Doctor and the Zimmerman diagnostic program.
Further cements the Doctor as one of Voyager’s central emotional anchors.

Title: False Profits
GuestCharacters: Bronzed-robe locals of the pre-warp world
Antagonists: Ferengi posing as gods to exploit a Bronze Age culture
Prime Directive violations by non-Federation actors

StorySections.Text:
Voyager detects the signature of a Federation-made wormhole and discovers that it is the same Barzan wormhole
once encountered by the Enterprise. At its far end, they find a pre-warp world whose economy and religion have
been twisted by the presence of two very familiar Ferengi.

Arridor and Kol, the Ferengi stranded by the unstable wormhole years earlier, have used the local myths to set
themselves up as ‘Sages of the Divine Treasury,’ siphoning off vast wealth from the population. Neelix and
Paris go undercover in gaudy Ferengi-style robes to infiltrate the operation and expose the impostors, while
Janeway struggles to uphold the Prime Directive in a situation already hopelessly compromised.

Voyager attempts to send the Ferengi back through the wormhole and undo some of the cultural damage, but the
plan goes awry, scattering the wormhole’s exit once again. Arridor and Kol are pulled away, and the locals are
left to rebuild their society without ‘divine’ interference. Voyager moves on, having brushed a tantalizing
but unreliable possible path home.

EthicalIssues: Responsibility for cleaning up when others have violated the Prime Directive.
Weighing the chance of a shortcut home against the cost to a developing civilization.
Exploiting faith and myth for personal gain.
ContinuityNotes: Directly follows up on the Ferengi stranded in TNG’s ‘The Price’.
Shows that Alpha Quadrant actors can have lingering consequences far from home.
Further refines Voyager’s stance on interfering with pre-warp cultures in unusual circumstances.
ThematicNotes: Uses comedy to explore serious questions about cultural contamination.
Highlights Neelix’s adaptability and flair for performance.
Reinforces that easy routes back to the Alpha Quadrant are rarely stable or ethical.
BehindTheScenes: Brings Ferengi-style economics and satire into the Delta Quadrant.
Provides a rare inter-series continuity link with a minor TNG plot thread.
Balances broad humor with classic Prime Directive dilemmas.

Title: Remember
Antagonists: Enaran leadership suppressing a genocide
Collective denial enforced by cultural conditioning

StorySections.Text:
Voyager ferries a delegation of Enarans, a telepathically gifted people, to their homeworld. Soon B'Elanna
begins experiencing vivid dreams of a young woman in an earlier Enaran society, falling in love and clashing
with family over an impending ‘relocation’ of a disfavored group.

As the dreams grow more detailed and emotionally intense, B'Elanna realizes she is reliving the memories of
Jora Mirell, an Enaran who slowly uncovered that the ‘relocation’ was in fact a genocidal purge of the
Regressives. The current Enarans insist that the Regressives died out due to their own backwardness, and they
deny any knowledge of the atrocities B'Elanna describes.

B'Elanna identifies an elderly Enaran passenger as the real Mirell, who transferred her memories to ensure the
truth would survive her death. With Mirell’s help, B'Elanna passes the memories on to a younger Enaran woman,
hoping the horrific truth will eventually surface and force the society to confront its past. Voyager departs,
leaving the seeds of remembrance behind.

EthicalIssues: The duty of later generations to acknowledge historical atrocities.
Using involuntary memory-sharing to expose genocide.
Whether outsiders have the right to disrupt a society’s chosen narrative about its past.
ContinuityNotes: Provides major character material for B'Elanna through an allegorical historical story.
Adds another telepathic species to Voyager’s growing list of Delta Quadrant civilizations.
Serves as a commentary on buried war crimes and cultural denial.
ThematicNotes: Explores guilt and remembrance through the lens of shared memory.
Shows how personal love stories can be entwined with structural violence.
Suggests that truth can be suppressed but not erased forever.
BehindTheScenes: Often praised for its allegorical approach to historical genocide.
Gives Roxann Dawson an emotionally rich performance showcase.
Uses dreamlike visuals to differentiate past and present.

Title: Sacred Ground
Antagonists: Cultural insistence on spiritual trial over medical intervention
Dangerous energy field in the shrine

StorySections.Text:
During a visit to the Nechani homeworld, Kes is accidentally injured by an energy field in a restricted
shrine. The locals insist that the field is part of a sacred trial and that only spiritual means—not
technology—can help her, leaving Kes comatose and near death in Voyager’s sickbay.

Janeway petitions the Nechani spiritual leaders for a way to save Kes and is told she must undergo the same
dangerous ritual, confronting fear, humility, and uncertainty. As she follows a seemingly irrational series of
tests, she wrestles with her scientific worldview and frustration at instructions that appear symbolic rather
than practical. Meanwhile, Voyager’s medical efforts yield no cure, increasing the pressure on Janeway’s
quest.

In the final trial, Janeway is told that nothing she does will matter and that she must simply accept not
understanding. When she finally surrenders her need for control and performs the ritual without expectation,
Kes recovers—though no clear causal link is ever identified. Janeway returns to the ship unsure whether faith,
chance, or misunderstood science saved her friend, and uneasy with an answer she cannot quantify.

EthicalIssues: Respecting religious practices when they conflict with urgent medical needs.
The limits of scientific certainty in the face of the unknown.
Whether accepting mystery can itself be a form of wisdom.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops Janeway’s complex relationship with belief and skepticism.
Adds depth to Kes’s importance to the crew, particularly to Janeway.
Highlights another Delta Quadrant culture with deeply rooted spiritual traditions.
ThematicNotes: Explores the tension between rationalism and faith without providing a tidy resolution.
Examines humility as a necessary trait even for highly advanced explorers.
Suggests that not all phenomena can be neatly categorized as either ‘magic’ or ‘science’.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its introspective, philosophical tone.
Gives Kate Mulgrew a contemplative, internal performance focus.
Leaves viewers deliberately uncertain about what ‘really’ happened.

Title: Future's End, Part I
Antagonists: Henry Starling exploiting stolen 29th-century tech
Temporal paradox threatening Earth and Voyager

StorySections.Text:
A 29th-century timeship commanded by Captain Braxton appears and attacks Voyager, claiming that the ship will
one day cause a catastrophic temporal explosion on Earth. The confrontation hurls both vessels back to 20th-
century Earth, leaving Voyager stranded in orbit over 1990s Los Angeles.

On the ground, Janeway and Chakotay investigate a mysterious technology magnate, Henry Starling, whose company
pioneered the computer revolution using technology salvaged from Braxton’s crashed timeship. Paris and Tuvok
navigate Southern California culture—complete with surfers, traffic, and skeptical astronomer Rain
Robinson—while trying to stay ahead of law enforcement and Starling’s security teams.

Starling uncovers Voyager’s presence and steals the Doctor’s mobile emitter from the future, gaining access to
advanced holographic technology. As he prepares to launch a modified timeship that could trigger the very
disaster Braxton feared, Voyager’s crew realizes they must stop him without further damaging the timeline.

EthicalIssues: Interfering with the past to prevent a future catastrophe.
Profiting from stolen technology without regard for its origin or consequences.
The risk of paradox when time travelers act on incomplete information.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Doctor’s portable holo-emitter, a key tool in later seasons.
Connects Voyager to 20th-century Earth history through Starling’s appropriation of future tech.
Sets up a two-part temporal adventure that will reshape Voyager’s capabilities.
ThematicNotes: Uses fish-out-of-water humor to explore culture shock in 1990s Earth.
Examines corporate greed in the context of technological acceleration.
Raises questions about destiny versus agency in time-travel scenarios.
BehindTheScenes: Popular for its present-day Los Angeles setting and location shooting.
Balances action, comedy, and temporal-paradox plotting.
Forms the first half of one of Voyager’s most accessible two-parters.

Title: Future's End, Part II
Antagonists: Starling’s stolen timeship
Temporal shockwave that could destroy Earth

StorySections.Text:
With Starling in control of both Braxton’s timeship and the Doctor’s holo-emitter, the race is on to stop his
launch. Voyager must operate covertly in Earth’s orbit while ground teams coordinate with Rain Robinson to
track Starling’s movements and plans.

Chakotay and Torres crash-land in the Arizona desert after a confrontation with Starling’s forces, relying on
20th-century bystanders for help. Paris and Tuvok work with Rain to hack Starling’s systems, while Janeway
maneuvers Voyager through Earth’s skies without triggering widespread panic. The Doctor, still active with his
new emitter, is forced to play both hostage and saboteur from inside Starling’s operation.

In a climactic chase, Voyager reveals itself in Earth’s atmosphere to disable Starling’s launch at the last
moment, destroying the timeship before it can damage the timeline. Braxton is restored to his proper time
frame—albeit with conflicting memories of the events—and Voyager is slingshotted back to the 24th century. The
Doctor retains his mobile emitter, and Rain remains in her own time, changed by what she has seen.

EthicalIssues: Using advanced force in a less-developed era to prevent a greater catastrophe.
The moral implications of leaving individuals in the past with knowledge of future events.
Responsibility for cleaning up temporal disruptions caused by other actors.
ContinuityNotes: Solidifies the Doctor’s new mobility as a permanent feature.
Expands on the Department of Temporal Investigations–style oversight glimpsed via Braxton.
Demonstrates Voyager’s first significant visit to contemporary Earth despite being stranded in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: Highlights teamwork across time and culture to avert disaster.
Shows that not every connection made in the past can—or should—be brought forward.
Reinforces Star Trek’s recurring cautionary stance on unearned technological power.
BehindTheScenes: Concludes one of Voyager’s most memorable time-travel stories.
Features extensive visual effects of Voyager in Earth’s skies.
Blends character moments with high-stakes temporal spectacle.

Title: Warlord
Antagonists: Tieran’s consciousness hijacking Kes’s body
Ilari power struggles

StorySections.Text:
Voyager rescues survivors from a damaged Ilari ship and brings them aboard. One of them, the feared warlord
