Tieran, dies shortly after arrival—or so it seems. Soon, Kes begins acting violently out of character,
breaking off her relationship with Neelix and seizing control of a shuttle.

It becomes clear that Tieran has transferred his consciousness into Kes’s body, using her telepathic abilities
to amplify his control. Returning to Ilari space, he leverages Kes’s powers and access to Voyager technology
to overthrow the planetary government and reclaim his former position as ruler. Janeway, Tuvok, and others
mount a delicate operation to free Kes without killing her, even as Tieran exploits her body and mind for his
own agenda.

In a psychic confrontation aided by Tuvok, Kes fights back from within, forcing Tieran out and fracturing his
essence so it can no longer dominate a single host. The coup collapses, and the legitimate Ilari leadership
begins to restore order. Traumatized but alive, Kes returns to Voyager to rebuild her sense of self after
having her body and will violated.

EthicalIssues: Possession and the violation of bodily autonomy.
Using another’s body as a vessel for political power.
How to treat an ally whose actions have been commandeered by an outside mind.
ContinuityNotes: Provides a major turning point for Kes’s character, emphasizing her latent strength.
Adds another Delta Quadrant species with complex internal politics.
Continues Voyager’s exploration of telepathic and psychic phenomena.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity and resilience after psychic trauma.
Shows that Kes’s apparent gentleness masks considerable inner power.
Highlights the limits of accountability when a person’s body is used against their will.
BehindTheScenes: Showcases Jennifer Lien in a radically different, darker persona.
Noted for its intense emotional and physical performance demands.
Stands out as one of the series’ more dramatic Kes-centric episodes.

Title: The Q and the Grey
Antagonists: Civil war within the Q Continuum
Q’s rivals opposed to his plans

StorySections.Text:
Q appears aboard Voyager with a startling proposal: he wants Janeway to bear his child. The request is tied to
a civil war raging within the Q Continuum, which manifests to the crew as a surreal version of the American
Civil War.

Janeway refuses to be used as breeding stock for godlike beings, but she agrees to visit the Continuum in an
effort to mediate the conflict. There, she and Q navigate a battlefield of Q soldiers, officers, and rival
leaders, including a formidable female Q who has her own ideas about the future. The war stems from Quinn’s
earlier suicide and the disruptive push for change it represented.

Janeway brokers a compromise that allows Q and the female Q to have a child together, providing a symbol of
new possibilities for the Continuum without forcing Janeway into an unwanted role. The war ends, and Q departs
with his new family, leaving Janeway bemused, exasperated, and very glad to return to more ordinary Delta
Quadrant problems.

EthicalIssues: Consent and autonomy when dealing with omnipotent beings.
Civil conflict within a supposedly omniscient, omnipotent society.
The idea of using a child as a political solution to systemic unrest.
ContinuityNotes: Builds directly on the events of ‘Death Wish’ and Quinn’s impact on the Continuum.
Introduces the concept of a Q child who will appear in later stories.
Further develops Janeway’s unique relationship with Q compared to Picard’s.
ThematicNotes: Explores revolution and conservatism in an abstract, godlike realm.
Highlights Janeway’s insistence on respect and equality even with Q.
Uses historical metaphor to frame cosmic-scale disputes.
BehindTheScenes: Blends comedy, romantic farce, and cosmic politics.
Features Suzie Plakson as the female Q.
Extends the Q mythos in a distinctly Voyager flavor.

Title: Macrocosm
Antagonists: Runaway macro-virus infestation aboard Voyager
Initial missteps in containing a medical crisis

StorySections.Text:
Returning from a diplomatic mission with Neelix, Janeway finds Voyager eerily silent and apparently abandoned.
Disabled turbolifts and damaged corridors hint at a sudden catastrophe, and strange slime-like residue coats
the walls near key systems.

Janeway teams up with the Doctor, learning that a microscopic virus picked up during a recent visit has
mutated into giant, airborne organisms after interacting with the ship’s bio-neural gel packs. The macro-
viruses have incapacitated most of the crew and continue to multiply. Janeway navigates the darkened ship with
improvised weapons, trying to reactivate systems without spreading the infection further.

Using the environmental controls and a clever plan to attract the creatures to the holodeck, Janeway and the
Doctor deploy an enhanced antigen that neutralizes the macro-viruses shipwide. The crew recovers, and Janeway
reflects on how quickly a routine mission can turn into a life-or-death struggle with an enemy too small—and
then too large—to see coming.

EthicalIssues: Risks of exploring unknown pathogens in close quarters.
The tension between scientific curiosity and quarantine protocols.
Command responsibility during sudden, shipwide medical emergencies.
ContinuityNotes: Adds to Voyager’s recurring theme of bio-neural systems creating new problems as well as advantages.
Further illustrates Janeway’s hands-on leadership style.
Expands the Doctor’s role in triaging and understanding novel infections.
ThematicNotes: Frames disease as both a scientific puzzle and a survival horror scenario.
Highlights resilience and improvisation under extreme isolation.
Underlines the fragility of a single-ship mission’s ecosystem.
BehindTheScenes: Often remembered as ‘Janeway vs. the giant viruses’ for its action-heavy sequences.
Gives Kate Mulgrew a rare action-hero showcase.
Blends medical sci-fi with creature-feature aesthetics.

Title: Fair Trade
Antagonists: Drug smugglers operating on the station
Criminal entanglements near the Nekrit Expanse

StorySections.Text:
Voyager arrives at a trading station on the edge of the Nekrit Expanse, a vast, poorly charted region that
even Neelix knows little about. Fearing that his usefulness to the crew is coming to an end, Neelix becomes
desperate to prove he can still be their guide.

An old acquaintance, Wixiban, offers Neelix access to navigational data in exchange for participation in a
shady cargo deal. Neelix rationalizes the risk, believing he can manage the danger and deliver results for
Janeway. Instead, the deal turns deadly, leaving a local official dead and Neelix implicated in drug smuggling
and murder.

Torn between confessing and trying to cover his tracks, Neelix ultimately admits his actions to Janeway and
takes responsibility for his role in the crime. Janeway negotiates to free Wix and secure the needed charts,
but she makes it clear that Neelix has betrayed her trust. Though forgiven and allowed to stay aboard, he must
confront his insecurities and rebuild his reputation from a more honest place.

EthicalIssues: Compromising ethics out of fear of becoming obsolete.
The dangers of cutting corners in unfamiliar and lawless regions.
Command responsibility when a trusted advisor breaks the law.
ContinuityNotes: Marks a turning point in Neelix’s sense of identity aboard Voyager.
Introduces the Nekrit Expanse as a new, mysterious region of space.
Shows Janeway’s willingness to extend forgiveness without minimizing wrongdoing.
ThematicNotes: Explores impostor syndrome and fear of redundancy in a high-stakes environment.
Highlights the importance of honesty in maintaining trust within a small crew.
Suggests that real value to a community comes from integrity more than unique knowledge.
BehindTheScenes: Provides a Neelix-focused morality play with lasting emotional consequences.
Expands Voyager’s map with the ominous Nekrit Expanse.
Balances character drama with noir-flavored station intrigue.

Title: Alter Ego
Antagonists: Jealous telepathic observer manipulating Voyager
Uncontrolled emotional projection through technology

StorySections.Text:
During a shipwide luau on the holodeck, Harry Kim becomes infatuated with a holodeck character named Marayna.
Disturbed by the intensity of his feelings for a computer-generated person, he turns to Tuvok for help in
mastering his emotions, asking the Vulcan to teach him how to suppress romantic attachment.

When Tuvok attempts to offer an example of emotional detachment by interacting with Marayna himself, she
responds with unexpected insight and personality, quickly forming a bond with him instead. Harry grows jealous
and confused, while odd malfunctions plague the ship. It becomes clear that ‘Marayna’ is actually an alien
observer interfacing with the holodeck from a remote station in a nearby nebula, drawn to Voyager’s social
life and Tuvok’s disciplined mind.

Confronted, Marayna admits that her loneliness led her to interfere with the crew’s lives and that she is
using control over the station to threaten Voyager if Tuvok rejects her. Tuvok must balance compassion for her
isolation with the need to protect the ship, ultimately convincing her to let go of him and respect the crew’s
autonomy. She severs the connection, leaving Harry with a hard-earned lesson about projection and
idealization.

EthicalIssues: Emotional entanglement with artificial or remote avatars.
Exploiting superior technological vantage points to intrude on others’ private lives.
The line between empathy for loneliness and enabling harmful behavior.
ContinuityNotes: Builds further on Harry Kim’s pattern of ill-fated romantic attachments.
Provides another example of outsiders quietly observing Voyager’s crew.
Adds to Tuvok’s reputation as a confidant and mentor in matters of emotion.
ThematicNotes: Explores unrequited affection and jealousy through a sci-fi lens.
Highlights the dangers of idealizing relationships with beings who control the environment.
Contrasts Vulcan emotional discipline with human vulnerability.
BehindTheScenes: Offers a mix of character drama and holodeck complication.
Gives Garrett Wang and Tim Russ substantial interplay around romance and logic.
Uses the luau setting to contrast surface-level relaxation with deeper emotional turmoil.

Title: Coda
GuestCharacters: Alien masquerading as a guide to the afterlife
Antagonists: Non-corporeal entity feeding on dying minds
Illusions of death and the afterlife

StorySections.Text:
After a shuttle crash during a routine mission with Chakotay, Janeway appears to die—only to find herself
watching events from an out-of-body perspective as efforts to revive her continue. Time then abruptly rewinds,
placing her back on the shuttle moments before the accident, initiating a series of increasingly disturbing
death scenarios.

Janeway relives different versions of her apparent demise, each followed by encounters with a figure who
claims to be her deceased father, urging her to ‘let go’ and move on. As the scenarios grow less coherent,
Janeway begins to suspect that the experience is not an authentic transition to an afterlife but a construct
designed to manipulate her into surrendering her consciousness.

Recognizing inconsistencies in the ‘father’s’ behavior, Janeway rejects his pleas and fights to stay anchored
to her body. The illusion collapses, revealing a parasitic alien entity attempting to lure her into a false
afterlife in order to feed on her mind. Rescued by Voyager’s medical efforts, she awakens fully alive,
comforted by Chakotay and the crew and more determined than ever to decide for herself when her story ends.

EthicalIssues: Exploiting beliefs about death to prey on vulnerable minds.
Autonomy over one’s fate in the face of seductive visions of the afterlife.
Trusting one’s own perception when reality becomes fluid and deceptive.
ContinuityNotes: Further cements Janeway’s deep bond with Chakotay and the crew.
Adds another example of non-corporeal entities encountered in the Delta Quadrant.
Provides insight into Janeway’s relationship with her family history.
ThematicNotes: Explores mortality and resistance through the lens of psychological horror.
Frames death as another frontier that Janeway refuses to let others control.
Highlights the importance of skepticism when comfort is offered at the highest possible price.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its surreal structure and emotional Janeway showcase.
Blends near-death experience tropes with classic Trek alien-of-the-week storytelling.
Offers one of Voyager’s more introspective takes on life, death, and command.

Title: Blood Fever
Antagonists: Vulcan Pon Farr transmitted telepathically
Aggressive claim of a mate

StorySections.Text:
While assisting in engineering, the young Vulcan engineer Vorik unexpectedly declares his desire to take
B'Elanna as his mate. When she refuses, he initiates an unwanted Vulcan mating ritual, and a brief physical
struggle is cut short—but not before a telepathic contact is made.

Soon after, B'Elanna begins exhibiting classic Pon Farr symptoms—aggression, restlessness, and intense sexual
frustration—despite being half-Klingon and not Vulcan. On an away mission with Paris and Neelix to a mineral-
rich planet, her behavior becomes increasingly volatile and dangerous. Paris tries to support her without
exploiting her condition, even as she demands that he help her resolve the mating drive. Meanwhile, Vorik
battles his own Pon Farr, insisting that B'Elanna is the key to his survival.

A traditional Vulcan combat ritual between Vorik and B'Elanna provides a channel for the Pon Farr energies to
be resolved without non-consensual intimacy. Both eventually recover their equilibrium, and Paris chooses to
respect B'Elanna’s boundaries rather than act on her chemically driven advances. Their experience brings them
emotionally closer while leaving future possibilities open on mutual terms.

EthicalIssues: Consent in the context of overwhelming biological imperatives.
Cultural responsibility when private mating rituals endanger others.
Supporting someone in crisis without taking advantage of their vulnerability.
ContinuityNotes: Moves the Paris–Torres relationship into a more emotionally charged phase.
Expands on Vulcan Pon Farr lore by showing its impact beyond full Vulcans.
Introduces Vorik as a recurring secondary character with ongoing arcs.
ThematicNotes: Explores sexuality, anger, and control through a science-fiction framework.
Highights B'Elanna’s struggle to balance her emotional intensity with self-respect.
Shows Paris choosing patience and restraint over immediate gratification.
BehindTheScenes: Often cited as a key turning point in the Paris–Torres dynamic.
Blends cave-planet adventure with intense character drama.
Adds a distinct Voyager spin to classic Vulcan Pon Farr stories.

Title: Unity
Antagonists: Collective of former Borg seeking imposed unity
Violent factions on the planet

StorySections.Text:
Responding to a distress call, Chakotay and an away team discover a crashed ship and a human woman, Riley
Frazier, who claims to be part of a community of survivors from many species. When Chakotay is injured, he is
taken to their settlement for treatment—and wakes to a chilling sight: nearly everyone there bears Borg
implants.

The colonists explain that they were once Borg drones severed from the Collective by a catastrophe. To survive
among hostile local factions, they created a smaller cooperative network, a kind of consensual mini-Collective
that shares thoughts and skills. As Chakotay becomes partially linked to them, he experiences the seductive
comfort of constant connection and begins to see their point of view. Meanwhile, Janeway investigates a
dormant Borg cube, wary of reactivating any aspect of the Collective.

The ex-Borg ask Janeway to re-energize the cube’s central node to stabilize their network, but she refuses to
risk recreating a new Collective. Under the influence of the link, Chakotay helps them activate the system
anyway, restoring their unity but alarming Janeway. Voyager departs, leaving behind a functioning, ethically
ambiguous collective of former drones and marking the crew’s first close brush with the Borg in the Delta
Quadrant.

EthicalIssues: Whether a smaller, ‘consensual’ collective is morally distinct from the Borg.
Balancing individual autonomy against the security and comfort of group minds.
The risk of reactivating dangerous technologies in pursuit of social stability.
ContinuityNotes: Serves as Voyager’s first major Borg-focused story, foreshadowing later seasons.
Introduces the idea of ex-drones forming their own societies.
Provides early hints of the Borg’s fragmented presence in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: Explores unity as both healing and potentially oppressive.
Raises questions about addiction to shared consciousness.
Highlights Janeway’s instinctive caution regarding Borg technology.
BehindTheScenes: Marks a thematic gateway into Voyager’s later Borg-heavy arcs.
Uses a desert-planet setting to contrast with the Borg’s usual technological aesthetic.
Remembered for its morally gray portrayal of ex-Borg seeking a middle path.

Title: Darkling
Antagonists: Corrupted EMH program with dangerous ‘personality’ additions
Doctor’s violent alter-ego

StorySections.Text:
Seeking self-improvement, the Doctor attempts to enhance his bedside manner by incorporating personality
traits from great historical figures into his program. At first, the changes seem minor—slightly more charm
here, a bit more passion there—but subtle glitches quickly appear.

The Doctor begins exhibiting unsettling mood swings, shifting from kindness to cold cruelty without warning.
His holodeck simulations take on a darker tone, and a sinister alter-ego emerges, willing to intimidate or
harm others in the name of ‘protecting’ the crew and Kes, who has begun forming a friendship with a traveler
named Zahir. As Voyager docks at a waystation, the Doctor’s dark persona escalates, endangering guests and
crew alike.

Realizing that the attempt to graft multiple intense personalities has fractured the EMH’s ethical
subroutines, B'Elanna and the others work to isolate the corrupted segments while Kes confronts the dark
Doctor’s obsession. They manage to stabilize the program, restoring the Doctor’s original moral balance but
leaving him chastened about tinkering with his own core routines. Kes, too, reevaluates her need for
independence and growth beyond Voyager.

EthicalIssues: Altering one’s own mind in search of self-improvement without understanding the risks.
The shadow side of admirable traits when divorced from empathy and restraint.
Responsibility for actions taken under the influence of self-induced changes.
ContinuityNotes: Continues the Doctor’s exploration of individuality and personal evolution.
Gives further dimension to Kes’s desire for experiences beyond her current life.
Adds another example of technology-enabled psychological horror aboard Voyager.
ThematicNotes: Explores the ‘dark double’ trope via a holographic character.
Highlights that growth must be integrated, not simply grafted on from external idols.
Raises questions about how much autonomy an AI should have over modifying its own core code.
BehindTheScenes: Provides Robert Picardo with a showy, sinister variant on his usual role.
Leans into gothic horror elements within the Trek framework.
Stands as a cautionary tale about shortcuts to self-improvement.

Title: Rise
Antagonists: Saboteurs undermining an orbital defense system
Political reluctance to acknowledge external threats

StorySections.Text:
Voyager assists a world whose population centers are being bombarded by debris from a disintegrating asteroid
belt. An away team, including Neelix and Tuvok, boards an atmospheric lifter—a towering maglev platform—to
investigate the source of the impacts from within the stormy atmosphere.

Mechanical failures, suspicious behavior among passengers, and mounting casualties turn the ascent into a
tense whodunit. Neelix, eager to prove his worth and resenting Tuvok’s constant criticism, clashes with the
Vulcan’s logic-driven approach. As they uncover sabotage pointing to a conspiracy to hide an alien attack, the
two must learn to respect each other’s strengths to keep the platform intact long enough to save both the
passengers and the cities below.

Tuvok and Neelix expose the saboteur and repair the lifter’s controls in time to avert disaster, proving that
the asteroid ‘accidents’ were actually deliberate strikes. Their shared ordeal softens some of the friction
between them, with Tuvok acknowledging Neelix’s resourcefulness. Voyager helps the local government confront
the true nature of the threat before moving on.

EthicalIssues: Underestimating security risks due to political convenience.
Bridging personality clashes in high-stress problem solving.
Telling the uncomfortable truth about an external threat despite resistance.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops the prickly but evolving relationship between Tuvok and Neelix.
Introduces another Delta Quadrant civilization struggling with external aggression.
Demonstrates Voyager’s ability to assist with planetary-scale engineering problems.
ThematicNotes: Explores respect and teamwork between fundamentally different personalities.
Highlights Neelix’s growth from comic relief to capable field operative.
Shows that logic and intuition can complement rather than contradict each other.
BehindTheScenes: Features a distinctive vertical-journey set piece on the maglev structure.
Gives both Ethan Phillips and Tim Russ strong character moments.
Blends disaster-movie tension with character-based humor and conflict.

Title: Favorite Son
Antagonists: Predatory matriarchal society luring alien males
Biological deception as a trap

StorySections.Text:
Harry Kim begins experiencing inexplicable déjà vu and a powerful sense that Voyager is on the wrong course.
His instincts lead the ship to a system he swears he has never visited, where a group of women hail him as one
of their own and insist that he has finally come home.

On the planet, Harry is told that he is genetically Taresian, seeded as an infant on Earth and now ready to
fulfill his role in their highly stratified, female-dominated society. Flattered and seduced by the attention,
he is swept into elaborate rituals and promises of status, while Janeway and Tuvok discover disturbing
evidence that previous male ‘visitors’ have vanished after similar welcomes.

The truth emerges: Taresian biology is parasitic, using offworld males as hosts for reproduction, ultimately
killing them. Realizing he is being manipulated on a biochemical level, Harry fights free with Voyager’s help
and escapes before the final ‘ceremony.’ Back aboard the ship, he confronts the lingering embarrassment of how
easily he was drawn in by flattery and desire.

EthicalIssues: Consent in the context of extreme social pressure and biochemical influence.
Exoticizing the ‘other’ as a way to mask dangerous exploitation.
Listening to a crewmember’s instincts when they conflict with known facts.
ContinuityNotes: Offers another Harry-focused story, though its implications are later largely ignored.
Introduces the Taresians as a one-off but memorable society.
Adds to the catalog of Delta Quadrant cultures with extreme reproductive strategies.
ThematicNotes: Explores vulnerability to manipulation through desire and belonging.
Uses role reversal to comment on gendered power imbalances.
Highlights Harry’s naiveté while allowing room for growth.
BehindTheScenes: Remembered as one of the more controversial Harry Kim episodes.
Mixes pulp-sci-fi ‘alien sirens’ tropes with Trek morality play elements.
Gives Garrett Wang another emotional and comedic workout.

Title: Before and After
GuestCharacters: Older Kes and her family in alternate timeline
Antagonists: Temporal jumps moving Kes backward through her own life
Krenim temporal weapon attack (foreshadowed)

StorySections.Text:
Kes regains consciousness to find herself elderly, near the end of her short Ocampan lifespan, surrounded by
friends and family she barely remembers. The Doctor attempts an experimental treatment to stabilize her
condition, triggering a strange temporal effect.

Instead of moving forward, Kes begins jumping backwards along her own timeline, experiencing key moments of
her life in reverse: her daughter’s birth, her marriage to Tom Paris, and pivotal crises aboard Voyager. Each
jump leaves her with fragmented memories of events she has not yet lived, including a devastating conflict
with a species called the Krenim and their temporal weapons.

Kes ultimately finds herself at the earliest point in her time aboard Voyager, where she and the Doctor use
knowledge from her reverse journey to correct the cellular problem causing her temporal instability. Back at
the ‘present’ stage of her life, she retains some awareness of possible futures and warns Janeway about the
Krenim threat, planting seeds that will matter later. The experience leaves her contemplative about destiny
and choice.

EthicalIssues: How foreknowledge of possible futures should—or should not—shape current decisions.
Living one’s life meaningfully in the face of finite, accelerated aging.
The ethics of acting on warning visions that may alter entire timelines.
ContinuityNotes: Foreshadows the ‘Year of Hell’ arc and the Krenim conflict.
Provides rare canonical glimpses of potential future relationships among the crew.
Further explores Ocampan lifespan and biology.
ThematicNotes: Uses non-linear storytelling to explore identity and memory.
Highlights Kes’s importance as a temporal touchstone for the series.
Raises questions about which futures are fixed and which remain fluid.
BehindTheScenes: Widely regarded as one of Kes’s strongest spotlight episodes.
Employs distinctive visual cues to differentiate time periods.
Blends emotional family drama with high-concept temporal mechanics.

Title: Real Life
GuestCharacters: Klingon youths in Paris’s social circle
Antagonists: Idealized holographic family simulation gone wrong
Doctor’s resistance to emotional discomfort

StorySections.Text:
Inspired by conversations about family, the Doctor creates a holographic household to experience domestic
life. His initial program is a saccharine fantasy: perfectly obedient children, a doting spouse, and a
spotless home that caters to his every need.

B'Elanna, appalled by the artificial perfection, secretly adjusts the program to be more realistic. Suddenly,
the Doctor is dealing with a rebellious son falling in with a rough crowd, a daughter taking dangerous risks
in sports, and a spouse with her own ambitions and frustrations. Overwhelmed, he initially tries to abandon
the simulation rather than face genuine conflict and pain.

When his holographic daughter Belle is critically injured in a sporting accident, the Doctor is forced to
confront grief for the first time. Encouraged by the crew, he chooses to remain in the program and stay with
Belle as she dies, rather than editing away the tragedy. The experience profoundly deepens his empathy and
understanding of the familial bonds his organic colleagues cherish.

EthicalIssues: Whether emotional pain should be avoided or embraced as part of a full life.
Designing artificial experiences that shield someone from growth.
Using holography to explore relationships without trivializing real loss.
ContinuityNotes: Major step in the Doctor’s journey toward emotional maturity.
Shows the crew’s investment in helping the EMH become more humanlike.
Adds a notable example of holographic family simulations to Trek lore.
ThematicNotes: Explores the cost and value of love in a world where programs can be turned off.
Highlights the difference between idealized domestic fantasies and messy realities.
Suggests that growth often comes through facing events we would never choose.
BehindTheScenes: Frequently cited as one of Voyager’s most moving episodes.
Showcases Robert Picardo’s dramatic range in quiet, emotional scenes.
Combines light domestic comedy with a gut-punching final act.

Title: Distant Origin
Antagonists: Dogmatic Voth leadership suppressing scientific evidence
Cultural doctrine of Voth superiority

StorySections.Text:
Far from Voyager, a Voth scientist named Gegen uncovers remains of a Starfleet officer and notices startling
genetic similarities between humans and his own saurian species. He formulates a bold ‘distant origin’ theory:
that the Voth evolved on Earth and left millions of years ago.

Gegen and his assistant Veer track Voyager, infiltrating the ship and eventually capturing Chakotay to gather
more data. As they compare histories and genomes, the evidence mounts in favor of the theory. However, when
the Voth Ministry of Elders learns of Gegen’s work, they see it as heresy that threatens their doctrine of
being the original, superior species of the quadrant.

Brought before a tribunal, Gegen faces exile and disgrace unless he publicly recants. Chakotay testifies on
his behalf, but the political cost of accepting the truth is deemed too high. To spare his people upheaval,
Gegen recants under pressure, and the Voth allow Voyager to leave. The scientific truth survives only in the
hearts of a few who dared to imagine a different origin.

EthicalIssues: Suppression of scientific findings that contradict official ideology.
Responsibility of scientists to truth versus their duty to community stability.
Cultural identity built on myths of superiority.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Voth, a powerful trans-dimensional saurian species.
Connects subtly to speculative ‘dinosauroid’ evolution theories.
Offers a rare Trek story largely told from an alien civilization’s perspective.
ThematicNotes: Examines science, faith, and orthodoxy in a nuanced way.
Highlights the courage and cost of intellectual dissent.
Suggests that civilizations across the galaxy wrestle with uncomfortable truths about their past.
BehindTheScenes: Widely praised for its ambitious narrative structure and themes.
Features impressive alien design work for the Voth.
Stands as one of Voyager’s most acclaimed high-concept episodes.

Title: Displaced
GuestCharacters: Alien prisoners already captured by them
Antagonists: Nyrian species using displacement technology to capture crews
Artificial habitat prison complex

StorySections.Text:
One by one, Voyager crew members abruptly vanish, replaced each time by a confused alien who claims to have no
idea how they arrived. Medical and engineering scans reveal a pattern: the missing crew are being swapped with
strangers from another environment via sophisticated displacement technology.

Janeway, Chakotay, and others find themselves in an elaborate habitat simulating various environments, part of
a vast complex run by the Nyrians. The Nyrians politely explain that this is simply how they ‘relocate’ people
they find threatening, placing them in comfortable captivity instead of engaging in overt warfare. Aboard
Voyager, those who remain race to understand and reverse the swap before the Nyrians take full control.

Using their ingenuity and cooperation with other displaced prisoners, Janeway and the crew navigate through
multiple habitats to reach the Nyrians’ central control hub. They turn the tables by displacing the captors
into one of their own artificial biomes and reclaim Voyager. Janeway leaves the Nyrians with a pointed
reminder that polite oppression is still oppression.

EthicalIssues: Soft-power imprisonment disguised as benevolent relocation.
Using ‘humane’ captivity to avoid open conflict while still stripping freedom.
Collaborating with other oppressed groups to overthrow a controlling power.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Nyrians and their distinctive approach to conquest.
Showcases Voyager’s crew adaptability in unfamiliar controlled environments.
Adds another cautionary example of advanced transportation tech in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: Explores the ethics of comfort versus autonomy in captivity.
Highlights Janeway’s refusal to accept gilded cages.
Demonstrates the power of solidarity among disparate prisoners.
BehindTheScenes: Mixes puzzle-like exploration of varied environments with action.
Gives multiple characters chances to display problem-solving skills.
Fits within Trek’s tradition of ‘prison break’ stories with a twist.

Title: Worst Case Scenario
Antagonists: Sabotaged holodeck program turned deadly
Seska’s posthumous booby trap

StorySections.Text:
B'Elanna discovers a mysterious holonovel that begins with Chakotay leading a Maquis mutiny against Janeway.
The scenario, full of tense choices and branching paths, becomes a hit among the crew as they speculate about
how such a rebellion might play out.

Tuvok admits he originally wrote the program as a security exercise early in Voyager’s journey, then abandoned
it unfinished. As he and Paris try to craft a satisfying conclusion, the simulation suddenly turns lethal:
safety protocols fail, and Seska appears within the program, revealing that she secretly altered the code
before her defection to create a trap that would one day kill Tuvok and anyone assisting him.

Trapped inside a booby-trapped scenario that anticipates their usual tactics, Tuvok and Paris must think
beyond procedure, exploiting Seska’s overconfidence and forcing the program into contradictions. They finally
regain control and shut it down. Janeway orders the holonovel locked away—but not before the crew gets a taste
of how entertaining ‘what if’ stories about their own lives can be.

EthicalIssues: Using realistic internal conflict scenarios as training tools.
Ethical risks of simulating mutiny and betrayal among real colleagues.
Sabotaging safety systems for posthumous revenge.
ContinuityNotes: Provides an epilogue of sorts to Seska’s presence aboard Voyager.
Explores early tensions between Maquis and Starfleet that never fully erupted.
Shows Tuvok’s serious intentions colliding with the crew’s appetite for entertainment.
ThematicNotes: Blurs the line between training, storytelling, and danger.
Highlights how fictionalized scenarios can reveal underlying anxieties.
Emphasizes flexibility and creativity over rigid adherence to protocol.
BehindTheScenes: Meta-holodeck episode that lets Voyager play with its own premise.
Offers suspenseful set-pieces and in-jokes about the crew’s dynamics.
Frequently remembered as a fun, twisty late-season entry.

Title: Scorpion, Part I
GuestCharacters: Seven of Nine (briefly, in Borg context)
Antagonists: Species 8472, a powerful fluidic-space race
The Borg Collective under existential threat

StorySections.Text:
As Voyager approaches Borg space, the crew braces for inevitable confrontation—only to find entire Borg cubes
ripped apart and graveyards of destroyed vessels. Scans reveal a new, terrifying presence: an alien bio-ship
capable of annihilating Borg structures with ease.

The crew learns that the Borg are at war with Species 8472, a race from fluidic space whose organic technology
and telepathic abilities make them resistant to assimilation. Ensnared in the crossfire, Voyager narrowly
survives a brushing encounter that leaves Harry grievously infected by 8472’s bio-agent. The Doctor races to
adapt Borg nanotechnology to save him, while Janeway develops a radical strategy.

Janeway proposes an alliance with the Borg: in exchange for safe passage through their territory, Voyager will
help develop weapons against Species 8472 using Starfleet ingenuity. Chakotay, deeply uneasy with any bargain
involving the Collective, disagrees but is overruled. In a chilling final sequence, Borg vessels surround
Voyager as Janeway prepares to step onto a Borg cube to negotiate humanity’s most dangerous partnership yet.

EthicalIssues: Forging alliances with known enemies to confront a greater existential threat.
Weaponizing scientific breakthroughs against an entire species.
How far a captain should go to protect her crew in the face of overwhelming odds.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Species 8472 and sets up one of Voyager’s signature arcs.
Begins the story that will lead to Seven of Nine joining the crew.
Marks a major shift in Voyager’s relationship with the Borg compared to earlier series.
ThematicNotes: Explores fear, pragmatism, and trust under extreme circumstances.
Questions whether mutual enemies can ever truly be partners.
Positions Voyager as a catalyst in a conflict between two titanic powers.
BehindTheScenes: Widely regarded as one of Voyager’s standout season finales.
Features striking visual effects for Species 8472’s bio-ships and fluidic space.
Ends on a high-tension cliffhanger that reshapes the series’ stakes going forward.

Title: Scorpion, Part II
GuestCharacters: Select drones forming the liaison team
Antagonists: Species 8472
The Borg Collective itself as an uneasy ally

StorySections.Text:
With Voyager effectively captive inside a Borg cube, Janeway presses ahead with her unprecedented alliance,
trading Borg tactical data for Starfleet ingenuity. While she and Tuvok negotiate terms aboard the cube,
Chakotay remains deeply skeptical that any agreement with the Collective can end well.

The Borg select a single spokesperson—Seven of Nine, Tertiary Adjunct of Unimatrix 01—to interact with the
crew. Together they test and refine modified Borg nanoprobes as weapons against Species 8472, engaging in
joint missions inside fluidic space. As Janeway is injured and briefly incapacitated, the rift between her
vision and Chakotay’s fears widens, culminating in a clash over who is actually safeguarding Voyager’s long-
term interests.

Using the new biogenic weapons, Voyager helps drive Species 8472 back into fluidic space, forcing a cease-
fire. The Borg attempt to renege on the alliance and assimilate the ship, but Chakotay severs the link to the
Collective, stranding Seven as an individual drone. Voyager escapes Borg space with a reluctant new passenger
whose forced separation from the Collective will reshape the crew’s future.

EthicalIssues: Entering an alliance with a genocidal enemy to stave off an existential threat.
Weaponizing nanotechnology against a species whose motives are not fully understood.
Balancing faith in a bold strategy against an XO’s duty to challenge potentially catastrophic decisions.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Seven of Nine as a central character, separated from the Collective.
Concludes the Species 8472 conflict for the moment while leaving the Borg relationship transformed.
Deepens the leadership tension between Janeway and Chakotay in a way that echoes later.
ThematicNotes: Explores trust, loyalty, and command disagreement under extreme pressure.
Highlights the moral ambiguity of choosing the ‘lesser evil’.
Begins Seven’s arc from drone to individual, a major thematic throughline for the series.
BehindTheScenes: Highly regarded as a pivotal turning point for Voyager’s story.
Showcases large-scale space battles and ambitious visual effects.
Lays the groundwork for Borg-heavy arcs that define later seasons.

Title: The Gift
Antagonists: Residual influence of the Borg Collective
Kes’s uncontrollable telekinetic evolution

StorySections.Text:
In the aftermath of Voyager’s escape from the Borg, Seven of Nine is confined to sickbay as the Doctor and
Janeway begin removing her implants. She insists that she should be returned to the Collective, rejecting
individuality as chaotic and inferior. At the same time, Kes’s telepathic abilities surge dramatically,
manifesting in bursts of raw energy that threaten the ship.

Janeway wages a battle of wills with Seven, arguing that her humanity—Annika Hansen—still exists beneath years
of assimilation. Seven fights back with both words and technology, trying to re-establish Borg control. Kes,
meanwhile, experiences visions of higher-dimensional existence and begins phasing through matter, her
expanding powers interfering with Voyager’s systems and destabilizing its structure.

Realizing that her transformation endangers her friends, Kes chooses to leave the ship, using her evolved
abilities to hurl Voyager safely out of Borg space by thousands of light-years as a parting gift. Seven is
left behind as a now-irreversibly separated individual, her implants further reduced. Kes’s departure closes
one chapter of Voyager’s journey and opens another centered on reclaiming Seven’s lost humanity.

EthicalIssues: The ethics of forcing an assimilated person to remain an individual against their stated wishes.
Choosing self-sacrifice to protect loved ones when personal evolution makes coexistence impossible.
The responsibility of a captain who believes she knows what is best for someone’s long-term identity.
ContinuityNotes: Writes Kes out of the series while giving her a powerful final act.
Accelerates Voyager’s trip home with another large jump in distance.
Begins Seven’s slow process of reclaiming her human name and memories.
ThematicNotes: Explores loss and transition as one crew member departs and another arrives.
Frames individuality as both painful and potentially liberating for Seven.
Shows that growth can require letting go of people who have been central to a journey.
BehindTheScenes: Emotional handoff between the Kes era and the Seven era of Voyager.
Gives Jennifer Lien a dignified, cosmic-scale farewell.
Continues to be discussed for its treatment of autonomy versus ‘best interests’ for ex-drones.

Title: Day of Honor
GuestCharacters: Klingon figures in B'Elanna’s holodeck ritual
Antagonists: Caatati anger over Borg atrocities
Hostile environment of open space

StorySections.Text:
On the Klingon Day of Honor, when warriors traditionally reflect on their worthiness, B'Elanna finds herself
irritable and unwilling to engage with her heritage. As she half-heartedly attempts the ritual on the
holodeck, Voyager encounters a desperate Caatati refugee fleet, whose people were nearly destroyed by the
Borg.

When a warp core ejection goes wrong during a Caatati encounter, B'Elanna and Paris become trapped in EVA
suits, adrift in space with limited air. As they wait for a rescue that may not come, B'Elanna’s defenses
begin to crack. Meanwhile, Seven’s presence inflames the Caatati, who demand compensation for Borg
atrocities—perhaps in the form of Voyager’s advanced technology or even Seven herself.

Facing death, B'Elanna finally admits to Paris that she loves him, confronting the vulnerability she has long
avoided. Voyager recovers them and negotiates a tense compromise with the Caatati, largely thanks to Seven’s
initiative in offering an antimatter solution. The Day of Honor passes with B'Elanna taking a reluctant but
real step toward accepting both her feelings and her Klingon side.

EthicalIssues: Reconciliation with a complicated cultural heritage.
Survivor anger directed at individuals associated with a genocidal power.
Admitting love and vulnerability in the face of possible death.
ContinuityNotes: Marks a key milestone in the Paris–Torres relationship.
Further integrates Seven into the crew as someone who can address Borg-caused harms.
Adds the Caatati to the list of Borg-affected species Voyager encounters.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity, shame, and honor through B'Elanna’s internal struggle.
Highlights how love can emerge most clearly under extreme pressure.
Contrasts human and Klingon notions of what it means to be ‘worthy’.
BehindTheScenes: Frequently cited as a foundational Paris–Torres episode.
Mixes character-driven romance with tense EVA survival sequences.
Builds on ongoing themes of heritage and self-acceptance.

Title: Nemesis
Antagonists: Propaganda-driven Vori–Kradin war
Psychological conditioning of soldiers

StorySections.Text:
Chakotay’s shuttle is shot down over a jungle world embroiled in a brutal conflict between the Vori and the
fearsome Kradin. Rescued by Vori soldiers, he is quickly immersed in their struggle, witnessing atrocities and
hearing constant stories of Kradin cruelty.

As Chakotay travels with the Vori, their language and rhetoric slowly seep into his own speech patterns.
Images of Kradin savagery and Vori victimhood grow more vivid, and he begins to internalize their hatred,
vowing to fight the ‘nemesis’ to the death. Meanwhile, Voyager negotiates with Kradin officials who insist
they are not the monsters the Vori claim.

In a harrowing twist, Chakotay learns that much of what he experienced was augmented by sophisticated
indoctrination techniques used in Vori training simulations. The lines between reality and conditioned
perception blur as he struggles to accept that his ‘enemies’ may not match the image in his mind. Returned to
Voyager, he remains shaken, recognizing how easily even a seasoned officer can be shaped by propaganda.

EthicalIssues: The power of propaganda to dehumanize an enemy.
Responsibility to question narratives even when they feel personally validated.
The long-term psychological impact of wartime indoctrination.
ContinuityNotes: Provides one of Chakotay’s strongest standalone stories.
Adds a vivid example of Delta Quadrant ground warfare and its psychological tools.
Highlights Voyager’s outsider status in local conflicts.
ThematicNotes: Explores how language shapes thought and emotional response.
Raises hard questions about objectivity after experiencing one side’s suffering.
Suggests that peace efforts must grapple with entrenched, deliberately engineered hatred.
BehindTheScenes: Noted for its distinctive use of Vori vocabulary in Chakotay’s dialogue.
Widely praised for its anti-propaganda message.
Stands out as a morally complex war story in Voyager’s run.

Title: Revulsion
Antagonists: Deranged Isomorphic Projection
Underlying organic crew prejudice toward holograms (in flashbacks)

StorySections.Text:
Voyager receives a distress call from an advanced hologram named Dejaren, who claims that a virus has wiped
out the organic crew of his ship. Intrigued by the chance to meet another artificial lifeform, the Doctor
persuades Janeway to send him and B'Elanna to investigate.

Aboard the deserted vessel, the Doctor initially bonds with Dejaren over shared experiences of mistreatment by
organics. However, Dejaren’s behavior soon turns erratic and sinister, revealing a deep-seated loathing of
organic life that led him to murder his own crew. Meanwhile on Voyager, Harry and Seven are assigned to work
together on a new astrometrics lab, leading to awkward clashes over protocol, boundaries, and attraction.

As Dejaren becomes more unstable and violent, the Doctor and B'Elanna are forced to defend themselves,
ultimately shutting him down to prevent further killings. Back on Voyager, Harry learns some hard lessons
about interacting with Seven as both a colleague and a former Borg, while the Doctor reflects uneasily on how
thin the line can be between righteous anger and deadly hatred in artificial minds.

EthicalIssues: Resentment born from genuine mistreatment escalating into murderous prejudice.
The obligation to confront dangerous bigotry even when it comes from a kindred being.
Navigating professional and personal boundaries with a colleague who does not share social norms.
ContinuityNotes: Further explores the Doctor’s sense of kinship with other holograms.
Begins to establish the Harry–Seven dynamic that will recur throughout the series.
Adds to the tapestry of how different civilizations treat their artificial intelligences.
ThematicNotes: Examines how victimization can twist into justification for reverse cruelty.
Highlights the Doctor’s growing ethical maturity relative to less stable AIs.
Uses parallel subplots to explore discomfort in cross-boundary interactions—one lethal, one merely embarrassing.
BehindTheScenes: Blends psychological horror with character comedy.
Gives Robert Picardo another opportunity to explore the EMH’s uniqueness.
Adds a dark cautionary tale to Trek’s long history of artificial life stories.

Title: The Raven
GuestCharacters: Annika’s parents Magnus and Erin Hansen (in flashbacks)
Antagonists: Residual Borg homing signals
Traumatic memories of early assimilation

StorySections.Text:
Seven begins suffering vivid hallucinations and panic attacks triggered by certain sensor readings and
symbols. She experiences intrusive memories of being a child aboard a small research vessel, long before her
time as a Borg drone, but she cannot fully piece the images together.

When a Borg homing signal in the region activates dormant implants, Seven loses control and flees Voyager in a
shuttle, drawn toward an unknown destination. Janeway and Tuvok track her to a wrecked Starfleet civilian ship
on the surface of a nearby world—the Raven, her parents’ vessel, where the Hansen family first encountered and
was assimilated by the Borg years earlier.

Inside the derelict Raven, Seven confronts both the physical remains of her parents’ work and the emotional
shock of remembering Annika Hansen’s final days as a child. Janeway helps her accept that her human past is
real and still part of her, even if much of it has been buried under Borg conditioning. The encounter deepens
their bond and strengthens Seven’s fragile sense of identity separate from the Collective.

EthicalIssues: Recovering suppressed traumatic memories as part of healing.
The ethics of parents exposing a child to unknown, potentially existential threats for the sake of research.
Supporting someone whose behavior becomes dangerous under the weight of past trauma.
ContinuityNotes: Reveals key elements of Seven’s human backstory and her parents’ role in early Borg study.
Connects Voyager’s Borg arc to pre-existing Federation encounters with the Collective.
Strengthens the mentor–protégé dynamic between Janeway and Seven.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity as a continuum that includes both painful and innocent eras.
Shows how trauma can resurface in unpredictable, destabilizing ways.
Frames Janeway’s support as crucial to Seven’s ongoing reclamation of self.
BehindTheScenes: A major milestone in Seven’s character development.
Uses haunting imagery aboard the Raven to visualize buried memories.
Frequently cited as an important early ‘Seven-centric’ hour.

Title: Scientific Method
Antagonists: Invasive experimenters treating the crew as lab specimens
Unseen tormentors exploiting Voyager as a test bed

StorySections.Text:
Crewmembers across Voyager begin experiencing odd symptoms—rapid aging, personality shifts, inexplicable
pain—without obvious cause. Routine diagnostics reveal nothing, and the anomalies appear random, affecting
different individuals in different ways.

The Doctor and Seven discover that cloaked aliens are literally walking through the ship, performing invasive
experiments on the crew and manipulating their biochemistry for research. Janeway’s attempts at negotiation
are dismissed by the aliens, who regard the humans as acceptable test subjects. As conditions worsen and lives
are lost, Janeway grows increasingly furious and sleep-deprived, pushed to the edge of her own stability.

Realizing that conventional defenses cannot stop the experimenters, Janeway flies Voyager directly toward a
dense, deadly binary pulsar, forcing the aliens to break off their tests or perish with their subjects. Under
extreme gravitational stress, the aliens finally retreat. The crew recovers, left with the knowledge that they
were treated as lab animals—and that their captain was willing to risk everything to end the violation.

EthicalIssues: Conducting non-consensual experiments on sentient beings for ‘pure’ research.
Finding the line between necessary risk and suicidal defiance in defense of autonomy.
Long-term psychological impact of being treated as less than fully sentient.
ContinuityNotes: Further solidifies the Janeway–Seven–Doctor triad in solving complex threats.
Adds another chilling example of hostile encounters in the Delta Quadrant.
Reinforces Voyager’s reputation among some species as dangerously uncompromising.
ThematicNotes: Explores the dark side of ‘objective’ science divorced from ethics.
Highlights Janeway’s capacity for ruthlessness when the crew’s dignity is stripped away.
Suggests that survival sometimes requires making an aggressor fear you.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its disturbing imagery of invisible experimentation.
Often praised for Kate Mulgrew’s intense performance as an exhausted, furious Janeway.
Ranks among the more unsettling episodes dealing with bodily autonomy.

Title: Year of Hell, Part I
Antagonists: Krenim temporal warfare erasing events and species
Annorax’s obsessive quest to restore his timeline

StorySections.Text:
Voyager enters Krenim space and experiences sudden, disorienting changes as a nearby temporal weapon ship
fires at targets in the region. Entire species vanish from history, and the balance of power in the quadrant
shifts around Voyager in real time, leaving the crew struggling to keep up with an ever-changing strategic
landscape.

Repeated temporal incursions batter Voyager, stripping away allies, structural integrity, and crew members.
Janeway orders the removal of non-essential systems, turning the ship into a hardened, scarred vessel barely
holding together. Chakotay and Paris are eventually captured by the Krenim weapon ship’s commander, Annorax, a
scientist who has spent centuries manipulating time in a futile attempt to restore a lost homeworld and erase
his mistakes.

As Annorax tries to enlist Chakotay’s help in refining his temporal calculus, Voyager limps on under constant
assault, with Janeway refusing to consider abandoning the vessel. The episode ends with the ship heavily
damaged, morale fraying, and the full scope of the Krenim threat still unfolding.

EthicalIssues: Manipulating time itself as a weapon of mass destruction.
The moral cost of sacrificing countless lives and histories to correct past choices.
Maintaining leadership and hope during prolonged, grinding catastrophe.
ContinuityNotes: Foreshadows built in ‘Before and After’ pay off here with the full Krenim conflict.
Redesigns Voyager visually to reflect a year of continuous damage and improvisation.
Introduces Annorax as one of Voyager’s most complex antagonists.
ThematicNotes: Explores endurance, trauma, and identity when reality keeps shifting.
Highlights Janeway’s refusal to surrender even in seemingly unwinnable conditions.
Raises questions about whether any personal loss can justify reweaving history.
BehindTheScenes: Frequently ranked among Voyager’s best episodes.
Features extensive makeup, costuming, and model work to depict the ‘war-torn’ year.
Sets up a bleak, serialized crisis rarely seen in mid-90s Trek.

Title: Year of Hell, Part II
Antagonists: Temporal weapon ship and its incursions
Annorax’s fixation on restoring his ideal timeline

StorySections.Text:
Months into the temporal war, Voyager is a shattered skeleton of a ship held together by patches and
stubbornness. Chakotay and Paris remain aboard Annorax’s weapon vessel, where they witness firsthand the cold
calculations behind each temporal strike.

Chakotay initially tries to reason with Annorax, appealing to his guilt and the unintended consequences of his
work, while Paris grows increasingly wary of being co-opted. Aboard Voyager, Janeway orders evacuation of non-
essential personnel to an allied ship, staying behind with a skeleton crew to attempt a final, desperate
assault. Obrist, disillusioned with Annorax’s unending campaign, quietly aids a rebellion against the project.

Janeway pilots the crippled Voyager on a suicide run directly into the temporal weapon ship, timing the impact
with an incursion to destabilize the core. The resulting temporal explosion resets the timeline, erasing the
Year of Hell from history and restoring Voyager and the surrounding space to their pre-war state. Only a faint
sense of déjà vu lingers among the crew, while Annorax is glimpsed back at the moment before he began his
experiments, never taking the fateful step.

EthicalIssues: Accepting that some losses cannot be fixed without causing greater harm.
The seduction and futility of trying to perfect history.
Heroic self-sacrifice when every other option would doom countless lives.
ContinuityNotes: Completes the Krenim narrative hinted at in earlier episodes.
Demonstrates a full reset timeline while preserving character impressions of growth.
Further cements Janeway’s image as a captain willing to go down with her ship for the greater good.
ThematicNotes: Explores closure and letting go in the context of temporal storytelling.
Frames redemption as choosing not to begin a catastrophic project at all.
Suggests that some of the most important growth may leave only subconscious traces.
BehindTheScenes: Widely praised as a powerful conclusion to the ‘Year of Hell’ duology.
Features one of Trek’s most memorable ship-ramming sacrifices.
Balances spectacle with intimate character beats amidst apocalypse.

Title: Random Thoughts
Antagonists: Telepathic ‘thought-crime’ enforcement system
Black market in violent imagery

StorySections.Text:
On the seemingly peaceful telepathic world of the Mari, Voyager’s crew enjoys a rare, tranquil shore leave.
The society’s tranquility is maintained by strict laws against violent thoughts themselves, monitored and
punished by specialized authorities.

When B'Elanna briefly imagines assaulting a local after a minor altercation, that fleeting thought is
telepathically amplified and linked to a real-world attack nearby. She is arrested and sentenced to a ‘thought
rehabilitation’ procedure that will permanently alter her mind. Tuvok investigates and uncovers a black market
in illicit violent imagery that is exploiting offworld visitors like B'Elanna as scapegoats.

By tracing the true source of the violent impulses and exposing the underground trade, Tuvok proves that
B'Elanna was manipulated and that the Mari’s system is not as foolproof as they claim. She is released, but
the society remains committed to its thought-control laws, leaving Voyager to depart with mixed feelings about
the balance between safety and mental freedom.

EthicalIssues: Criminalizing thoughts rather than actions.
Using outsiders as convenient scapegoats to preserve the illusion of a perfect society.
The ethics of altering someone’s mind to prevent potential violence.
ContinuityNotes: Further explores the dangers of telepathic justice systems in Trek.
Provides another strong B'Elanna-focused ethical dilemma.
Shows Tuvok in a detective role that leverages his logical and telepathic skills.
ThematicNotes: Questions whether the absence of overt violence is true peace if it relies on oppressive mental control.
Highlights the difference between intrusive impulses and genuine intent.
Suggests that black markets inevitably spring up where desires are excessively suppressed.
BehindTheScenes: Often praised for its ‘thought-crime’ allegory.
Blends police procedural elements with sci-fi telepathy.
Adds to Voyager’s catalog of morally complex first-contact worlds.

Title: Concerning Flight
Antagonists: Technology thieves exploiting local commerce
Janeway’s own distraction with da Vinci’s world

StorySections.Text:
When several key pieces of Voyager technology— including the computer core and Janeway’s Leonardo da Vinci
holoprogram—are stolen via advanced transport, the trail leads to a bustling Renaissance-like marketplace on a
nearby planet.

On the surface, Janeway discovers her Leonardo program alive and well in the stolen database, believing
himself to be the real da Vinci in a land of strange wonders. As she works with him to track down the thieves,
she must balance her affection for his curious, idealistic perspective with the urgency of recovering vital
equipment. Meanwhile, Tuvok and others negotiate with a wily arms dealer and local powers who see Voyager’s
tech as valuable merchandise.

Using Leonardo’s ingenuity and her own tactical acumen, Janeway stages an aerial escape in a glider, retrieves
the stolen core, and exposes the thieves’ operation. She returns Leonardo to Voyager’s holodeck, where he
continues to dream of flight and invention within the confines of his simulated studio, while Janeway reflects
on the inspiration he provides amid the harsh realities of command.

EthicalIssues: Responsibility for advanced technology that can destabilize less-developed markets.
Treating sentient-seeming holograms with respect even when they are mission tools.
Balancing the need for wonder against the demands of survival.
ContinuityNotes: Brings back Janeway’s Leonardo program from earlier seasons.
Shows the continued risk of Voyager’s tech being stolen and trafficked.
Further humanizes Janeway through her intellectual and emotional connection to historical figures.
ThematicNotes: Explores creativity and curiosity as coping mechanisms in dire circumstances.
Highlights the contrast between idealism and pragmatic scavenging cultures.
Suggests that art and science can coexist even in war-torn contexts.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its lighter, adventure-tinged tone amid a darker season.
Features Anthony Zerbe as a memorable alien merchant antagonist.
Offers Kate Mulgrew playful, character-rich interactions with John Rhys-Davies as Leonardo.

Title: Mortal Coil
Antagonists: Neelix’s crisis of faith after resurrection
Psychological fallout of near-death experience

StorySections.Text:
During a shuttle mission with Chakotay, Neelix is killed instantly by an energy discharge. Hours later, Seven
suggests using Borg nanoprobes to revive him, and the procedure miraculously restores him to life—apparently
without lasting physical damage.

Neelix’s joy at being alive quickly curdles into terror and confusion when he realizes that, during death, he
experienced nothing resembling the comforting Talaxian afterlife he has always believed in. His faith
shattered, he questions the meaning of his life, his role aboard Voyager, and the value of his relationships.
Attempts by friends to reassure him fall flat as he spirals into depression.

On the verge of suicide, Neelix is interrupted by Naomi Wildman, whose innocent trust forces him to confront
how much he still means to others. With help from Chakotay and Janeway, he chooses to continue living even
without the certainty his former beliefs provided. The episode ends with Neelix beginning a fragile, honest
reconstruction of his sense of purpose.

EthicalIssues: Crisis of faith following an experience that contradicts religious expectations.
The psychological impact of being resurrected by technology.
Choosing life in the absence of comforting spiritual assurances.
ContinuityNotes: One of Neelix’s most significant character episodes.
Shows a rare, direct engagement with religious doubt in Trek.
Demonstrates Seven’s medical contributions via Borg technology beyond combat.
ThematicNotes: Explores existential despair and recovery with unusual frankness.
Suggests that meaning can be built through relationships rather than doctrine.
Highlights the quiet heroism of choosing to go on living.
BehindTheScenes: Often cited as a standout Neelix story and an emotionally heavy episode.
Features strong performances from Ethan Phillips and the supporting cast.
Respected for tackling themes of suicide and faith with care within Trek’s framework.

Title: Waking Moments
Antagonists: Species that attacks through shared dreams
Collective dreamscape used as a battleground

StorySections.Text:
Multiple crew members experience intense, unsettling nightmares on the same night, each involving a mysterious
alien figure. The dreams feel unusually vivid, and their lingering effects begin to interfere with normal
duties.

As more of the crew falls asleep and fails to wake, Chakotay—skilled in controlled dream states from his
cultural background—volunteers to remain in a lucid dreaming mode to investigate. He discovers that an alien
species is using a shared dreamscape to trap and terrorize the crew, intending to keep them in perpetual
slumber while seizing the ship. Distinguishing dream from reality becomes increasingly difficult as the aliens
exploit fears and hopes alike.

Chakotay uses dream-signaling techniques to coordinate with Janeway and others across layers of false
awakenings, ultimately confronting the alien leader inside the dream and threatening mutual destruction if
they do not release the crew. The aliens back down, and Voyager’s personnel finally wake. Though the immediate
danger has passed, the episode closes with an uneasy sense that sleep itself has been permanently complicated
for many aboard.

EthicalIssues: Weaponizing dreams and vulnerability during sleep.
Using cultural spiritual practices as tactical tools.
The psychological residue of shared, manufactured nightmares.
ContinuityNotes: Further explores Chakotay’s spiritual practices in a sci-fi context.
Adds another unusual Delta Quadrant species with non-conventional attack methods.
Continues Voyager’s interest in mindscapes and altered states of consciousness.
ThematicNotes: Blurs boundaries between reality and dream to examine fear and trust.
Highlights resilience in the mental as well as physical arena.
Suggests that inner disciplines can be as powerful as technology in certain battles.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its twisty dream-within-dream structure.
Gives Robert Beltran a central, psychologically focused role.
Offers a memorable entry in Trek’s tradition of dream-based storytelling.

Title: Message in a Bottle
Antagonists: Romulan hijackers of the Prometheus
Risks of experimental multi-vector assault mode

StorySections.Text:
Seven detects an ancient Federation relay network extending into the Delta Quadrant. Janeway seizes the
opportunity to try to contact Starfleet, and the Doctor volunteers to be transmitted through the unstable
system as a data stream, hoping to reach a Federation vessel.

The Doctor materializes on the USS Prometheus in the Alpha Quadrant—only to find it captured by Romulans and
running on automatic. With the Mark II EMH as his only ally, he must retake control of the experimental
warship, mastering its complex multi-vector assault capabilities while keeping the Romulan boarding parties at
bay.

After some chaotic trial and error, the two holograms successfully defeat the hijackers and contact Starfleet
Command. For the first time since being stranded, Voyager’s crew learns that Starfleet is aware of their
situation and will work to send assistance and news to their families, giving the crew renewed hope.

EthicalIssues: Risking a unique, irreplaceable individual (the Doctor) on a dangerous communications gambit.
Questioning the wisdom of designing heavily automated warships vulnerable to takeover.
Recognizing holograms as capable officers, not just tools.
ContinuityNotes: Marks the first confirmed contact between Voyager and Starfleet since ‘The Caretaker’.
Introduces the EMH Mark II and the Prometheus-class warship.
Establishes that Starfleet will begin sending data to Voyager via the relay network.
ThematicNotes: Explores autonomy and competence of holographic beings in a purely Starfleet setting.
Highlights hope as a powerful motivator after years of isolation.
Contrasts the rough-around-the-edges EMH Mark I with his more polished successor.
BehindTheScenes: Often remembered for its comedic ‘two Doctors’ dynamic.
Features extensive new ship design and effects for the Prometheus.
Represents a major turning point in Voyager’s connection to the Alpha Quadrant.

Title: Hunters
Antagonists: Hirogen predatory culture
Hazards of the ancient relay network

StorySections.Text:
Using the newly accessible relay network, Voyager begins receiving long-awaited letters from home. The
emotional impact is immediate: joy, grief, and shock ripple through the crew as they finally learn what has
happened to their families and friends since their disappearance.

Attempts to access more of the network bring Voyager into conflict with the Hirogen, a nomadic species that
considers the stations their hunting grounds. The Hirogen capture Tuvok and Seven to study them as prey,
revealing a culture built entirely around ritualized pursuit and trophies. A rescue mission must balance
protecting the crew with avoiding wholesale escalation.

Voyager manages to rescue the captives and disable the local relay, knowing it will limit further contact with
home. The crew is left processing deeply personal news—some comforting, others devastating—as Janeway
contemplates the price of knowledge and the new threat posed by the Hirogen.

EthicalIssues: Whether limited, painful information is better than none at all.
Respecting or resisting a culture that treats sentient beings as game.
Balancing strategic opportunities against the risk of provoking a powerful new enemy.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Hirogen, who will recur as major antagonists.
Continues the Starfleet-message arc begun in ‘Message in a Bottle’.
Provides key character beats as crew members learn fates of loved ones back home.
ThematicNotes: Explores the emotional cost of re-establishing ties with a distant home.
Frames hunting culture as both fascinating and deeply disturbing.
Highlights Seven’s growing sense of individuality in the face of objectification.
BehindTheScenes: Combines intimate character drama with the debut of a new warrior species.
Frequently noted for its moving ‘letters from home’ sequences.
Sets up longer-term storylines involving the Hirogen and the relay grid.

Title: Prey
Antagonists: Hirogen hunters
Rampaging but injured Species 8472

StorySections.Text:
Voyager rescues a battered Hirogen ship whose Alpha leader insists on pursuing a mysterious, deadly prey that
has escaped onto Voyager. Evidence soon reveals that the quarry is a lone, wounded member of Species 8472.

The Hirogen demand the right to continue their hunt aboard Voyager, clashing with Janeway’s insistence on
protecting her crew and attempting to treat the injured alien. Seven, weighing Borg experience against
Starfleet ethics, argues that Species 8472 is too dangerous to risk. As the creature stalks the corridors,
Tuvok and Seven work to contain it while tensions with the Hirogen approach open conflict.

When Janeway orders that the 8472 individual be transported to a safe area rather than surrendered, Seven
defies her and beams it to a Hirogen ship instead, believing that honoring the hunt and removing the threat is
the most logical path. The Hirogen depart, but the breach of trust strains Janeway and Seven’s relationship,
underscoring their different views on survival and principle.

EthicalIssues: Protecting a dangerous sentient being versus eliminating a clear threat.
Interfering with a hunt rooted in another culture’s identity.
Obedience to command decisions versus personal judgment in crisis.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops Hirogen culture and their obsession with worthy prey.
Revisits Species 8472 as a formidable, if now more vulnerable, presence.
Deepens the Janeway–Seven conflict begun in earlier Borg-related episodes.
ThematicNotes: Shows Seven pivoting toward independent moral decisions, not just Borg conditioning.
Explores the limits of Federation humanitarianism in extreme circumstances.
Highlights the friction between utilitarian calculus and Starfleet ideals.
BehindTheScenes: Regarded as a strong Hirogen-centric episode with high tension.
Features extensive creature effects for Species 8472 in confined spaces.
Continues Voyager’s darker, ethically complex fourth-season tone.

Title: Retrospect
Antagonists: Possibly false recovered memories of assault
Rush to judgment in a criminal accusation

StorySections.Text:
After a tense trade negotiation with arms dealer Kovach, Seven suddenly lashes out and assaults him,
apparently triggered by physical contact. Disturbed by her own reaction, she agrees to a new psycho-
therapeutic technique from the Doctor to explore underlying trauma.

Under the Doctor’s guidance, Seven experiences vivid ‘recovered’ memories of Kovach restraining and violating
her autonomy while extracting Borg technology. Convinced of her account, the crew pursues Kovach, who denies
any abuse. As the confrontation escalates, the Doctor and Janeway struggle with how much weight to give
Seven’s subjective experience in the absence of corroborating evidence.

Clues emerge suggesting that Seven’s memories may be distorted or misattributed to routine medical scans,
raising doubts about the accusation just as Kovach is killed in a firefight. The Doctor is left wracked with
guilt for pushing an unproven therapy and fueling a potentially false charge, while Seven grapples with the
ambiguity of what truly happened and the reality of feeling violated regardless.

EthicalIssues: Handling allegations of assault when evidence is ambiguous.
Dangers of suggestive therapeutic techniques creating or reshaping memories.
Taking survivors seriously while guarding against irreversible judgments.
ContinuityNotes: Adds another layer to Seven’s complex post-assimilation trauma.
Advances the Doctor’s growth—and fallibility—as a mental health practitioner.
Contributes to ongoing debates among fans and critics about memory reliability.
ThematicNotes: Explores the fraught intersection of trauma, memory, and justice.
Highlights the weight of responsibility borne by those in helping professions.
Acknowledges that emotional truth and factual truth do not always align neatly.
BehindTheScenes: One of Voyager’s more controversial episodes due to its subject matter.
Showcases Jeri Ryan and Robert Picardo in intense psychological drama.
Frequently revisited in discussions of how Trek handles assault narratives.

Title: The Killing Game, Part I
GuestCharacters: Holodeck WWII resistance fighters and Nazi officers
Antagonists: Hirogen using Voyager as a holographic hunting ground
Nazi holodeck program as a backdrop for the hunt

StorySections.Text:
Voyager has fallen under full Hirogen control. The crew, implanted with neural interfaces that overwrite their
memories, are trapped in elaborate holodeck scenarios where they unknowingly play prey in endless hunts, while
the Hirogen observe and participate as apex predators.

In a sprawling World War II simulation set in Nazi-occupied France, Janeway believes herself to be a
resistance leader, Seven a nightclub singer and informant, and other crew members various roles in the
conflict. As the Doctor and a few partially aware crew struggle behind the scenes to circumvent the Hirogen
systems, fractures in the holodeck illusion hint at the ship’s true state. The Hirogen commandant sees the
simulations as a way to evolve his people beyond simple one-on-one hunts.

Sabotage efforts begin to destabilize the holoprograms, causing overlapping simulations and increasing chaos.
The Hirogen tighten their control, determined to maintain their grand experiment, even as Janeway and others
start to experience flickers of their true identities beneath the imposed roles.

EthicalIssues: Enslaving sentient beings for ritualized entertainment and training.
Using historical atrocities as a playground for bloodsport.
The ethics of imposing cultural ‘reform’ through violent coercion.
ContinuityNotes: Deepens the Hirogen arc by showing their desire to adapt their traditions.
Makes extensive use of Voyager’s holodeck technology as a tool of oppression.
Sets up major consequences for Voyager’s physical and psychological state.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity under layered roles and false memories.
Uses WWII imagery to comment on fascism and dehumanization.
Highlights the adaptability of Voyager’s crew even when stripped of context.
BehindTheScenes: Noted for its ambitious production design and large-scale holodeck war sequences.
Part one of a two-part event that heavily features the Hirogen.
Offers a distinctive genre mashup of Trek and war epic.

Title: The Killing Game, Part II
Antagonists: Expanding, uncontrolled holodeck war zone
Hirogen faction resisting change

StorySections.Text:
Holodeck damage causes multiple programs to bleed together, turning Voyager into a chaotic battleground: WWII
soldiers, Klingon warriors, and other simulations collide in the corridors, with crew and Hirogen caught in
the middle, many still unaware of their true identities.

Janeway and the Doctor work to disable the control interfaces and awaken key crew members, while the Hirogen
commandant faces rebellion from traditionalists who reject his vision of a more sustainable, story-based
hunting culture. Seven, gradually regaining her memories, must juggle her undercover holodeck persona with her
real loyalty to Voyager.

Janeway negotiates a tenuous peace by offering the Hirogen permanent holotechnology templates they can use to
continue their hunts without decimating real populations. The Hirogen accept the compromise and depart,
leaving Voyager severely damaged but free. The deal raises long-term questions about what the Hirogen will do
with that gifted technology.

EthicalIssues: Providing dangerous technology to a violent culture as a harm-reduction strategy.
Preserving life by enabling simulated violence on a massive scale.
The cost of cultural evolution when it is imposed amid bloodshed.
ContinuityNotes: Substantially changes Hirogen society’s potential trajectory via holotechnology.
Leaves Voyager with lasting physical damage and psychological scars.
Demonstrates Janeway’s willingness to make morally uneasy bargains to protect her crew.
ThematicNotes: Explores the idea of narrative and role-play as outlets for destructive impulses.
Raises questions about whether simulation truly substitutes for real violence.
Highlights compromise as sometimes the only viable path short of annihilation.
BehindTheScenes: Concludes one of Voyager’s most visually ambitious two-parters.
Features large-scale combat sequences and extensive guest cast work.
Remains a memorable example of Trek’s ability to cross genres within its own framework.

Title: Vis à Vis
GuestCharacters: Alien victims whose bodies were previously stolen
Antagonists: Body-hopping con artist
Misuse of identity and trust

StorySections.Text:
Restless and bored with his growing responsibilities, Tom Paris becomes fascinated with a visiting pilot,
Steth, who flies a sleek, morphing spacecraft. Steth’s freewheeling lifestyle and disregard for rules appeal
to Paris’s old rebellious streak.

When Paris helps Steth repair his ship, the alien unexpectedly switches bodies with him, trapping Paris in
Steth’s form while the impostor boards Voyager and begins impersonating Tom. The fake Paris’s erratic behavior
strains relationships and threatens the ship, while the real Paris must convince others in distant space that
he is not the body-swapping criminal.

With the help of another victim of Steth’s body theft, Paris returns to Voyager and exposes the impostor. A
struggle ends with the true Steth restored to his own body and the entity’s latest host freed. Back in his own
skin, Paris is chastened about his flirtation with running away from his responsibilities and recommits to his
role on Voyager.

EthicalIssues: Identity theft taken to the level of literal bodily possession.
Temptation to abandon hard-earned growth for the illusion of freedom.
Responsibility to warn others about a predator who steals lives piecemeal.
ContinuityNotes: Adds another entry to Trek’s long list of body-swap tales.
Further explores Tom Paris’s ongoing maturation from rebel to reliable officer.
Offers small development beats in his relationships with the crew, especially the Doctor.
ThematicNotes: Examines escapism and commitment through sci-fi identity play.
Highlights how subtle personality shifts can signal something deeply wrong.
Suggests that real freedom can come from embracing, not fleeing, responsibility.
BehindTheScenes: Often viewed as a more modest, character-driven episode in a big season.
Showcases Robert Duncan McNeill’s ability to play both ‘real’ and ‘fake’ Tom.
