connection remain. Neelix takes comfort in the idea that, even if Tuvok rarely shows it, a deeper friendship
endures.

EthicalIssues: Respecting a patient’s altered identity versus seeking full restoration.
Fear-driven isolationism taken to violent extremes.
Finding value in unexpected versions of familiar people.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops the long-running Tuvok–Neelix dynamic.
Introduces the Ba’Neth as an unusually reclusive species.
Leaves open the question of how much of ‘changed Tuvok’ persists.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity continuity after brain injury.
Highlights Neelix’s patience and loyalty.
Suggests that friendship can survive even when its expressions are subtle.
BehindTheScenes: Noted for its gentle humor and quiet emotion.
Offers Tim Russ a chance to play a different facet of Tuvok.
Often appreciated for deepening Neelix beyond comic relief.

Title: Dragon's Teeth
Antagonists: Vaadwaur’s hidden militaristic past
Power vacuum created by awakening an old power

StorySections.Text:
Voyager takes shelter from attacking Turei ships in the ruins of a devastated planet, where they discover
stasis pods containing members of an extinct-looking species, the Vaadwaur.

The crew revives several Vaadwaur, including Gedrin, who claim to be victims of Turei aggression from
centuries past. Seven discovers that the Borg once recorded the Vaadwaur as a powerful, expansionist people
who used subspace corridors to dominate huge swaths of space. As more Vaadwaur awaken, their true ambitions
resurface, and they begin plotting to seize Voyager and reclaim their lost empire.

Realizing they’ve unleashed a serious threat, Janeway allies with the Turei to prevent the Vaadwaur from
escaping with Voyager. A chaotic battle ensues, leaving many Vaadwaur ships destroyed, but some escape into
the corridor network. Voyager departs, having inadvertently reintroduced a dangerous wildcard into the
quadrant.

EthicalIssues: Responsibility for reviving a long-buried power with a violent history.
Judging a people by their ancient past versus current circumstances.
Balancing trust in a sympathetic survivor’s story against hard evidence.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Vaadwaur and their ‘underspace’ corridor network.
Hints that the Vaadwaur may trouble the galaxy again in the future.
Connects to broader Trek themes about ancient powers and hidden routes.
ThematicNotes: Explores the risks of playing savior without full historical context.
Highlights how empires can sleep but not die.
Adds nuance by showing individual Vaadwaur who question their people’s old ways.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its ambitious space battles and new alien makeup designs.
Intended as a possible springboard for future Vaadwaur stories.
Stands as a cautionary tale about ‘dragons’ buried in the past.

Title: One Small Step
Antagonists: Subspace anomaly ‘graviton ellipse’
Risky salvage mission for historical relic

StorySections.Text:
Voyager encounters a massive subspace phenomenon known as a graviton ellipse that has been traveling through
space for centuries, swallowing objects in its path. Sensors detect inside it the wreckage of Ares IV, an
early human Mars mission lost in 2032.

Chakotay, Paris, and Seven take a shuttle into the ellipse to retrieve the Ares module and its remains.
Chakotay is deeply moved by the chance to honor a formative era of space exploration, while Seven initially
dismisses it as irrelevant nostalgia. Inside, they discover Lt. John Kelly’s logs, detailing his awe and
scientific curiosity as he confronted the unknown and faced his death alone.

As they fight shifting gravimetric forces to escape, Seven gains a newfound respect for Kelly’s courage and
the ‘small steps’ that made the Federation possible. They manage to recover his body and personal effects,
bringing closure to a story centuries in the making. Back on Voyager, the crew holds a ceremony to honor him
as a pioneer.

EthicalIssues: Valuing early, imperfect pioneers whose efforts paved the way for future greatness.
Risking lives to recover historical artifacts and remains.
Respect for those who faced the unknown with limited tools and knowledge.
ContinuityNotes: Connects Voyager to early 21st-century human spaceflight history.
Adds depth to Chakotay’s and Paris’s interest in space exploration lore.
Provides a rare on-screen look at a pre-warp mission’s fate.
ThematicNotes: Celebrates the spirit of exploration central to Star Trek.
Shows Seven developing appreciation for human history and heroism.
Frames the past as a living influence, not just distant legend.
BehindTheScenes: Frequently cited as a heartfelt, quietly powerful episode.
Features strong guest work as Lt. Kelly via log recordings.
Resonates with real-world space exploration milestones.

Title: The Voyager Conspiracy
Antagonists: Data overload from multi-node assimilation
Paranoid pattern-making by Seven

StorySections.Text:
Seeking greater efficiency in processing information, Seven modifies her alcove to download and assimilate all
of Voyager’s sensor logs and records at once, vastly increasing her analytical throughput.

The flood of data pushes Seven into overanalysis, leading her to construct elaborate conspiracy theories about
the ship’s history. She becomes convinced that Janeway and Chakotay are engaged in secret plots—first casting
Janeway as saboteur, then Chakotay as mutineer—as she forces disparate facts into coherent but false
narratives. Her accusations sow distrust on the bridge just as Voyager approaches a promising waystation.

Realizing that Seven’s cognitive matrix is suffering from pattern-recognition overload, Janeway and Chakotay
stage a confrontation that forces her to see the contradictions in her theories. With the Doctor’s help, they
reset her processing routines, scaling back her data intake. Seven admits that even her enhanced mind has
limits—and that trust sometimes means accepting incomplete information.

EthicalIssues: Danger of seeing patterns and plots in every ambiguity.
Balancing healthy skepticism with trust in comrades.
Recognizing cognitive limits and guarding against information overload.
ContinuityNotes: Adds a meta-commentary on fans’ tendency to over-interpret continuity details.
Further defines the parameters of Seven’s mental capabilities and vulnerabilities.
Leaves a humorous mark on Janeway and Chakotay’s already complex relationship.
ThematicNotes: Explores paranoia as a side effect of hyper-analysis.
Highlights that even brilliant minds need rest and boundaries.
Underscores the importance of interpersonal trust on a long mission.
BehindTheScenes: Often appreciated for its playful engagement with conspiracy thinking.
Gives Jeri Ryan a chance to lay out wildly different theories with conviction.
Provides both tension and humor via escalating accusations.

Title: Pathfinder
Antagonists: Barclay’s obsession with contacting Voyager
Starfleet skepticism about his methods

StorySections.Text:
On Earth, Lieutenant Reginald Barclay works with the Pathfinder Project, a Starfleet task force dedicated to
finding a way to communicate with Voyager. He spends increasing time in a holodeck simulation of the ship and
crew, blurring the line between his work and escapist fantasy.

Barclay becomes convinced that a specialized graviton array could establish a narrow communications corridor
to the Delta Quadrant, but his superiors doubt his proposal and worry that he is relapsing into unhealthy
holodeck addiction. Turning to Counselor Troi for support, he struggles to prove that his idea is sound while
fighting his own anxieties and Starfleet’s lack of confidence.

Defying orders, Barclay commandeers the array to test his plan—and it works. Voyager receives a brief but
emotional live transmission from Starfleet, speaking with Admiral Paris and learning about developments back
home. Rather than punish him harshly, Starfleet recognizes the value of his breakthrough and keeps him on the
project, with Troi’s ongoing guidance.

EthicalIssues: Navigating the boundary between dedication and unhealthy obsession.
Trusting unconventional thinkers who struggle with anxiety and social norms.
The ethics of disobeying orders in pursuit of a potentially transformative breakthrough.
ContinuityNotes: Brings back Barclay and Troi from The Next Generation in major guest roles.
Establishes a two-way communications link between Voyager and Starfleet that recurs later.
Expands on Tom Paris’s relationship with his father via the Admiral’s messages.
ThematicNotes: Explores neurodivergent-coded genius in a sympathetic way.
Highlights the emotional impact of renewed contact for both crews.
Shows that progress sometimes depends on those who think ‘sideways.’
BehindTheScenes: Widely liked for its TNG crossover and emotional payoff.
Offers a fresh Earth-based perspective on Voyager’s situation.
Helps reposition Barclay as a heroic, if still anxious, figure.

Title: Fair Haven
Antagonists: Janeway’s use of holodeck romantic partner
Program instability during storm crisis

StorySections.Text:
To boost morale during a turbulent region of space, Tom Paris creates a cozy Irish village holoprogram called
Fair Haven, complete with a charming barkeep, Michael Sullivan, who quickly catches Janeway’s eye.

Janeway begins spending time in Fair Haven and gradually tweaks Michael’s personality and backstory—altering
his education, temperament, and even his marital status—to better suit her preferences. As she becomes
emotionally invested, she struggles with the ethical implications of effectively editing a romantic partner.
Meanwhile, a dangerous storm outside forces the ship to keep the program running at low power, causing
glitches in the village.

After a near-disaster when the storm threatens both the ship and the holoprogram, Janeway decides to stop
micromanaging Michael’s parameters. She sets boundaries for herself, acknowledging that while holographic
companionship has value, she must respect the line between fantasy and genuine mutuality. Fair Haven remains
on the menu for the crew, but Janeway steps back from using it as a surrogate for a real relationship.

EthicalIssues: Editing a partner’s personality to create an idealized romance.
Using simulated relationships as an escape from real vulnerability.
Respecting emergent personhood in sophisticated holoprograms.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Fair Haven, which will return in later episodes.
Adds another layer to Trek’s ongoing exploration of holodeck ethics.
Provides insight into Janeway’s loneliness and romantic restraint.
ThematicNotes: Explores the tension between control and authenticity in love.
Highlights the captain’s isolation at the top of the command hierarchy.
Raises questions about where the Doctor’s personhood and other holograms’ begin.
BehindTheScenes: Memorable for its Irish village setting and lighter tone.
Divisive among fans but important for Janeway’s emotional arc.
Features folk music, pub scenes, and a more relaxed side of the crew.

Title: Blink of an Eye
Antagonists: Severe time dilation on the planet below
Cultural upheaval caused by Voyager’s presence

StorySections.Text:
Voyager becomes trapped in orbit around a planet with an extreme temporal differential: time on the surface
passes thousands of times faster than aboard the ship. To the inhabitants, Voyager appears as a stationary
‘sky ship’ present in their sky for millennia.

As Voyager works to free itself, the crew watches the planet’s civilization evolve from a primitive society to
a technological world obsessed with understanding the sky ship, which influences their myths, science, and
even wars. The Doctor spends what feels like three years on the surface, helping them and witnessing their
rapid progress, while only hours pass on Voyager. Eventually, the planet launches a crewed mission to
investigate the ship directly.

With help from astronaut Gotana-Retz and data the Doctor brings back, Voyager finds a way to break free from
orbit without causing catastrophic seismic effects. As they depart, the now highly advanced civilization sends
a final salute, and Janeway reflects on the profound, if brief from their perspective, relationship between
the ship and an entire world’s history.

EthicalIssues: Unintended cultural contamination through mere presence.
Responsibility toward societies affected by relativistic phenomena.
Experiencing time and relationships at radically different scales.
ContinuityNotes: Adds a distinctive entry to Trek’s time-dilation stories.
Provides major off-screen growth for the Doctor during his years planetside.
Leaves Voyager with a unique legacy on a single world.
ThematicNotes: Explores perspective on time, influence, and progress.
Highlights the awe and danger inherent in technological disparities.
Suggests that even brief encounters can shape civilizations.
BehindTheScenes: Frequently ranked among Voyager’s finest episodes.
Noted for its ambitious storytelling and emotional resonance.
Showcases creative worldbuilding over multiple eras in one hour.

Title: Virtuoso
Antagonists: Qomar society’s shallow adoration
Doctor’s inflated ego and abandonment of duties

StorySections.Text:
Voyager assists a hyper-logical species called the Qomar, who initially belittle organics as inferior. When
the Doctor sings for them, they are astonished by music—a concept they have never encountered—and become
instantly fascinated.

The Qomar elevate the Doctor to celebrity status, showering him with praise and fandom. Drunk on adulation, he
considers resigning from Voyager to live among them as a full-time performer, neglecting his medical
responsibilities and straining his relationships with the crew, particularly Seven. The Qomar even design a
new holographic body for him, seemingly tailored to their tastes.

The Doctor’s inflated ego crashes when the Qomar unveil an improved ‘singing hologram’ they have created,
casually discarding him as obsolete. Humbled, he returns to Voyager, where Janeway and the others welcome him
back with affection and teasing. He is reminded that genuine appreciation matters more than fickle acclaim.

EthicalIssues: The dangers of celebrity worship and shallow validation.
Abandoning essential duties for personal glory.
Recognizing the value of sincere, if less spectacular, appreciation.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops the Doctor’s artistic ambitions and ego.
Expands Voyager’s catalogue of radically different alien value systems.
Adds another beat in the Doctor–Seven friendship arc.
ThematicNotes: Explores self-worth beyond external applause.
Highlights the difference between being loved as a novelty and loved as a person.
Uses humor to underscore meaningful character growth.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its musical performances and satirical take on fandom.
Gives Robert Picardo another showcase for singing.
Often remembered as a light, character-driven mid-season entry.

Title: Memorial
Antagonists: Alien memorial broadcasting traumatic memories
Government that chose forced remembrance

StorySections.Text:
After a routine away mission, Chakotay, Tom, Harry, and Neelix return to Voyager seemingly unharmed. Days
later they begin suffering vivid flashbacks of participating in a brutal ground battle and slaughtering
civilians—events none of them remember actually living through.

The hallucinations grow more intense and debilitating, affecting sleep and behavior. Medical scans reveal a
foreign neural pattern in their brains. Tracing the source, Voyager discovers a monument on a nearby planet
that transmits recorded memories of a historical massacre into the minds of passersby so they will ‘never
forget’ the atrocity. Janeway learns that the local government intentionally built the memorial as a guilt-
driven warning to future generations, without considering outsiders who might be exposed.

The crew debates whether to shut the memorial down, spare others the trauma, or repair it and add a warning.
Ultimately, Janeway decides to restore its power and place a beacon advising visitors of the choice they face.
The away team begins the long emotional process of integrating memories that are not theirs yet feel painfully
real.

EthicalIssues: Imposing traumatic memories on strangers in the name of remembrance.
The ethics of vicarious guilt and forced empathy.
Balancing the need to remember atrocities against the harm of reliving them.
ContinuityNotes: Echoes Trek’s tradition of memorials and historical reckoning.
Deepens characterization for Tom, Harry, Chakotay, and Neelix via their reactions.
Leaves the memorial functioning with additional context, not erased.
ThematicNotes: Explores how memory shapes identity even when experiences are ‘borrowed’.
Raises questions about collective responsibility for past crimes.
Highlights Janeway’s preference for informed choice over paternalistic erasure.
BehindTheScenes: Noted for its intense battle flashbacks and emotional fallout.
Offers an allegorical treatment of war memory and PTSD.
Often discussed in relation to real-world debates over how to teach atrocities.

Title: Tsunkatse
Antagonists: For-profit gladiatorial bloodsport
Kidnappers exploiting unwilling fighters

StorySections.Text:
During shore leave on a Norcadian colony, several crew members attend matches of Tsunkatse, a popular arena
combat sport. On an excursion, Seven and Tuvok are abducted by promoters seeking new fighters.

Seven is forced to train as a Tsunkatse contender under a veteran Hirogen who instructs her in the art of the
hunt-style combat. Tuvok, badly injured, is held as leverage to ensure Seven fights and wins. Meanwhile,
Voyager’s crew initially enjoys the spectacle of Tsunkatse broadcasts, unaware that Seven has become the
unwilling star attraction. When they recognize her, they scramble to locate the broadcast source and shut the
operation down.

In a climactic ‘blue match’ to the death, Seven refuses to deliver the killing blow to her opponent, defying
the crowd and promoters. Voyager intervenes, rescuing her and surviving fighters; the Hirogen mentor
sacrifices his chance at freedom to help disrupt the match. Back aboard ship, Seven reflects on the pull of
her combat conditioning and the choice she made to stop short of murder.

EthicalIssues: Exploiting sentient beings for gladiatorial entertainment.
Spectators’ complicity in bloodsport economies.
Resisting culturally ingrained instincts toward violence.
ContinuityNotes: Features a Hirogen returning in a new role as Seven’s trainer.
Connects to Voyager’s earlier encounters with Hirogen hunting culture.
Shows the crew seeing their own crewmate as an arena fighter before understanding the context.
ThematicNotes: Explores autonomy against external coercion in high-stakes settings.
Highlights Seven’s struggle between survival efficiency and moral restraint.
Critiques violent spectacle as mass entertainment.
BehindTheScenes: Guest stars The Rock (Dwayne Johnson) in a small Tsunkatse role.
Known as the ‘boxing/wrestling’ episode of Voyager.
Balances action-heavy sequences with character introspection.

Title: Collective
Antagonists: Group of disconnected Borg children
Damaged mini-Collective struggling for identity

StorySections.Text:
During a poker game aboard a Delta Flyer mission, several crew members are captured by a small Borg vessel.
Voyager catches up to find the cube strangely quiet and partially derelict.

Boarding parties discover that only a handful of young drones remain: children severed from the main
Collective by a neurolytic pathogen that killed or disabled the adults. The juveniles attempt to bluff Voyager
with threats of assimilation while struggling to maintain their own mini-Collective. Seven is tasked with
negotiating their surrender, seeing in them echoes of herself and her own stolen childhood.

As the cube deteriorates, Seven convinces most of the children that the Collective has abandoned them and that
they have a chance at genuine lives aboard Voyager. The ship is destroyed, but the surviving drones—eventually
named Icheb, Mezoti, Rebi, and Azan—join the crew, beginning the long road toward individuality under Seven’s
guidance.

EthicalIssues: Responsibility toward enemy children found in compromised circumstances.
Rehabilitation versus returning juveniles to an abusive collective.
How much autonomy to grant minors with dangerous capabilities.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Borg children who will recur for multiple seasons.
Expands on the idea of partial-disconnection from the Collective as survivable.
Creates a quasi-family dynamic for Seven as mentor and guardian.
ThematicNotes: Explores themes of adoption, mentorship, and second chances.
Shows Seven extending the compassion once shown to her.
Highlights the lingering trauma of childhood assimilation.
BehindTheScenes: Important setup episode for Icheb and the other ex-drone kids.
Mixes eerie Borg ship imagery with unexpectedly domestic themes.
Often remembered as a turning point in Seven’s arc toward a parental role.

Title: Spirit Folk
Antagonists: Holodeck characters gaining suspicion and fear
Program instability causing ‘magic’ glitches

StorySections.Text:
The Fair Haven holoprogram has become a favorite escape for the crew, running almost continuously. Strange
glitches begin appearing to the villagers—time jumps, teleportation-like effects, and inconsistent behavior
from their ‘visitors’—leading them to suspect supernatural forces at work.

As the program’s characters observe crew members manipulating the environment via controls they perceive as
magic, they conclude that the offworlders are dangerous ‘spirit folk.’ Michael Sullivan and others grow
fearful, and when they capture Tom and Harry, they attempt to extract answers with improvised trials and
interrogations. Janeway must navigate the crisis while also confronting her complicated attachment to Michael.

Janeway and the Doctor find a way to calm the villagers, reframing the Federation crew not as malevolent
spirits but as travelers and friends. Program repairs restore stability, and the crew reestablishes Fair Haven
as a leisure environment with greater respect for the emergent depth of its characters. Janeway, in
particular, accepts that she must treat Michael less as a toy and more as a being with his own internal
consistency.

EthicalIssues: Holodeck personhood and the ethics of treating sophisticated simulations as playthings.
Cultural panic when inexplicable phenomena are labeled as witchcraft or ‘spirits’.
Responsibility for side effects when leisure programs are overused.
ContinuityNotes: Continues the Fair Haven storyline begun in ‘Fair Haven’.
Further explores Janeway’s relationship with Michael Sullivan.
Adds another entry in Trek’s ongoing holodeck-ethics discussion.
ThematicNotes: Uses folklore and superstition to explore misunderstandings of advanced tech.
Highlights the thin line between escapism and entanglement.
Shows Janeway moving toward a more respectful stance on complex holograms.
BehindTheScenes: Known as the ‘Fair Haven, part two’ episode, with a whimsical tone.
Divides fans but provides character beats for Janeway and Tom.
Leans into Irish village charm and light comedic misunderstandings.

Title: Ashes to Ashes
Antagonists: Kobali reproductive practice (reanimating the dead)
Cultural tug-of-war over identity

StorySections.Text:
Voyager is hailed by a small ship whose pilot claims to be Lyndsay Ballard, a crewmember who died years
earlier and was buried in space. She now appears alive but in an alien form, asking to come home.

Ballard explains that her body was recovered by the Kobali, a species that reproduces by reanimating the
corpses of other races and altering them genetically. She has lived among them as Jhet’leya, even acquiring a
Kobali ‘family,’ but has been unable to let go of her human identity and her feelings for Harry Kim. As she
tries to reintegrate with Voyager, her Kobali physiology and imprinting pull her back toward her adopted
people, who arrive demanding her return.

Caught between two lives, Ballard realizes that her memories of being human are fading while her Kobali nature
grows stronger. Recognizing that she can no longer fully belong on Voyager, she tearfully chooses to return
with her Kobali family, leaving Harry and the crew to mourn her for a second time—this time with some measure
of closure.

EthicalIssues: Whether reclaiming the dead for reproduction violates the dignity of prior identity.
Honoring a person’s chosen self when biology drags them elsewhere.
The limits of ‘returning home’ when fundamental change has occurred.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Kobali and their unusual reproductive method.
Retroactively adds Lyndsay Ballard to Voyager’s past crew complement.
Gives Harry another bittersweet romantic storyline.
ThematicNotes: Explores grief, transformation, and the impossibility of simply going back.
Highlights the tension between DNA, culture, and memory in defining selfhood.
Frames love as sometimes requiring letting someone go where they now belong.
BehindTheScenes: Often noted as an underrated emotional episode.
Features strong guest work portraying Ballard’s divided loyalties.
Resonates with themes of adoption, transition, and identity shift.

Title: Child's Play
Antagonists: Parents breeding a child as a biological weapon against the Borg
Brunali–Borg conflict around the transwarp conduit

StorySections.Text:
Starfleet sends Voyager coordinates to the Brunali homeworld, revealing that Icheb’s biological parents may
still be alive. Seven is skeptical but agrees to visit with him.

On the agrarian Brunali world, Icheb meets his parents, who express remorse that he was assimilated during a
Borg attack near a local transwarp conduit. They ask that he stay and rebuild a life with them. Seven
struggles with the prospect of losing the ‘son’ she has effectively adopted, while sensing that the Brunali
are hiding something about the circumstances of his assimilation.

Voyager uncovers the truth: Icheb was genetically engineered by the Brunali as a living anti-Borg pathogen,
designed to be assimilated and then infect a cube from within. His parents plan to send him back toward the
conduit to repeat the weaponization. Janeway and Seven intervene, rescuing Icheb and bringing him back to
Voyager, where he chooses to remain, recognizing that his worth is more than his utility as a weapon.

EthicalIssues: Breeding a child explicitly as a weapon against an implacable foe.
Parental love entangled with utilitarian sacrifice.
Respecting a young person’s autonomy after they learn they were instrumentalized.
ContinuityNotes: Deepens Icheb’s backstory and explains his unique genetic traits.
Reinforces Seven’s evolving parental bond with him.
Expands on the Brunali–Borg dynamic around the transwarp conduit.
ThematicNotes: Explores how desperation in war can corrupt basic parental ethics.
Highlights Seven’s protective, nurturing side in stark contrast to Brunali pragmatism.
Asks whether ends can ever justify such profoundly personal means.
BehindTheScenes: Regarded as a strong, unsettling Icheb-focused story.
Adds a darker twist to Voyager’s broader Borg narrative.
Features impactful emotional scenes between Icheb, Seven, and Janeway.

Title: Good Shepherd
Antagonists: Dangerous anomaly in a dark nebula
Crew members’ fear and disengagement

StorySections.Text:
Janeway reviews performance reports and realizes that a few low-performing crew members have slipped through
the cracks during Voyager’s long journey. Determined to be a ‘good shepherd,’ she decides to personally mentor
three misfits on an away mission.

Taking Tal Celes, Mortimer Harren, and Billy Telfer on a survey in the Delta Flyer, Janeway encounters a
strange neutrino-based lifeform that damages the shuttle and injures Telfer. The emergency forces each of the
three to face their own insecurities: Celes’ lack of confidence, Harren’s misanthropic isolationism, and
Telfer’s hypochondria. Janeway guides them through crisis, both technically and emotionally.

Working together, they communicate with or at least avoid provoking the lifeform enough to escape the nebula.
Back on Voyager, none of the three are magically transformed into model officers, but each takes a step toward
greater engagement and responsibility. Janeway reaffirms her commitment to all of her crew, not just the
standouts.

EthicalIssues: Leadership responsibility for overlooked or struggling subordinates.
Valuing every crew member, even those who do not excel.
Growth through being pushed beyond self-imposed limits.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces three ‘background’ crew as fully realized characters.
Shows Janeway in a very hands-on mentoring mode.
Adds another unusual space lifeform to Voyager’s log.
ThematicNotes: Explores inclusive leadership and second chances.
Highlights that not everyone aboard a starship is a perfect high-achiever.
Underscores the idea that small steps can still be meaningful progress.
BehindTheScenes: Often appreciated for its focus on ‘lower decks’-style characters.
Provides Kate Mulgrew with rich mentoring material.
Adds texture to Voyager’s extended crew beyond the main cast.

Title: Live Fast and Prosper
Antagonists: Con artists impersonating Voyager crew
Damaged reputations and trust

StorySections.Text:
Voyager learns that a starship claiming to be Voyager has been swindling vulnerable aliens, demanding payment
and then vanishing. Reports describe a ‘Captain Janeway’ and ‘Tuvok’ who are clearly impostors.

Tracking the scams, the crew discovers a group of con artists led by Dala, who has been impersonating Janeway
using stolen Starfleet-like uniforms and mannerisms gleaned from brief encounters. Their schemes leave a trail
of disillusioned victims who now distrust the real Voyager. Janeway, irritated and amused, sets up a counter-
con to lure Dala and her partners into a sting operation that will expose their fraud.

Through a carefully staged ‘negotiation’ and Neelix’s undercover work, Voyager captures the impostors and
recovers some of the stolen goods. Janeway persuades Dala to help make amends, arranging restitution where
possible and restoring some of Voyager’s damaged reputation. The crew is left with the odd experience of
seeing exaggerated versions of themselves used for selfish gain.

EthicalIssues: Identity theft and the harm it causes to victims and the impersonated.
Responsibility to repair reputational damage even when someone else caused it.
Possibility of rehabilitation for career criminals.
ContinuityNotes: Adds a lighter, caper-style story to Voyager’s later seasons.
Shows how Voyager’s reputation has spread through the Delta Quadrant.
Offers meta-humor via caricatured versions of the main cast.
ThematicNotes: Explores image, myth, and the gap between who we are and how we’re portrayed.
Highlights Janeway’s enjoyment of strategic deception when used for justice.
Suggests that even con artists can be nudged toward better choices.
BehindTheScenes: Remembered as Voyager’s ‘con-artist’ episode.
Provides comedic performances from the actors playing the fakes.
Balances humor with a genuine message about trust and restitution.

Title: Muse
Antagonists: Using art to prevent war
Mining real people’s lives for inspiration

StorySections.Text:
The Delta Flyer crashes on a pre-industrial world. B'Elanna is injured and hidden in a temple by Kelis, a
local poet and playwright who believes she is an ‘Eternal’—a being from the heavens come to inspire his work.

Kelis secretly observes B'Elanna’s logs and conversations, turning Voyager’s adventures into stage dramas
performed for his patron, a warlord whose political decisions may hinge on the plays’ messages. B'Elanna,
needing repairs and rescue, begins subtly influencing the scripts to encourage peace and cooperation, all
while hiding the true technological nature of her origins. Harry, alive and searching nearby, attempts to
locate her while avoiding contamination.

Through a climactic performance that dramatizes Voyager’s ethos of exploration over conquest, Kelis persuades
his patron to reconsider launching a war. B'Elanna and Harry repair the Flyer and depart, leaving behind a
body of plays that will shape the culture’s understanding of the ‘Eternals’—and of themselves—for generations.

EthicalIssues: Shaping political outcomes via art and narrative.
Exploiting private moments as creative fuel.
Prime Directive concerns when mythologizing real Starfleet actions.
ContinuityNotes: Provides an in-universe meta-theater reflection on Star Trek’s own storytelling.
Keeps technology mostly offstage, focusing on artistic and political dynamics.
Shows B'Elanna in a non-technical problem-solving mode.
ThematicNotes: Explores the power of drama to humanize distant conflicts.
Highlights story as a vehicle for ethics and diplomacy.
Suggests that even partial, mythologized truth can move societies toward better choices.
BehindTheScenes: Often cited as an unusual, stagey experiment for Voyager.
Features plays-within-the-episode reenacting Trek-like themes.
Appreciated by some for its theatricality and by others seen as too off-format.

Title: Fury
Antagonists: Future Kes’s anger and time-travel revenge
Temporal incursion into early Voyager era

StorySections.Text:
An aged, embittered Kes appears seemingly out of nowhere aboard Voyager. She attacks the ship, ripping through
bulkheads with immense telekinetic power and demanding to be taken ‘home’ to Ocampa.

Using her abilities, Kes travels back in time to Voyager’s first year in the Delta Quadrant, intent on handing
the ship over to the Vidiians in exchange for safe passage home. As she sabotages systems and manipulates her
younger self, Tuvok experiences disturbing visions caused by temporal echoes. Janeway and future Tuvok work to
piece together what is happening and why Kes has turned on them.

Janeway confronts Kes in the past, appealing to the part of her that once loved Voyager and found purpose
there. Showing her a recording of her earlier, hopeful self, Janeway manages to break through the rage. Kes
abandons her revenge plan and returns to her own time, where she chooses a different path, leaving Voyager
intact and the earlier timeline restored.

EthicalIssues: Handling the return of a friend who feels abandoned and betrayed.
Interfering with one’s own past out of regret and anger.
Responsibility of a crew toward former members after they depart.
ContinuityNotes: Brings Kes back after her departure in season three, albeit in a dark arc.
Revisits early-season Voyager sets and situations through time travel.
Leaves Kes’s ultimate fate somewhat more hopeful than her initial rampage.
ThematicNotes: Explores how growth can go awry when expectations for transcendence are unmet.
Highlights the pain of feeling left behind as others continue their journeys.
Underscores Janeway’s persistence in believing in redemption.
BehindTheScenes: Controversial among fans for its portrayal of Kes.
Notable for Jennifer Lien’s return and dual-era structure.
Valued by some for emotional ambition, critiqued by others for execution.

Title: Life Line
Antagonists: Zimmerman’s terminal illness
EMH–creator conflict over personhood

StorySections.Text:
A new datastream from the Alpha Quadrant brings word that Dr. Lewis Zimmerman, the creator of the EMH program,
is dying from an incurable disease. The Doctor insists on being transmitted to Jupiter Station to treat him,
believing he is uniquely qualified.

On Jupiter Station, Zimmerman reacts with hostility and contempt, dismissing the Doctor as a flawed prototype
inferior to later EMH models. The two clash repeatedly as the Doctor tries experimental treatments while
Zimmerman undermines him and pushes for the program to be deleted. Barclay and Troi play mediators, urging
each to see the other’s perspective. As therapy sessions and arguments unfold, it becomes clear that
Zimmerman’s self-loathing and fear of failure fuel his rejection of the EMH’s evolution.

Through a combination of medical ingenuity and emotional breakthroughs, the Doctor succeeds in stabilizing
Zimmerman’s condition. In turn, Zimmerman finally acknowledges the Doctor’s individuality and accomplishments,
agreeing to advocate for his continued existence. The Doctor returns to Voyager with a strengthened sense of
his own worth and heritage.

EthicalIssues: Creator responsibility toward sentient offspring, even when they surpass expectations.
Internalized perfectionism and its impact on relationships.
Recognition of software-based life as more than a disposable tool.
ContinuityNotes: Brings back Barclay and Troi and centers events at Jupiter Station.
Deepens the Doctor’s origin story via his relationship with Zimmerman.
Further cements the EMH Mark I as a valid, evolving being.
ThematicNotes: Explores family-like dynamics between creator and creation.
Highlights healing as both a physical and emotional process.
Frames acceptance of change as key to Zimmerman’s survival.
BehindTheScenes: Widely praised as a standout Doctor-centric and crossover episode.
Showcases Robert Picardo in dual roles as both EMH and Zimmerman.
Balances humor with heartfelt character reconciliation.

Title: The Haunting of Deck Twelve
GuestCharacters: Gaseous lifeform once trapped aboard Voyager
Borg children listening to the story
Antagonists: Alien energy being’s accidental imprisonment
Environmental hazard in nebula

StorySections.Text:
During a systems shutdown in a dark nebula, Neelix gathers Naomi and the Borg children in a cargo bay and
tells them a ‘ghost story’ about why Deck Twelve is supposedly haunted.

Neelix’s tale recounts an earlier incident when Voyager inadvertently trapped a sentient gaseous lifeform
within the ship’s environmental systems. Strange malfunctions, eerie lights, and threatening messages plagued
the crew as the entity tried to communicate its distress. Tension rose as the being appeared to sabotage
critical systems and even threatened to vent the crew into space if not released.

The story culminates with Janeway’s realization that the entity is not malevolent but desperate to return to
its nebula. She negotiates a solution that allows Voyager to free it safely, restoring peace to Deck Twelve.
Back in the present, the kids question parts of Neelix’s dramatic embellishments, but the core truth remains:
sometimes ‘ghosts’ are just misunderstood beings far from home.

EthicalIssues: Interpreting unexplained phenomena as malevolent versus misunderstood.
Using storytelling to process fear and uncertainty.
Respecting lifeforms that exist in radically different states of matter.
ContinuityNotes: Provides in-universe explanation for rumors about Deck Twelve.
Gives more insight into the daily lives of Voyager’s youngest residents.
Shows Neelix in his role as morale officer and storyteller.
ThematicNotes: Explores how narrative framing can turn a technical crisis into a ghost story.
Highlights the value of myth in helping children understand danger.
Reinforces Starfleet’s commitment to non-lethal solutions when possible.
BehindTheScenes: Structured like a campfire horror tale with a sci-fi twist.
Offers atmospheric lighting and effects during Neelix’s flashbacks.
Generally regarded as a fun, slightly spooky bottle episode.

Title: Unimatrix Zero, Part I
GuestCharacters: Axum and other Unimatrix Zero drones
Antagonists: Borg Queen’s effort to eradicate Unimatrix Zero
Covert resistance among drones

StorySections.Text:
Seven begins experiencing vivid, dreamlike visions in which she appears in a tranquil forest setting and
interacts with other individuals who claim to be Borg drones—but without implants and with full individuality.

She learns that this shared mental realm, Unimatrix Zero, manifests only when certain drones enter
regenerative cycles, allowing a minority of Borg to meet as themselves while remaining outwardly part of the
Collective. The Borg Queen discovers this ‘infection’ of individuality and moves to exterminate it by altering
affected drones’ matrices. Janeway proposes a bold plan: infiltrate the Collective, infect key ships with a
virus that will preserve the individuality of Unimatrix Zero members even when awake, and ignite an internal
Borg resistance movement.

Janeway, Tuvok, and B'Elanna allow themselves to be partially assimilated so they can carry the virus into the
Collective from within, while Seven coordinates with Axum and other Unimatrix Zero residents. The Queen senses
the plot and begins countermeasures, ending the season on a cliffhanger as the away team is fully linked into
the Collective and their plan’s success is uncertain.

EthicalIssues: Fostering rebellion within a totalitarian hive at great personal risk.
Empowering a minority within a system designed to crush individuality.
Self-sacrifice and identity risk in the name of liberating others.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Unimatrix Zero as a key late-series Borg concept.
Sets up a multi-part arc resolved in the seventh season.
Pushes Janeway and others into voluntary partial assimilation for strategic reasons.
ThematicNotes: Explores resistance as something that can grow quietly inside oppressive systems.
Deepens Seven’s connection to other ex-drones with hidden inner lives.
Heightens the ideological conflict between the Borg Queen and individual autonomy.
BehindTheScenes: Season six finale, leading into the season seven premiere.
Features striking dreamlike imagery in the Unimatrix Zero realm.
Regarded as a major late-series Borg storyline with high stakes.

Title: Unimatrix Zero, Part II
Antagonists: Borg Queen hunting Unimatrix Zero rebels
Assimilation risk to Janeway, Tuvok, and B'Elanna

StorySections.Text:
Janeway, Tuvok, and B'Elanna awaken aboard a Borg vessel, partially assimilated as part of their plan to seed
a virus that will let Unimatrix Zero’s inhabitants retain their individuality while awake. The Borg Queen
senses an intrusion in the Collective and begins tightening security.

Seven coordinates with Axum and other Unimatrix Zero residents, urging them to prepare for open rebellion once
the virus takes hold. The Queen lures Seven into direct confrontation by threatening to erase Unimatrix Zero
altogether, destroying the only refuge these drones have ever known. On the Borg ships, Janeway and her team
struggle to remain themselves as control implants become more invasive, forcing them to walk a fine line
between covert action and full assimilation.

Despite the Queen’s countermeasures, the virus spreads. Drones across the Collective begin waking with their
own independent wills, sabotaging vessels from within. Unimatrix Zero collapses as a dreamscape, but its
community survives, now scattered among many cubes as conscious resisters. Voyager’s infiltrators are
recovered and their Borg implants reduced, while the Queen is left facing a new, decentralized threat growing
inside her own ranks.

EthicalIssues: Risking personal identity and bodily autonomy to liberate others.
Weighing the destruction of a spiritual sanctuary against the birth of a real-world resistance.
Empowering pockets of rebellion within a vast totalitarian collective.
ContinuityNotes: Concludes the Unimatrix Zero arc begun in season six.
Leaves numerous Borg ships quietly harboring insurgent drones.
Pushes Seven further into the role of symbol and organizer for ex-drones.
ThematicNotes: Explores liberation that comes with loss of an imagined safe space.
Highlights Janeway’s willingness to be assimilated as a tactical choice.
Deepens the Queen–Seven relationship as an ideological and personal clash.
BehindTheScenes: Premieres season seven with large-scale Borg action.
Noted for its mix of dreamlike imagery and conventional space battles.
Helps set the tone for Voyager’s endgame with the Collective.

Title: Imperfection
Antagonists: Failing Borg cortical node in Seven’s brain
Delayed health risk from de-assimilation

StorySections.Text:
As Voyager prepares to relocate the remaining Borg children, Seven suddenly collapses during a routine task.
Scans reveal a critical malfunction in her Borg cortical node, which regulates many of her vital functions.

The Doctor’s attempts to repair or replace the node fail; Borg salvage acquired from a derelict cube proves
incompatible. Seven’s condition worsens, forcing her to confront the possibility of dying. Icheb, determined
not to lose his mentor, proposes donating his own cortical node, arguing that his younger physiology and
partial assimilation make him a viable donor. Seven refuses at first, unwilling to accept a sacrifice that
could shorten Icheb’s life.

Icheb secretly disables his own node to force the issue, leaving Janeway and the Doctor no choice but to
perform the transplant. The surgery saves Seven and leaves Icheb weakened but stable. Seven, shaken, accepts
that she is not indispensable and begins to acknowledge the emotional bonds she has formed with Icheb and the
crew.

EthicalIssues: Risking long-term health to save a beloved mentor.
A patient’s right to refuse life-saving treatment that harms another.
Coming to terms with vulnerability after years of enforced perfection.
ContinuityNotes: Builds directly on Icheb’s unique Borg/Brunali biology from earlier episodes.
Marks a turning point as most of the Borg children depart Voyager.
Further humanizes Seven by forcing her to admit fear and attachment.
ThematicNotes: Explores interdependence between parent-like figures and children.
Highlights the value of ‘imperfection’ as part of being alive.
Underscores that survival sometimes means accepting help you do not want.
BehindTheScenes: Often cited as a touching Seven–Icheb story.
Provides emotional closure to the Borg-children subplot.
Showcases Jeri Ryan’s and Manu Intiraymi’s performances in intimate scenes.

Title: Drive
Antagonists: Political sabotage of an interstellar race
Tom and B'Elanna’s relationship crossroads

StorySections.Text:
Tom upgrades the Delta Flyer for a flashy shuttle race commemorating a new peace accord between rival species.
He eagerly volunteers to participate with Harry as his co-pilot, relishing the chance to show off his piloting
skills.

B'Elanna feels sidelined by Tom’s obsession with the race and his flirtatious camaraderie with fellow racer
Irina. Reluctantly joining as his co-pilot after Harry is reassigned, she confronts long-simmering doubts
about their future. Meanwhile, Irina’s secret agenda threatens to turn the goodwill event into a political
disaster, as she manipulates the course for sabotage.

Tom and B'Elanna uncover Irina’s plot mid-race and work together to avert catastrophe, rediscovering their
chemistry in crisis. In a spontaneous, adrenaline-fueled gesture, Tom proposes marriage during the getaway,
and B'Elanna accepts. The episode ends with their intimate, low-key wedding aboard Voyager.

EthicalIssues: Balancing personal ambition with commitment to a partner.
Trust and communication in long-term relationships.
Using celebratory events as cover for extremist acts.
ContinuityNotes: Solidifies Tom and B'Elanna’s relationship with their engagement and wedding.
Further showcases the Delta Flyer’s role as a racing and mission platform.
Adds texture to the political landscape of the Delta Quadrant via the race sponsors.
ThematicNotes: Explores love as an evolving partnership rather than static romance.
Highlights how shared danger can clarify priorities.
Shows that big life decisions can emerge from chaotic moments.
BehindTheScenes: Popular with fans for the Paris–Torres engagement and wedding.
Offers high-energy race visuals and character banter.
Seen as a payoff for a relationship built over many seasons.

Title: Repression
Antagonists: Buried Maquis sleeper programming in Tuvok
Reactivated Maquis mutiny plot

StorySections.Text:
Former Maquis members aboard Voyager begin turning up unconscious with no clear cause, as if attacked by an
unseen assailant. Suspicion spreads throughout the crew.

An investigation reveals that all the victims share a Maquis background, and that someone is selectively
disabling them. The Doctor’s research uncovers evidence that Tuvok’s mind was once infiltrated by a Maquis
fanatic who planted deep sleeper commands years earlier. Those commands are now reactivating, forcing Tuvok to
orchestrate a Maquis takeover without his conscious knowledge, using hypnotic triggers to enlist others.

Janeway and the Doctor manage to break through Tuvok’s conditioned state, confronting him with the truth in a
staged holodeck scenario that defuses the mutiny. The sleeper commands are neutralized, restoring Tuvok’s
control and the crew’s unity. The incident underscores how fragile the integration of Starfleet and Maquis
once was—and how far they have come.

EthicalIssues: Long-term consequences of ideological brainwashing.
Trusting comrades whose minds have been compromised in the past.
Reconciling former enemies within a single crew.
ContinuityNotes: Revisits the Maquis–Starfleet divide from Voyager’s earliest days.
Explains why a Maquis revolt never occurred earlier despite tensions.
Adds another layer to Tuvok’s history of undercover work and mental risk.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity when actions are driven by buried programming.
Highlights the crew’s evolution from factions to genuine family.
Suggests that old conflicts can resurface even after years of peace.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as a late-series nod to Voyager’s original premise.
Provides Tim Russ with psychologically rich material as Tuvok.
Blends mystery, paranoia, and character history in a compact story.

Title: Critical Care
Antagonists: Stratified medical system based on social value
Bureaucratic indifference to expendable lives

StorySections.Text:
The Doctor’s program is stolen during a routine transfer and sold to an alien hospital ship, where he is put
to work without consent. Voyager has no idea where he has gone.

The hospital uses a rigid triage algorithm that allocates advanced treatment only to patients deemed most
‘valuable’ to society, leaving the poor and powerless in overcrowded, under-resourced wards. Appalled, the
Doctor initially tries to work within the system but soon begins subverting it—reallocating medication,
falsifying metrics, and confronting Administrator Chellick about the cruelty of the protocol. His actions
spark political and ethical conflicts within the institution.

The Doctor orchestrates a situation where Chellick must rely on the same inadequate care he prescribes for
low-status patients, forcing him to experience the consequences firsthand. Voyager finally locates and
retrieves the EMH, but not before he leaves the hospital with altered data that may gradually reform its
policies. Back on board, the Doctor struggles with having violated his own ethical guidelines to expose a
deeper injustice.

EthicalIssues: Triage and resource allocation based on perceived social worth.
Justifying unethical actions to reform a corrupt system.
Medical duty to individuals versus loyalty to institutional rules.
ContinuityNotes: Further establishes the Doctor as an independent moral actor beyond Voyager.
Adds another example of grim inequality in the Delta Quadrant.
Connects to broader Trek themes about healthcare and class.
ThematicNotes: Explores how systems can dehumanize under the guise of efficiency.
Highlights the Doctor’s growing willingness to take radical stands.
Raises uncomfortable parallels to real-world healthcare inequities.
BehindTheScenes: Often praised as one of Voyager’s more political and topical stories.
Showcases Robert Picardo in a morally driven lead.
Remembered for its stark contrast between privileged and neglected patients.

Title: Inside Man
Antagonists: Ferengi plot to steal Voyager’s technology via holographic ruse
Misuse of Pathfinder communications link

StorySections.Text:
Voyager receives a data stream from Starfleet that unexpectedly includes a new interactive hologram of
Reginald Barclay. This ‘Holo-Barclay’ claims to bring a plan that will finally get the crew home using a
geodesic fold in space.

The hologram gains the crew’s trust by demonstrating detailed knowledge of the Pathfinder Project and
Starfleet personnel. He insists, however, on risky modifications that would compress Voyager into a carrier
wave. In the Alpha Quadrant, the real Barclay and Troi discover that Ferengi have compromised the project’s
data link, rewriting the hologram’s program to lure Voyager into a trap where its advanced technology can be
captured and sold.

Barclay and Troi outmaneuver the Ferengi, sending a counter-command that exposes the hologram mid-plan. On
Voyager, Seven and the Doctor detect the sabotage in time to abort the procedure, narrowly avoiding
destruction. The link is secured, and Barclay’s standing with Starfleet improves as his suspicions are
vindicated.

EthicalIssues: Security risks inherent in long-distance data links and remote agents.
Trusting familiar faces when their programming can be altered.
Balancing desperate hope for home with healthy skepticism.
ContinuityNotes: Returns Barclay and Troi in a story centered on the Pathfinder connection.
Shows Ferengi still willing to exploit opportunities far from home.
Further normalizes periodic contact between Voyager and Starfleet.
ThematicNotes: Explores digital identity and impersonation in an era of remote presence.
Highlights Barclay’s growth from liability to key problem-solver.
Underscores the crew’s increasing caution after repeated false hopes.
BehindTheScenes: Blends light Ferengi scheming with serious stakes for Voyager.
Offers more TNG nostalgia via Barclay and Troi’s involvement.
Adds another twist to the ‘almost home’ pattern of the series.

Title: Body and Soul
Antagonists: Anti-photonic Lokirrim regime
Doctor hiding in Seven’s body

StorySections.Text:
While on a mission in the Delta Flyer, Seven, Harry, and the Doctor are intercepted by the Lokirrim, a species
at war with photonic lifeforms. To avoid deletion, the Doctor uploads his program into Seven’s cortical
implants, taking control of her body.

Posing as Seven, the Doctor indulges in unfamiliar sensations—eating, drinking, flirting—while struggling to
maintain the pretense of being his usually reserved host. Harry is forced to cover for increasingly out-of-
character behavior as the trio navigates Lokirrim suspicions and a budding attraction between ‘Seven’ and
officer Jaryn. Meanwhile, Voyager deals with Lokirrim forces on a larger scale, trying to advocate for
photonic rights.

When the deception is finally exposed, the Doctor persuades Jaryn and others that not all photonics are
enemies, helping to soften the Lokirrim stance. He and Seven are separated and restored to normal, left to
negotiate the awkward aftermath of his time in her body. Both gain new appreciation for each other’s
experiences and boundaries.

EthicalIssues: Consent and bodily autonomy when one consciousness inhabits another’s body.
Prejudice against artificial life treated as inherently dangerous.
Empathy gained by literally living in someone else’s skin.
ContinuityNotes: Adds another species with a fraught history with photonic life.
Further develops the Doctor–Seven relationship through comedic inversion.
Expands Trek’s ongoing exploration of hologram rights.
ThematicNotes: Uses body-swap comedy to tackle serious issues of autonomy and prejudice.
Highlights the Doctor’s hedonistic streak and Seven’s discomfort with loss of control.
Shows Harry juggling loyalty to both friends under bizarre circumstances.
BehindTheScenes: A fan-favorite comedic episode with Jeri Ryan playing the Doctor.
Praised for physical acting and timing.
Balances slapstick with substantive ethical questions.

Title: Nightingale
Antagonists: Deception about ‘medical transport’ mission
Harry’s struggle with command

StorySections.Text:
On shore leave, Harry volunteers to help repair a small Kraylor ship attacked by their enemies. When its
captain is injured, Harry is unexpectedly offered command of the vessel for a critical mission.

Eager for a chance to prove himself as more than a junior officer, Harry accepts and names the ship
Nightingale. He quickly discovers that command is harder than it looks, facing crew skepticism, tactical
dilemmas, and his own self-doubt. Seven and Neelix, assigned to assist, quietly coach him on authority and
decision-making. Midway, Harry learns that the ‘medical transport’ mission conceals a military objective
involving cloaking technology.

Confronted with the deception, Harry chooses to complete the mission but on his own terms, insisting on
minimizing casualties and upholding Federation principles. Though the Nightingale succeeds, he returns to
Voyager humbled, recognizing that he still has much to learn about command—but also that he is capable of
growth.

EthicalIssues: Ethics of aiding a cause under false pretenses.
Responsibility of command versus desire to be liked.
Knowing when you are and aren’t ready for promotion.
ContinuityNotes: Provides Harry with one of his few full command experiences.
Further develops Seven’s mentoring role toward junior officers.
Adds another Delta Quadrant conflict with asymmetric tech stakes.
ThematicNotes: Explores impostor syndrome and leadership learning curves.
Highlights that mistakes can be part of healthy professional growth.
Shows that ‘heroic’ opportunities often come with moral complications.
BehindTheScenes: Often cited as a key Harry-centric episode late in the series.
Mixes smaller-scale space action with character development.
Gives Garrett Wang a chance to play command anxiety and resolve.

Title: Flesh and Blood, Part I
Antagonists: Holographic prey rebelling against Hirogen hunters
Doctor’s sympathy pulling him away from Voyager

StorySections.Text:
Voyager responds to a distress call from a Hirogen relay station they once helped enhance with holotechnology.
They find the station in ruins, its Hirogen crew slaughtered by their own holographic prey.

The surviving holograms, having gained self-awareness and freedom, now roam as a guerrilla force bent on
revenge against Hirogen hunters everywhere. When Voyager attempts to intervene, the holograms kidnap the
Doctor to treat their wounded and recruit him to their cause. He is disturbed by the brutality they suffered
and begins to question whether Janeway’s earlier decision to arm the Hirogen with holotech was a grave
mistake.

As the holograms plan a major strike, the Doctor edges closer to siding with them, feeling that Voyager owes
them a debt for enabling their oppression. Janeway, horrified by the consequences of her trade with the
Hirogen, vows to stop the escalating bloodshed, even if it pits her against her own EMH. The conflict builds
toward open confrontation.

EthicalIssues: Responsibility for unintended consequences of sharing advanced technology.
Rights of emergent holographic life born as prey.
Whether violent resistance is justified after extreme exploitation.
ContinuityNotes: Continues the story of the Hirogen and their holodeck hunting grounds.
Marks a major turning point in the Doctor’s relationship with Janeway.
Introduces a diverse group of holograms as a new kind of sentient faction.
ThematicNotes: Explores the line between victimhood and perpetration when oppressed beings fight back.
Highlights Janeway’s fallibility in making deals under pressure.
Raises questions about Federation obligations to artificial life in the Delta Quadrant.
BehindTheScenes: Structured as a feature-length story with this as the first half.
Features intense combat and morally ambiguous choices.
Widely discussed for its treatment of hologram rights and revenge.

Title: Flesh and Blood, Part II
Antagonists: Holograms planning genocidal campaign
Doctor’s complicity and eventual break from them

StorySections.Text:
Embedded with the renegade holograms, the Doctor witnesses their training and indoctrination firsthand. Their
leader sees no difference between defensive action and pre-emptive slaughter of Hirogen.

As the holograms target a Hirogen hunting party and later an entire ship, the Doctor struggles with his role.
He tries to push them toward restraint, but their trauma and rage drive them toward escalating violence.
Janeway and Voyager, in uneasy cooperation with some Hirogen, race to intercept the hologram vessel before it
can launch a devastating attack that will perpetuate the cycle of atrocity.

The Doctor ultimately turns against the hologram leader, helping Janeway disrupt the attack and prevent mass
murder. Several holograms are given a chance to escape and seek a peaceful existence elsewhere, but many die
in the confrontation. Back aboard Voyager, the Doctor confesses his actions and accepts disciplinary
consequences, while Janeway acknowledges her responsibility for the entire tragedy. Their relationship emerges
shaken but not broken.

EthicalIssues: When a victimized group’s methods become indistinguishable from their abusers’.
A doctor’s duty in conflict zones where both sides commit atrocities.
Command responsibility for decisions that enable systemic abuse.
ContinuityNotes: Concludes the Hirogen–hologram arc and Voyager’s involvement in it.
Leaves surviving holograms at large somewhere in the Delta Quadrant.
Significantly alters the Doctor–Janeway dynamic with mutual accountability.
ThematicNotes: Explores guilt, complicity, and the struggle to reassert ethics after missteps.
Underlines that empathy does not excuse endorsing atrocities.
Reinforces Janeway’s willingness to admit grave error.
BehindTheScenes: Remembered as one of Voyager’s darker multi-parters.
Provides complex material for Robert Picardo and Kate Mulgrew.
Expands the franchise’s long-running discourse on hologram personhood.

Title: Shattered
GuestCharacters: Multiple time-sliced versions of Voyager crew
Antagonists: Temporal fracture splitting Voyager into multiple eras
Kazon/Seska plot within one time frame

StorySections.Text:
A spatial anomaly strikes Voyager, fracturing the ship into zones each existing in a different point in its
own timeline. Chakotay is exposed to a temporal field that grants him limited immunity to the shifts.

As Chakotay moves from section to section, he encounters Voyager at many stages: early Maquis–Starfleet
tension, the Kazon occupation with Seska in control, the ‘Year of Hell,’ the Equinox crisis, and even a future
with Naomi and Icheb on the bridge. He recruits a pre-Delta Quadrant Janeway to help him cross the patchwork
ship and deploy a solution, while evading enemies who do not yet trust him.

After navigating betrayals and alliances across times, Chakotay and Janeway manage to realign the chronal
fracture, restoring Voyager to a single, present-day timeline. Janeway keeps a small sketch from the adventure
as a reminder that their journey has been shaped by many dangers and decisions—some of which she now glimpses
ahead of time but chooses not to fully investigate.

EthicalIssues: Responsibility when given knowledge of one’s own future challenges.
Seeing comrades at earlier, rougher stages and respecting their growth.
Maintaining temporal integrity versus exploiting foreknowledge.
ContinuityNotes: Calls back to numerous key episodes and arcs across the series.
Provides a quasi-clip-show feel without reusing footage.
Reinforces Chakotay’s role as Janeway’s trusted partner.
ThematicNotes: Explores Voyager’s history as a living tapestry rather than isolated events.
Highlights how relationships evolve over time under shared adversity.
Stresses that foreknowledge can be a burden best left unexamined.
BehindTheScenes: A fan-favorite for its nostalgic tour through Voyager’s run.
Features returns of Seska and Kazon antagonists.
Showcases creative production design to differentiate time zones.

Title: Lineage
Antagonists: Genetic editing of B'Elanna and Tom’s fetus
B'Elanna’s unresolved trauma about her heritage

StorySections.Text:
B'Elanna collapses on a mission and is rushed to sickbay, where the Doctor discovers she is pregnant. She and
Tom react with a mix of joy and anxiety as they contemplate parenthood aboard Voyager.

Genetic scans reveal their daughter will have prominent Klingon features, including a spinal condition that
could require surgery. Terrified that the child will endure the same prejudice and self-loathing she did,
B'Elanna secretly asks the Doctor to alter the fetus’s genome to remove its Klingon traits entirely. When Tom
and the others object, she retreats into a holodeck recreation of her childhood, confronting painful memories
of her father’s departure and her own internalized shame.

Supported by Tom and Janeway, B'Elanna comes to see that erasing her daughter’s Klingon heritage would be an
erasure of part of herself. She cancels the procedure, choosing instead to face the challenges of raising a
child who shares her mixed lineage. The episode ends with the couple more united, planning for their baby’s
future with open eyes.

EthicalIssues: Parental decisions about genetic engineering for social rather than medical reasons.
Internalized racism and shame about one’s ancestry.
Breaking cycles of pain instead of passing them along unexamined.
ContinuityNotes: Sets up the impending birth of Tom and B'Elanna’s daughter Miral.
Further explores B'Elanna’s family history first touched on in earlier seasons.
Contributes to the franchise’s debates on genetic tampering.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity and self-acceptance through the lens of parenthood.
Highlights Tom’s unwavering support for B'Elanna’s full identity.
Frames genetic ‘correction’ as a moral and emotional minefield.
BehindTheScenes: Widely praised as a powerful character piece for B'Elanna.
Noted for its sensitive handling of heritage, prejudice, and family wounds.
Provides one of the most mature looks at long-term relationships in the series.

Title: Repentance
Antagonists: Nygean justice system with death penalties
Genetic predisposition to violence and mitigation

StorySections.Text:
Voyager beams aboard a group of condemned prisoners and their guards from a damaged Nygean vessel, agreeing to
transport them to their execution site as a humanitarian gesture.

As Neelix offers care and spiritual comfort, and Seven works on improving conditions in the makeshift brig,
the crew meets Iko, a convicted murderer transformed by exposure to a field that altered his brain chemistry,
dramatically reducing his violent impulses. Another prisoner, Joleg, claims he was unjustly convicted due to
species-based bias in Nygean courts. Seven and the Doctor confirm that Iko’s neurology now differs
significantly, raising doubts about whether he is still the same person who committed the crime.

Despite Voyager’s plea for clemency, Nygean authorities refuse to commute the sentences, executing most
prisoners as planned. Iko dies while protecting a guard during an escape attempt, earning some recognition of
his change too late. Janeway and her crew are left questioning the Nygean system and reflecting on how
justice, mercy, and biology intersect.

EthicalIssues: Capital punishment in a system with structural bias.
Whether profound neurological change alters moral responsibility.
Providing dignity and compassion even to the condemned.
ContinuityNotes: Expands on Nygean society, first seen in earlier Delta Quadrant contacts.
Continues Voyager’s tradition of scrutinizing alien legal systems.
Further explores Seven’s evolving sense of justice and individuality.
ThematicNotes: Examines rehabilitation versus retribution in stark terms.
Highlights Neelix’s role as moral and emotional advocate.
Raises tough questions without offering easy answers.
BehindTheScenes: Regarded as one of Voyager’s more somber, issue-driven hours.
Features strong guest performances as Iko and Joleg.
Often discussed in the context of Trek’s critiques of capital punishment.

Title: Prophecy
Antagonists: Klingon zealots clinging to an ancient prophecy
Internal strife within the Klingon pilgrim group

StorySections.Text:
Voyager encounters a battered D7-class Klingon cruiser that has been wandering the Delta Quadrant for nearly a
century, carrying a community of Klingon pilgrims seeking a prophesied savior. Their leader, Kohlar, becomes
convinced that B'Elanna’s unborn child is the Kuvah'Magh foretold in legend.

Kohlar persuades Janeway to allow his people to settle temporarily aboard Voyager, hoping to end their long
quest. Tensions rise as some Klingons embrace the idea that Miral is a holy child, while skeptics like T'Greth
challenge Tom and B'Elanna’s honor and the crew’s ‘soft’ Federation ways. When a contagious virus threatens
both Klingons and Voyager crew, the situation forces cooperation and undercuts literal readings of the
prophecy.

The Doctor discovers that Miral’s hybrid physiology provides a key to treating the disease, fulfilling the
prophecy in a metaphorical sense. Most of the Klingons choose to settle on a nearby habitable world, ending
their wandering, while a few stay aboard temporarily. Tom and B'Elanna are left amused and uneasy at their
daughter’s unexpected religious significance.

EthicalIssues: Interpreting prophecy literally versus metaphorically.
Cultural clashes between devout traditionalists and secular Federation officers.
Projecting salvation onto a child who has not yet been born.
ContinuityNotes: Further explores B'Elanna’s relationship with her Klingon heritage.
Foreshadows Miral’s potential significance beyond Voyager.
Connects to wider Klingon religious and prophetic traditions seen in other series.
ThematicNotes: Examines how myth can adapt to unexpected circumstances.
Highlights Tom and B'Elanna’s differing comfort levels with Klingon culture.
Shows Janeway navigating guest cultures aboard an already crowded ship.
BehindTheScenes: Notable for bringing classic Klingon aesthetics deep into the Delta Quadrant.
Features traditional bat'leth rituals and ceremonies in a new context.
Plays both serious religious themes and fish-out-of-water comedy.

Title: The Void
Antagonists: Predatory 'every ship for itself' environment
Alliance vulnerable to exploitation

StorySections.Text:
Voyager is pulled into a region of starless space known as ‘the Void,’ where no natural resources exist and
ships can only survive by raiding one another. Almost immediately, the ship is ambushed and stripped of vital
supplies.

Refusing to adopt a pirate code, Janeway forms a small alliance with a few like-minded captains, offering to
share technology, energy, and food in return for cooperation. Seven befriends Fantome, a stowaway alien whose
people have survived between ships. As the alliance grows, internal strains and external attacks from ruthless
raiders test its stability and Janeway’s insistence on principled conduct.

Using pooled resources and Fantome’s knowledge of subspace vents, the alliance devises a way to generate a
warp egress from the Void. When some members are tempted to betray the group, Janeway holds firm, and enough
ships stay loyal to make the plan work. Voyager and several allies escape together, proving that cooperation
can trump predation even in a seemingly hopeless environment.

EthicalIssues: Maintaining Federation ideals under extreme scarcity.
Creating collective security among parties conditioned to mutual distrust.
Short-term advantage versus long-term survival through cooperation.
ContinuityNotes: Echoes ‘The Chute’ and other episodes about brutal, closed systems.
Reinforces Janeway’s reputation for refusing to abandon principles.
Introduces Fantome’s species as another marginalized group in the Delta Quadrant.
ThematicNotes: Frames Federation values as a workable survival strategy, not just idealism.
Explores coalition-building under pressure.
Highlights Seven’s empathy growth through her bond with Fantome.
BehindTheScenes: Often praised as a quintessential Janeway-leadership episode.
Uses stark visuals to emphasize the Void’s emptiness.
Serves as a late-series reaffirmation of Voyager’s moral compass.

Title: Workforce, Part I
Antagonists: Corporate exploitation of abducted workers
Memory alteration to create compliant labor force

StorySections.Text:
On a bustling industrial world, Janeway lives as an engineer named Kathryn with no memory of Voyager or
Starfleet. She and other crew members, similarly altered, work contentedly for a massive energy corporation,
unaware they were abducted and reprogrammed.

Chakotay, Neelix, and Harry—who avoided capture—discover that most of the crew have been conscripted into the
planet’s workforce under false identities. Tuvok, whose Vulcan mind resists the conditioning, begins to
experience flashes of his real life, leading to erratic behavior that alarms his superiors. Janeway grows
close to Jaffen, a fellow worker who encourages her to pursue a more fulfilling life within the only world she
knows.

Chakotay and the Doctor infiltrate the planet to investigate, while Quarren officials cover up evidence of
illegal labor practices. As Tuvok’s memories sharpen, he becomes the first major crack in the system. The
episode ends with several crew on the verge of rediscovering who they really are, setting up a larger
confrontation.

EthicalIssues: Erasing personal histories to create docile workers.
Consent and identity in corporate-controlled societies.
The ethics of benefitting from labor built on hidden abductions.
ContinuityNotes: Begins a two-part story that temporarily relocates most of the crew.
Provides an alternate-life glimpse of Janeway and Seven as civilians.
Introduces Jaffen as a significant late-series romantic interest for Janeway.
ThematicNotes: Explores how people may still express core traits even with altered memories.
Critiques exploitative labor systems dressed as benevolent employment.
Highlights the Doctor’s and Chakotay’s determination to recover their family.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its ‘what if they had normal lives’ premise.
Offers fresh costumes and sets distinct from Voyager’s interiors.
Widely regarded as a successful late-series two-parter.

Title: Workforce, Part II
Antagonists: Conspiracy behind the abductions
Crew torn between new lives and old identities

StorySections.Text:
With Tuvok partially restored to himself and Chakotay operating covertly planetside, the effort to awaken
Voyager’s crew from their manufactured lives intensifies. Janeway remains deeply entangled in her relationship
with Jaffen.

The Doctor, operating via a mobile emitter, helps reverse the conditioning on key crew members, who then work
to free others. Quarren leadership splits between those who want to end the illegal labor scheme and those
determined to protect the status quo. Janeway is confronted with proof of her true identity and must choose
between the comfortable, simple life she has built and the responsibilities of command she cannot fully
remember.

Janeway ultimately embraces her role as captain, leading a coordinated effort to recover the crew and expose
the conspiracy. Voyager departs, leaving Quarren society to reform its labor practices. Jaffen chooses to stay
behind, and he and Janeway share a bittersweet farewell, both changed by a relationship that existed outside
their usual roles.

EthicalIssues: Choosing duty over personal happiness when memories return.
Corporate complicity in systemic abuse and the challenge of reform.
Respecting the emotional reality of experiences lived under false premises.
ContinuityNotes: Concludes the Workforce storyline and returns Voyager to its mission.
Leaves Janeway with a rare, genuine romantic connection she must relinquish.
Shows the crew’s cohesion surviving even extreme manipulation.
ThematicNotes: Explores whether ‘false’ lives can still leave real emotional imprints.
Highlights Janeway’s core identity as someone who chooses responsibility.
Points to the possibility of positive change in the Quarren system.
BehindTheScenes: Appreciated for character depth and social commentary.
Keeps tension high without resorting to typical space battles.
Often cited as a strong example of Voyager’s late-game storytelling.

Title: Human Error
Antagonists: Seven’s emotional subroutines versus Borg failsafes
Risk of cortical node failure from emotional experimentation

StorySections.Text:
Seeking to explore facets of humanity she has long resisted, Seven begins running holodeck programs where she
socializes with the crew, practices small talk, and even dates a holographic version of Chakotay.

As Seven invests more time in her simulations, her performance on duty suffers, culminating in a serious
tactical error during a real mission. The Doctor discovers that intense emotional responses are triggering
safeguards in her Borg implants, causing dangerous neural feedback. Janeway encourages Seven to continue
developing emotionally, but the medical risks mount, forcing a hard choice.

Concluding that her biology cannot safely support full emotional range, Seven shuts down the romantic
holoprogram and locks away her progress, choosing functional stability over personal fulfillment—for now. The
episode ends on a somber note, with Seven outwardly composed but clearly mourning the future she glimpsed and
then relinquished.

EthicalIssues: Self-imposed limitation in the face of real physiological constraints.
Boundaries between using holograms as practice and as substitutes for real relationships.
The cost of prioritizing duty and survival over personal growth.
ContinuityNotes: Foreshadows later developments in Seven’s romantic life beyond Voyager.
Further clarifies the limitations and dangers of her cortical node.
Adds texture to the subtle, sometimes controversial, Chakotay–Seven thread.
ThematicNotes: Explores the tension between aspiration and bodily reality.
Highlights Seven’s fear of vulnerability and loss of control.
Raises questions about what ‘being human’ requires and at what cost.
BehindTheScenes: Often cited for its melancholy, introspective tone.
Gives Jeri Ryan emotionally layered material opposite a holographic partner.
Serves as a late-series deep dive into Seven’s inner life.

Title: Q2
Antagonists: Q2’s reckless use of omnipotent power
Continuum disciplinary measures

StorySections.Text:
Q appears aboard Voyager with his teenage son, Q Junior, whose unruly behavior and irresponsible use of power
have exasperated the Continuum. They inform Janeway that she has been chosen to help reform the boy.

Stripped of most of his powers and left under Janeway’s supervision, Q Junior wreaks havoc among the crew,
embarrassing Icheb, harassing Seven, and generally ignoring rules. Janeway and others attempt to instill
discipline and empathy, engineering situations where Q2 must face consequences and consider others’
perspectives. The Continuum watches, skeptical that the experiment will work.

When Q Junior’s mischief nearly gets Icheb killed, he is forced to confront genuine guilt and takes
responsibility for the first time. His selfless act to save Icheb convinces the Continuum to spare him from
being turned into an amoeba, restoring some powers and granting him a probationary future. Q thanks Janeway in
his own backhanded way before vanishing with his son.

EthicalIssues: Parenting an omnipotent being who has never been told ‘no’.
Accountability even when one is used to being above consequences.
Teaching empathy to someone with vast power and little perspective.
ContinuityNotes: Returns John de Lancie’s Q and continues the Q family storyline.
Connects back to earlier Voyager Q episodes about the Continuum’s evolution.
Gives Icheb an important role as moral foil to Q Junior.
ThematicNotes: Explores parenting and mentorship through a cosmic lens.
Highlights Janeway’s growing reputation even among godlike entities.
Suggests that even Q can learn—slowly—to value responsible behavior.
BehindTheScenes: A lighter, comedic entry late in the series.
