Features over-the-top Q antics and Continuum politics.
Offers closure of sorts to Voyager’s Q arc.

Title: Author, Author
GuestCharacters: Holo-publisher at the Federation News Service
Antagonists: Publisher exploiting the Doctor’s work without consent
Federation law’s ambiguity on hologram rights

StorySections.Text:
With regular communication to Earth now possible, the Doctor submits a holonovel, ‘Photons Be Free,’ to a
Federation publisher. The interactive story presents a dystopian starship where a holographic doctor is abused
by a bigoted organic crew clearly modeled on Voyager.

When the crew sees their unflattering analogues, they are outraged, while the Doctor insists that the
holonovel is a legitimate critique of hologram treatment. The publisher moves to release it against his
wishes, citing a contract. A legal battle ensues over who owns the work: its programmer ‘property’ or the
sentient EMH who created it. Testimony from Voyager’s crew and Alpha Quadrant witnesses lays bare the
uncomfortable truth about Mark I EMH use in Dilithium mines.

The arbiter rules that while the Doctor is not yet recognized as a full Federation citizen, he does have
certain rights as an artist, including control over his work’s distribution. The holonovel is revised with
input from the crew, and its release sparks broader debate about holographic personhood. For the Doctor, it
marks a major step toward legal and social recognition.

EthicalIssues: Intellectual property and moral rights for artificial authors.
Exploiting sentient programs as disposable labor.
Using art as a vehicle for social critique and reform.
ContinuityNotes: Builds on TNG’s ‘The Measure of a Man’ by applying similar questions to holograms.
References EMH Mark I reassignments seen in prior canon.
Advances the in-universe conversation about AI rights in Starfleet.
ThematicNotes: Explores how storytelling can expose systemic injustice.
Highlights tension between personal grievances and fair depiction of friends.
Suggests that legal change often begins with incremental rulings.
BehindTheScenes: Widely praised as a spiritual successor to major Trek courtroom episodes.
Gives Robert Picardo and the ensemble strong comedic and dramatic beats.
Frequently ranked among Voyager’s most thematically important episodes.

Title: Friendship One
GuestCharacters: Vaadwaur-descended planet inhabitants (actually a different species: survivors)
Antagonists: Aftermath of early Earth probe causing planetary catastrophe
Hostage crisis driven by deep resentment

StorySections.Text:
Starfleet orders Voyager to divert from its course to locate Friendship One, an early 21st-century Earth probe
sent before first contact with Vulcan, which has not been heard from in centuries.

The probe is found on a devastated world whose atmosphere is poisoned by antimatter fallout. The planet’s
survivors blame the probe for inspiring experiments that led to nuclear-scale disaster, seeing Earth as
ultimately responsible. When an away team is taken hostage by desperate locals demanding evacuation, Janeway
must confront the reality that pre-warp human outreach indirectly contributed to this tragedy.

Voyager helps repair atmospheric systems enough to make the world slowly more habitable, and a limited number
of survivors are evacuated. Janeway sends a somber report to Starfleet urging greater caution with unmonitored
probes, acknowledging that even well-intentioned exploration can have catastrophic unintended consequences.

EthicalIssues: Historical responsibility for harm caused by long-ago exploratory actions.
The limits of apology and restitution across vast spans of time.
Tension between the ideal of exploration and respect for those harmed by it.
ContinuityNotes: Shows Starfleet’s dealing with pre-Federation legacies like Friendship One.
One of the rare times Voyager is given a direct mission from Earth.
Deepens Trek’s self-reflection on its optimistic spacefaring origins.
ThematicNotes: Explores colonial and technological fallout themes in a grounded way.
Highlights Janeway’s willingness to accept institutional culpability.
Frames exploration as requiring humility, not just pride.
BehindTheScenes: Known for its bleak, post-apocalyptic atmosphere.
Offers strong moral material for Janeway and the away team.
Often discussed as one of the series’ more somber late episodes.

Title: Natural Law
Antagonists: Energy barrier isolating Ventuan culture
Ledosian desire to penetrate and exploit the region

StorySections.Text:
A shuttle accident strands Chakotay and Seven on a planet within a protected jungle region, separated from the
technologically advanced Ledosian cities by a mysterious energy barrier.

They discover the Ventu, a pre-warp indigenous people who live in harmony with the environment and appear
protected by the barrier, which was erected by an ancient advanced species. As Chakotay integrates with the
community and is treated for his injuries, Seven slowly gains appreciation for the Ventu’s way of life.
Meanwhile, Tom Paris deals with Ledosian air-traffic bureaucracy after a minor infraction, highlighting the
planet’s rigid regulations.

When Ledosian authorities learn of the barrier breach, they plan to bring modern technology and ‘aid’ to the
Ventu, likely disrupting their culture. In line with Prime Directive principles, Voyager helps restore the
barrier, preserving the Ventu’s isolation while leaving diplomatic channels open for future, more careful
contact. Paris accepts his penalties, illustrating respect for local law despite its pettiness.

EthicalIssues: Prime Directive tensions around intervening in or protecting pre-warp cultures.
What constitutes ‘help’ versus cultural disruption.
Respecting local laws even when they appear trivial or excessive.
ContinuityNotes: Adds another example of ancient guardian technology protecting a less advanced people.
Provides further grounding for Chakotay as an anthropologically minded officer.
Gives Tom a lighter B-plot about local regulations.
ThematicNotes: Explores environmental and cultural preservation themes.
Highlights Seven’s capacity for learning from non-technological societies.
Balances serious Prime Directive issues with a comedic side thread.
BehindTheScenes: Remembered as Voyager’s last substantial Prime Directive case.
Features lush planet-side locations and Ventu language work.
Viewed as a classic-style Trek anthropology story late in the run.

Title: Homestead
Antagonists: Corporate exploitation of Talaxian colony’s asteroid home
Neelix’s choice between Voyager and a new family

StorySections.Text:
Voyager discovers a Talaxian mining colony living inside an asteroid field, decades away from the Talaxian
homeworld. Neelix is surprised and delighted to find kindred people so deep in the Delta Quadrant.

He befriends Dexa and her young son Brax, gradually becoming a father figure as he helps defend the colony
against a powerful mining consortium intent on evicting them. Voyager offers support, but the Talaxians must
ultimately stand their ground. Neelix finds himself deeply attached to the community and the domestic life he
glimpses there.

After a successful defensive stand that forces the miners to negotiate, Neelix faces a painful decision:
remain with Voyager for the final leg of its journey or stay with Dexa, Brax, and the colony to help them
build a future. With Janeway’s blessing and an emotional farewell from the crew—complete with a rare smile
from Tuvok—Neelix chooses to stay, finally finding a home of his own.

EthicalIssues: Choosing between found families when paths diverge.
Community self-defense against corporate displacement.
Letting a beloved friend go when it is best for them.
ContinuityNotes: Serves as Neelix’s farewell episode before the series finale.
Resolves his long-running search for belonging and purpose.
Leaves a Starfleet envoy in the Talaxian community for future contact.
ThematicNotes: Explores themes of home, identity, and adoption.
Highlights Janeway’s willingness to release valued crew for their happiness.
Gives emotional payoff to Neelix–Tuvok relationship in a quiet moment.
BehindTheScenes: Widely regarded as a fitting, heartfelt send-off for Neelix.
Often remembered for Tuvok’s small but meaningful gesture of dancing.
Acts as a pre-finale goodbye to one of Voyager’s most distinctive characters.

Title: Renaissance Man
GuestCharacters: Hierarchical aliens from earlier season (Lokirrim-like? actually Hierarchy)
Antagonists: Hierarchy coercing the Doctor into betraying Voyager
Layered deceptions aboard the ship

StorySections.Text:
Returned to Delta Quadrant patrol, the Doctor and Janeway are confronted by Hierarchy operatives who threaten
to destroy Voyager unless she surrenders the ship’s warp core. They intercept the two on a shuttle, forcing
the Doctor into a secret mission.

The Doctor, under duress, impersonates multiple crew members using his holomatrix—Tuvok, Janeway, and
others—to manipulate systems and crew into preparing the warp core for theft while hiding his actions. His
increasingly bizarre behavior raises suspicion, and the real Janeway, held captive, tries to engineer an
escape and warn her crew. The Doctor’s internal conflict grows as he juggles roles and lies.

Ultimately, the Doctor turns the tables on the Hierarchy, feeding them false data and engineering a rescue for
Janeway while preventing the theft. Severely damaged, he later experiences what he believes to be his final
moments, confessing a cascade of humorous and heartfelt ‘secrets’ to the crew—only to learn he will recover.
The incident leaves everyone more aware of his capacities and vulnerabilities.

EthicalIssues: Coercion of an individual to betray their family under threat.
Identity strain from constantly shifting roles and telling lies.
The need to forgive actions made under extreme duress.
ContinuityNotes: Brings back the Hierarchy from ‘Tinker Tenor Doctor Spy’.
Further demonstrates the Doctor’s flexibility as a physical performer.
Serves as a near-finale comedic-thriller for the EMH.
ThematicNotes: Explores how far the Doctor will go to protect the crew.
Uses impersonation to highlight his understanding of each character.
Reflects on his growth through his ‘deathbed’ confessions.
BehindTheScenes: Known for Robert Picardo’s rapid-fire multi-role performance.
Blends suspense with screwball humor effectively.
Acts as a final showcase episode for the Doctor before the finale.

Title: Endgame, Part I
Antagonists: Admiral Janeway’s temporal incursion to alter history
Borg transwarp hub controlling network of corridors

StorySections.Text:
In an alternate future, an older Admiral Janeway attends a ceremony marking Voyager’s eventual return to
Earth—decades after it was stranded. Many crew have aged, some have died, and others carry lasting scars.
Haunted by the cost, Admiral Janeway decides the timeline is unacceptable.

Defying Starfleet orders, she steals a timeship and travels back to intercept Voyager in the Delta Quadrant,
offering present-day Janeway advanced technology and a plan to get home using a Borg transwarp hub. Their
encounter pits Admiral Janeway’s regret and ruthlessness against Captain Janeway’s commitment to letting
history unfold naturally. The Borg Queen becomes aware of temporal interference, complicating any attempt to
strike at the hub.

The two Janeways clash over strategy: a safer route home that leaves the hub intact versus a riskier plan that
destroys it and deals a crippling blow to the Borg. Meanwhile, hints of future tragedies—including Seven’s
death and Tuvok’s decline—hang over the crew. The first part ends with a daring infiltration of Borg space in
motion, the full scope of the sacrifice still unclear.

EthicalIssues: Rewriting history to spare friends at the cost of temporal integrity.
Balancing personal grief against broader strategic opportunities.
Responsibility to dismantle oppressive powers when given a chance.
ContinuityNotes: Establishes the ‘prime’ future timeline that Admiral Janeway aims to change.
Defines the Borg transwarp hub as a central node in the Collective’s reach.
Deepens the Janeway–Seven and Janeway–Chakotay relationships via future glimpses.
ThematicNotes: Explores self-confrontation between two versions of the same leader.
Highlights the weight of years-long command decisions on a captain’s conscience.
Poses the question of what price is acceptable for a quicker victory.
BehindTheScenes: Sets up Voyager’s series finale with high stakes and time travel.
Features heavy makeup and future-era Starfleet designs.
Often compared structurally to TNG’s ‘All Good Things…’.

Title: Endgame, Part II
Antagonists: Attack on the Borg transwarp hub
Admiral Janeway’s suicide mission into the Collective

StorySections.Text:
Continuing their incursion into Borg space, present-day Voyager prepares to ride a transwarp conduit to Earth,
while Admiral Janeway sets off alone on a different path deeper into the Collective.

Captain Janeway leads Voyager in a spectacular assault inside a transwarp conduit, fighting off cubes and
spheres as they attempt to use the hub’s network as a shortcut. Admiral Janeway infiltrates the Borg Queen’s
Unicomplex, offering herself as bait. She infects the Collective with a neurolytic pathogen, intending to
collapse the hub and cripple the Borg from within, fully aware that it will kill her.

As the pathogen ravages the Collective and the Unicomplex begins to self-destruct, Voyager escapes through a
conduit that opens directly into the Sol system, bursting out in front of a stunned Starfleet armada. The crew
finally sets foot on Earth, their journey shortened but enriched by the years they did spend in the Delta
Quadrant. The series ends with Voyager heading toward home, silhouetted against Earth and a new, unwritten
future.

EthicalIssues: Self-sacrifice to rewrite a painful history for others.
Using time travel as both a strategic weapon and a personal act of atonement.
Accepting that some growth came from hardship even as one chooses a better path.
ContinuityNotes: Concludes Voyager’s seven-year journey with a return to Earth.
Deals a massive blow to the Borg, leaving their future status ambiguous.
Leaves some character futures open to later novels and other media.
ThematicNotes: Explores legacy: what remains of a journey if its timeline is altered.
Highlights Janeway’s defining traits—defiance, cunning, and protectiveness—at their peak.
Suggests that alternate futures can still matter emotionally even after being overwritten.
BehindTheScenes: A visually ambitious finale with large-scale Borg effects.
Generated debate over pacing and epilogue length among fans.
Remains a key milestone in the broader Star Trek timeline.
